full_transcript: ninh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new off record wasted years this is the latest full-length LP from California hardcore punk outfit off a band that is pretty much infamous for its throwback punk rock sound a sound that literally works off the blueprint of Black Flag's nervous breakdown 7-inch an early release from the hardcore punk outfit which the lead singer of off Keith Morris was on in the short span of time in which he fronted the band Black Flag then he actually went on to Front Circle Jerks and the other members of offer seasoned vets as well bring experience and connections to seminal acts in punk rock or just underground rock in general and to be completely honest while yeah this record this band is a bit of a throwback I don't really mind this flavor of punk rock coming back especially since I think the sound of the nervous breakdown EP as well as a lot of the tracks from the first four years compilation from Black Flag had a lot more potential than they were actually given in the short amount of time that these songs were made the return of the sound was it's had an offs debut first four EPS back in 2010 release that was a fantastic continuation of these old hardcore punk tropes except with more clarity more composure I think more maturity too but in a good way it's like at this point hardcore punk finally has the experience and the knowledge to justify the incredible anger it's always harbored for all these years and it's hard for me to boy them I love this record down to nostalgia considering how well this sound is being performed on this thing not only that but a lot of the issues addressed in the lyrics feel pretty current now when off came back with a self-titled record in 2012 it was a bit of a redo the same sound a lot of the same aesthetics although a little less impressive because of the redundancy and sound and every in comparison with their last album and on top of that the mix on this thing was slightly out of whack the guitars and the vocals just kind of felt out of proportion however these mixing issues seem to have been fixed on this latest release from off wasted years there's a lot more instrumental balance on this LP although in comparison with previous releases I would say it's a tad heavier but outside of that offf style really hasn't changed in any significant kind of way they are still delivering high-octane punk rock with a vintage flare that couldn't be more convincing if they haven't impressed you yet with their previous releases chances are they're not going to be impressing you with this one and if they have been impressing you I guess the question is how long can they continue doing it as they seem to just be kind of repeating themselves for me personally as long as off continues to do this sound well and do it justice they will most likely have my ear in some capacity and for me doing the style of music well means memorable riffs it means visceral performances it means hearing Keith Morris's uncompromising ly angry and socially aware lyrics as indebted to the Past as they are I think off makes really captivating punk rock music with an infectious energy punchy messages and relatively short song lengths as far as what these songs are about I'm loving a lot of what off brings to the table like being voted out by the powers that be being broken down ground up in the land of the free it's moments like this where Keith Morrison's incredible sarcasm as he recites patriotic lines like this that really makes the track same goes for the track red white and black where the lyrics address things like your possessions being repossessed and surveillance or the song all I can grab which is a track about extreme greed or over our heads which seems to be a track about the imperialistic wars that are being waged right now as I mentioned before the riffs on this thing a lot of power chords they're pretty speedy every once in a while off really changes up the pace by doing a slower riff maybe you break down something a bit heavier a bit more menacing like on the track no easy escape everyone while there's a chaotic guitar solo or a bright wailing guitar lead so yeah there is a very slight degree of variety on this LP but it's just 23 minutes of incredibly fast aggressive socially aware music so it does tend to run a little homogeneous and maybe this becomes more apparent when some of the lyrics on these tracks aren't that gripping because then all that you really have to ride on are the riffs which tend to sound similar to other riffs on this very album like Legion of evil or wasted years the title track on this thing and the similarities run even deeper when comparing these tracks to songs that off.have release on their previous records if there's more than one way to skin this cat off is certainly not interested in finding out about it they definitely flirt with that idea on the track you must be damned which is one minute and 50 seconds long which is almost like progressive rock length for off and generally a lot of the songs on this LP are longer than tracks on previous releases they're not a single song on this record that dips under the 1 minute mark however these longer songs and this extra effort on this record doesn't really add up into any meteor or more detailed songs any increase in ambition and the songwriting style that off brings to the table off does not use this time to make their hooks stickier off doesn't use this time to add any real major surprises into this record I can't say I'm disappointed because I did get what I expected from off I got a good hardcore punk record however I feel like off is at a point where they have proven that yes they've resurrected the hardcore monster it's back from the dead however I feel that well why not experiment with it a bit without completely bastardizing it and continuing to do the genre justice or at least change up the riffs or add more melodies things that are going to make these songs feel distinct from other songs the band has previously recorded if any group is capable of doing either of these two things it is off I have complete faith in their ability to go down that road if they so choose to but as of right now I'm just kind of feeling a decent too strong 7 on this new LP of theirs transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana off wasted years forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Tony ballina record distant dismissed Tony Molina is a California singer-songwriter who is following up a seven and she dropped on Matador Records a little while back as well as the embarrassing times EP he has also put in time as a vocalist and a guitar player for the punk band of ins a band whose sound is loud it's lo-fi it's poppy it's sweet its melodic its energetic a lot of these same characteristics carry on into Tony's music as well the dude has an addiction to power pop groups like Weezer and underground or indie rock from the 90s like that is her junior or Elliott Smith heat miser Seba dough plus a lot of the songs that Tony writes and records are vibrantly colored with harmonized super harmonized guitar solos that occasionally show off a classical music influence as well so you know there's definitely some Fitness underneath all that grime on Tony's records and the songs that this guy brings to the table on his LPS on this record are a mix of ballads very pretty interludes and sort of stone-faced power pop rockers all of which are packaged into super short song lengths typically landing somewhere in the thirty second to one minute mark now this LP that we're talking about in this video was put out late last year was a bit of an underground release when under the radar this year Slumberland records is reissuing it it's 12 songs the album itself runs just under 12 minutes and every single one of these tracks are boiled down to their most basic of elements there might be a catchy riff or a vocal melody starting off the track and then there's a verse and maybe if you're lucky the song ends off with a spectacular melodic guitar solo but Tony's ultra simplified approach doesn't necessarily mean that there is a lack of effort on these songs I mean there is an immediate sweetness to nearly all the songs here and the guitar solos are just really fun so not only on a level is the instrumentation on this thing impressive but this is a bit of a concept record a break up record so many songs on this LP about heartbreak the end of a relationship moving on past that initial breakup point Tony sings about missing this person going crazy being around this person having been in a relationship where this person would would build him up just to tear him down and even though Tony's lyrical approach on this LP can be pretty basic at times every once in a while lyric will stick out that's like huh like the glass is only being filled for the chance to have it spilled Oh despite all the depressing breakup imagery it is a fun little album and an LP whose pacing is so fast these songs start and so quickly that I mean it's it's hard not to repeat the album the album is over and done with and starting right back at the beginning before I even know it and the beginning doesn't sound too much unlike the ending you know at least when you're first listening to the record so it's kind of like to me this album is the musical equivalent to a Jif a gift a guy a guy but it's not just how fast these songs start and end it's how quickly they surrender their sweetest moments like a cheap one-night stand that gives this record an incomparable amount of replayability I will try to go into the songs themselves a little bit but they are so freakin brief all the guitar riffs are fairly catchy and straightforward they have a really crunchy tone to them the bass the drums are hidden away in the background the vocals seemed overdubbed for a nice very layered effect that makes them kind of pop out it's a rough recording but the songs shine through even with the sort of apathetic indie rock vocals that are layered on top of this thing I love the vocal melody on the track nowhere to go the song can't believe has one of my favorite chord progressions on this entire LP wandering boy poet is a really nice acoustic ballad on this thing nothing I can do is this really slow heavy distorted monolithic in comparison to the other songs on here slow burner the sick-ass roof is really nice pretty acoustic intro sick-ass riff tony's got a sense of humor and the song don't come back is one of the longer tracks on this LP and stands out was one of my favorites because it has just this genuine feeling of over you girl this is over not only that but it has this really awesome awesome set of chugging guitar riffs on the back end of this song that are matched with vintage in beanie man and the ending song has a really pretty melody to it that gives the LP a sense of finality but the ending of the track is just so abrupt and brings it right back to the start if you are listening to the record like on an mp3 player or on a CD did they have the sound on CD I don't think so to me while this record really where's its influences on its sleeves it's an album that to me and this is something I've always felt for a very long time given that I've been a huge fan of punk music for many years but it really really highlights the power of the short song which we all know has been scientifically proven as a superior mode of musical expression just listen to this 100% true song about short songs short songs are great they don't repeat and repeat they just give you what they've got and then they're complete who wants a minutes worth of ideas stretched into four if you really love that refrain and you wanna hear it some more just play the song again as soon as it's over me to the next short song I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen and a very short listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Tony Malina distin dismissed forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new timbre tambour record hot dreams these guys are a band the musical project of singer-songwriter Taylor Kirk whose earring deep voiced ballads have been captivating me for like five years now there's a lot of vintage fulk Americana rock and roll rhythm and blues rockabilly doo-wop and country music influentially flowing throughout timber timbres records it's music that really goes back in time especially on the project's latest two releases and this is music that isn't just looking to the past with the style of music or the genre that is playing out on this record but also in the production as well a lot of the instrumentation especially the guitars the keyboards the vocals had this springy echo on them this really nice bright 50s style Sheen however do not take this band as a simple exercise in nostalgia while a lot of the sounds on this record are old the very dark and twisted feelings that feed into the songs on this LP feel brand new timber timbres records have a reputation for being eerie frightening kind of like a psychological thriller shot in black and white in the 50s or 60s or even like a David Lynch film with how he fetishizes the past but presents this very surreal picture of it the music on this record is music that has the makings of a fantastic serial killer it's smart its seductive but just strange enough to put me on edge it's always trying to wander in my periphery or take my focus off of it's weird behavior with a very clean outward appearance like this guy I've got your number freak oh well on timber timbres last full-length LP creep on creepin on the band dropped some of its most creepy material yet songs that displayed a really twisted view on the world of love and displayed stalker-like levels of obsession and I was looking forward to hearing a lot of the same characteristics play on to this new record from timber timber and for the most part they do however there are some noticeable improvements to the recipe this time around for one timber timber is much more ambitious with sound and instrumentation on this LP than they were on their previous four full-length releases and there are some very beautiful catchy kind of well arranged tracks on here that aren't quite so disconcerting like hot dreams meanwhile timber timber also delivers some of the most twisted songs I've ever heard them write thus far such as run for me and both tracks have spectacular instrumental finishes - lots of tasteful but flashy horns strings background vocals easily again some of the best instrumentation timber timber has pulled together thus far and the keyboards on this thing keys have for the most part played a pretty large role in many timber timber records but here they sound so fantastic amazing keyboard sounds on this thing whether they be from piano or some kind of synthesizer there are moments where I'm hearing this really kind of grainy eerie thin keyboard sound that kind of feels like I'm hearing a Mellotron or at least a mock Mellotron nearly every piece of instrumentation just sounds otherworldly on this thing I just feel like I'm really being transported back to the pirate ship of 1950 if you know what I mean like a ghost pirate ship but like for a whole decade not actually like a real pirate ship the songwriting for the most part has improved in a lot of ways the tracks on here are dynamic they're multifaceted they're not quite as hook driven or verse chorus verse oriented as tracks off of timber timbres previous releases which make these songs a little less hooky a little less sweet on the ear a little less gratifying from a pop music standpoint but so many of these tracks feel like an emotional and instrumental journey but still the verses that are on this record are delivered in the very deep baritone Stern vocal of Taylor Kirk the chorus is on here blossom very beautifully and the instrumental interludes on these songs either uplift these track sent two beautiful heavenly soundscapes that really alter the mood of the song or they just submerge them deeper into the depression that they were built out of that is exactly what happens on the opening from this thing beat the drum slowly which for me is a bit of a theme song for timbre Tambor a kind of a mission statement I think it sets the tone of the album really well with some lone acoustic guitars some chili bells a bit of woodwind what kind of feels like a vibraphone in the mix there are also these thudding baritone guitar riffs that march in step militaristically with snare drums it is dramatic as hell it is like listening to an army of zombies rise from the dead the instrumental sounds amazing all this earring is hanging in the treble side of the spectrum the bass is heavy its thick they're all these sound effects thrown against it - they're all these sound effects thrown into the mix - this song really sounds like a horror movie and yeah while in a sense the music is kind of campy it sounds like it was recorded and orchestrated long ago on some kind of Hollywood sound stage but that is the very reason that I love it not only that timber timber embraces this aesthetic so well but they drive it into uniquely dark territory I think it's a great reappropriation now the lyrics of this song which really to me carry the theme of timber timber as a whole speak of nostalgia of a time that seemed illustrious beautiful a golden age in its heyday but now it's just kind of a burnt-out hollow dead depressing shell of its former self that is slowly going psychotic sitting in a very dimly lit room drinking whiskey watching Lawrence Welk reruns the song hot dreams the title track off of this thing when my favorite songs of this year is a wonderful beautiful waltz and it's a love song but the obsession runs deep I want to wake from hot dreams of you baby I want to write to someone so true but still there is a little bit of subversion in the lyrics like on the line I want to follow through with all my promises and threats to you baby and why I do love this song it is one of my favorite timber timber tracks period I love that the band veers off of that love path to dive into some other song topics to like bring me simple men the song that has a really twangy dramatic instrumental that feels like it could fit snugly into an epic spaghetti western I love the watery keyboards or guitars on this thing that sounds so warped and lyrically the song delves and the themes of pride pretense swagger and competition eating up the male psyche and wanting to surround oneself with people who are sort of free of that baggage seems like an innocent enough desire however I'm not so sure that this song doesn't have kind of a darker component to it lyrically that I haven't picked up on yet there are tracks on here that really throw that in your face though like Grand Canyon while it is one of the more strikingly beautiful tracks on this entire LP with an uplifting instrumental finish without even paying attention to the lyrics I just get choked up over what's going on here and Taylor Kirk is beautifully describing some kind of flight over the Grand Canyon area seeing clouds shadows on the ground below on the canyon as well as the plane shadows and then eventually in his lyrical description he says that he prays for the canyon to swallow the plane hole which I'm not sure if that's some kind of beautiful visual metaphor or if he's literally praying for a plane crash the lyrics seem to get even more esoteric for me from there on in and I'm just kind of drawn into the beauty of that the additional lyrical imagery and again this stellar effect Acula I just made up a freaking word finish the song curtains has another great instrumental feels like a sort of weird piece of 60s psychedelic garage pop with an emphasis on upbeat of the track which the keyboard rides pretty hard the bassline sounds a lot like my Sharona though this song is not nearly as upbeat and from what I'm gathering the there's kind of like an element of Fame going on here in the lyrics I'm still in the midst of interpreting it but I can't read out every vocal with the very bouncy springy echoed reverb on this track and it's unfortunate because this song and a few others too are just not hitting me lyrically as hard as many tracks from timber timbres self-titled timber timbres creepin creepin on even on the song locomotion which is a song in here that I do dig quite a bit but it doesn't feel nearly as hard-hitting as other like lovesick songs from previous releases I actually think it rehashes quite a few ideas with being a dog being a machine for this other person's love but that song run from me on this thing is is really the standout when it comes to anti love songs not only for timber timbres entire discography but maybe one of the greatest anti love songs I've ever heard the song starts off like a slow Ballard type song that reminds me a lot of something such as Elvis's are you lonesome tonight but our narrator in this track would love nothing more than for his significant other to run away run for her life I absolutely love the line on this track where he's saying that he loves the idea of her swinging gate I guess meaning that she just kind of ran through us of the gates still kind of moving now not only does this song have a great instrumental finish but right after there is another instrumental there's also an instrumental in the middle of the cell P as well on the fifth track and these two instrumentals are awesome I am so happy that timber tambour continued to put instrumentals on their records and that they came out so good one of my main issues with their last full-length album is that there were several instrumentals on it that were not enjoyable at all simply because instrumentally and just emotionally they felt so out of place with everything else that was going on the record it was like I was listening to a completely different band play the interludes meanwhile we would switch back into a totally different world and mood and vibe on the normal verse chorus verse lyrical tracks here a lot of the instrumentation on these instrumentals remains the same as some of the instrumentation on the other songs it's just that they're very well composed they have great crescendos but I guess I'm sort of left with an instrumental kicking off this record as well just like timber timbres last album I kind of feel like I'm listening to a two-act play on this thing in a sense where I'm getting four tracks than an instrumental and then four more tracks and another instrumental and I'm just left kind of hungry after all of it I feel like this last instrumental while it is good it leaves me kind of on a cliffhanger while I think timber timbres writing some of its best stuff to date I'm still not incredibly blown away by what the band is doing from a holistic album type of standpoint and aside from the ending on this thing and a few tracks just not being that gripping lyrically there is the song the new tomorrow which to me is is really one of the more lackluster songs off of this LP with verses that are incredibly underwhelming there's not a strong melody coming through there but the choruses do flourish beautifully I'm still going to come out here and say that this is the band's best collection of tracks to date better than the last full-length album which I did love so of course I love this new record as well just to smidge more I'm feeling a strong eight on this thing transition if you given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan oh timber timber forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new white hinterland record baby this is the musical project and band of multi-instrumentalist singer songwriter Casey day who is on her third full-length record with this group and album that really came out of left field for me sort of surprised me I wasn't expecting to hear a record that I connected with so much on so many levels from this band because to tell you the truth there wasn't much from white hinterlands back catalogue that really caught my attention their debut slipped under my radar and came out before I even had a youtube channel where I did this and the project sophomore full-length LP Kairos was a little too ethereal for my taste just an indie tronic record that they just laid it on a little too heavy with the reverb but no matter now we have this third full-length LP and I'm assuming that since Kairos came out in 2010 that this album has kind of been four years in the making and I wouldn't be surprised if that was in fact the case because the detail really shows the quality of the songwriting really explosive hooks and moving ballads all over this thing as well as the instrumentals which are incredibly detailed layered and Casey's really stunning singing and voice all over this album I think Casey is one of the most passionate and impressive singers that you can lend your ear to this year and I think Casey's influences tend to run a little diverse to some of the more strict back piano ballads on here sound a little bit like Amos or Apple and some of the more production intensive tracks that feel a lot more electronic in sound occasionally give off a Bjork sound like homogenic Vespertine Bjork and while these sonic influences are very clearly there Casey does come through with a wholly different voice KC's immense talent and winding linear songs really steal my attention away from whoever shadow she might be standing in on a given track like with the song ringing the bell which to me seems like a bus lovesong looking to pick a relationship back up from a point where it seems to have broken apart and the hopes the dreams the aspirations for this move this decision all ring out beautifully in Casey's voice the rich multitrack horns blaring away in the background the very pretty background vocals there's a really nimble bassline darting and weaving through all of these sounds hidden in the background there's a little detail to eat up in nearly every instrumental on this record every time I listen through this thing but Casey and her band don't lose energy and and viscera in the process of putting together this very particular set of sounds I also love the segues and the transitions that white hinterland comes up with to move a track from one point to another and this track rides a really interesting groove too as well as many other songs on here while I do think there is an element of pop and an element of accessibility to this record a strong element of beauty that comes through in the instrumentation and the vocals this is music that definitely walks to the beat of a different drum a different drum than just your normal average pop tune like with the song baby where Casey's voices is slowed down a lot more her her singing is much more emotive and drawn-out this is another relationship centric track with some pretty telling lyrics about how her shyness was an act to give this person a sense of security and the instrumentation on this track is pretty chilly - I can see my breath when I'm listening to this thing I love the really dreary and strange vocal harmonies on this thing that wearing high hats there's a really nice murky bass line that's heavy it kicks the track off sets a very dark tone and then there's like a surprise transition at the midway point where all of a sudden the song really starts to warm up there's some insane vocal harmonies at this point in the track it really feel excites the instrumentation there is a stellar refrain is this my weakness then there is the song metronome which i think is is possibly the catchiest most straightforward song on this entire LP although it is just as layered and as thick as many other songs on here there's all these cycling background vocals creating a foundation for the track and these repeat again again again it kind of reminds me of like an animal collective track or something but what Casey does what this foundation is is very much different I mean she really rides over this and and brings some up-tempo piano rock there's a surprise transition in the middle of this song - Casey really keeps me on my toes with all the surprises that these songs hold but the very smooth kind of easygoing piano ballets catch my ear on this thing - like the song wait until dark the opening track on here a song that is really somber in tone Casey's voice sounds fantastic she sings so wonderfully over the pianos on this track and she transitions right into some very lumbering piano arpeggios just those bass e heavy notes sound great and I love how when Casey really strips back the instrumentation she feels the need to change things up with the song structure even more it's like she can go wherever she pleases without all of these people playing with her because she's just really in control of the flow of the track the song David is a bit more straightforward and is like so close to get me all teared up it opens up at this stunning lyric about how she doesn't believe in God or chance or fate when it comes to what her and this person have together while instrumentally and in vocally this song as well as the closer on here do exemplify some of those typical slow burner piano ballad cliches I still feel that these very familiar troops don't take away from the quality of the song or the singing definitely as far as downsides on this record there are tracks on here like no devotion or dry mind whose beats I might be very impressed with but I'm not that into the pacing of the song I feel like with how much Casey weighs these tracks down in sound and in detours the songs 10 to kind of lose their appeal and overall I loved listening to this thing I think Casey has a really great assembly of tracks on this record she shows some real vocal chops some piano chops there's a strong lyrical component to nearly every track here while I wouldn't call this thing a concept album many of these songs do seem to be relationship centric I'm loving the creative instrumentals on this thing the adventurer's song structures just how beautiful so many moments on this record are I'm feeling the light a decent eight on this thing Tran vision what did you think of this new white hinterland album did you love it hate it why and what should Anthony review next white hinterland baby forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new bull album no mythologies to follow this is the deluxe debut full-length LP from Danish singer-songwriter and pianist Karen Murray Oersted she has come seemingly out of nowhere with instant electro pop it's like pilgrim glass off of the strength of these tracks she got a pretty quick and very nice endorsement from Diplo who produced a beat off of this LP and Karen is showing a ton of promise so early on in her career I think she's at a point right now where she is yet to really chisel out a distinct or memorable or a unique sound for herself but I think she has shown a lot of prowess in the realm of singing in the realm of hook writing I think this girl's mystical sound in her vocal range as long as she continues to do them well are going to take her far and earn her fans from people who find her style to be similar to that of like Lourdes or Grimes or purity ring or churches or Nicki in the dove or Glasser or the knife her music has a really strong pop appeal but I think her instrumentals are a little eccentric there's a ton of atmosphere surrounding the rhythms and the synthesizers the beats the the percussion sounds that she tends to use feel kind of organic a little primal every once in a while she switches out these drum sounds in favor of a sort of 808 drum sound where she gives a bit of a nod to trap music and consistently the synthesizers whether it be the melodies that they're playing or just the the the tone the the effect the sound of the sense that she's using have a bit of a in 80's chart-topping pop hit vibe occasionally Karen veers from this formula and sort of ends up in a totally different genre entirely like on the song never want to know a song that feels like a synthetic take on some kind of vocal pop song from the 1950s or the song dust is gone which is a bit of an airy ballad where the way she sings in the way she pronounces her lyrics on this track she sounds a lot like Lana Del Rey or the song don't want to dance which is like the most blatantly poppy track on this entire LP I don't wanna dance with nobody dance with nobody oh but with that hook the groove is so infectious it kind of is a dance song you know you do want to dance just not with anybody get away from me or the song slow love another favor of mine on this LP which is just like a pop ballad straight out of the 80s there's there's nothing really about this track that feels new at all the synth bass line is amazing some of the synthesizer leads feel like something out of a todo song loving the drum fills on this track too when the chorus hits I go insane but the songs that ended up appealing to me the most on this LP are the ones that sound most like the singles that led up to the release of this record like the vocal layering on the song fire rides is awesome I love the snappy snares on this track I love it when Karen reaches up into her upper register on the song - she doesn't have the most distinct voice on the block but I think her singing is emotive I think it's sensual and I think in comparison with a lot of these artists who I find her to be similar to she shows a little bit more technical talent she harmonizes over her own vocals really well and I think she has great pitch control I love the pan-flute synthesizer leads on the song red in the gray as well as the bubbling synthesizer arpeggios just rhythmically playing into the tempo of the track I love the glockenspiel and the Phil Collins like drum fills as well as the synthesizer horn leads on the song pilgrim the song xxx 88 where Diplo handles the instrumental here the beat actually complements all the songs on this record and Caryn really well it doesn't feel out of place or anything like that however the melody and the vocal harmonies on this track do feel eerily similar to that of Lords which I guess isn't that big of a surprise considering last year's when Royals really blew up last year's when the song originally came out and the song glass is really good as a closer to the sort of normal non deluxe version of this record with its really jittery very colourful instrumental I think Karen has a lot of great ideas and the hooks are especially good on this LP but here and there I think she's a little too quick to embrace the sound of her contemporaries also I think there's maybe a little too much similarity between how each of the tracks here are mixed and just how they sound overall and while I do like a lot of the hooks on this record I think Karen has a bit of a weak spot in her songwriting in that her approach to vocal melody on the verses of these tracks feels roughly the same - it's really the synthesizer leads and the hooks that give each song on this record their distinct flavor it's not so much Karen's voice which I mean sometimes doesn't sound like anything special sometimes just sounds exactly like another artist who's already popular right now and you know those verses again they're just not that distinct sometimes don't get me wrong I think there are a lot of good characteristics to this record the rhythms the instrumentation all of its very tangible all of it is very well assembled and put together and like I said consistently I do get into these hooks I mean there's only really one track I was just outrightly disappointed with and that was a song walk this way which to me the the production the sound quality of this track was sort of that of demo however the hook is really good on this song so I could sort of see why Karen would want to include it on the tracklist here but still the recording quality of the track really does have this song feeling a little out of place though you know that this this LP while there were some bright moments and there were some tracks on here I really liked it's just really really hit or miss for me and that's all I'm kind of feeling a decent strong six on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana well forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Matt DeMarco record salad days this is the latest full-length LP from singer/songwriter Mac DeMarco following up his modestly successful full-length LP - which turned him into a pretty massive personality in the jangle pop world and I say personality because between numerous music videos and interviews that he's done since the release of this really lacks easygoing record he has come off really eccentric playful hilarious Mac DeMarcos persona to me is so enjoyable that I can only hope that his music continues to stay relevant just so that one day I can sort of see his goofy smile on a billboard somewhere now I didn't love his last record but I did think it had some fantastic tracks on it tracks that made for great singles great music videos like my kind of woman or Oh - Viceroy or dreaming really gentle combination of bass and drums twinkling guitars were some really expressive strumming the whole vibe was really chill however the melodies on these tracks and sometimes the lyrics and the song concepts but mostly the melody is really sharp I was hoping Mac would come through develop a bit more on his next record drop some stronger singles bring a little more variety to the table but personally I do not feel like that happen I think Mac came through with an even more homogenous record than he did with - not only that but I think this record has less single power as well I mean sonically melodically I don't think there's a single song on this record that rivals one of the better tracks on - and I think with Mac putting out more music touring more signing with captured tracks he's almost lost the spontaneity that was there on some of his stuff like rock and roll nightclub Mac's really smooth gentle easygoing sound seems to be the only likable quality about his music that has stuck around for this record then some of the different song topics that he tends to address over the course record some of which may not be apparent from first listen just because of how emotionally disconnected and just sigh of relief this whole album feels in terms of its vocal delivery there are some true heartbreak songs on this LP however emotionally it doesn't really feel that way necessarily because the the emotional pain doesn't really ring through all of the sonic lethargy that I think the instrumentation brings and that's unfortunate you know I understand that to was a really big breakout record for Mac but I think salad days kind of shows where his ambitions lie at the end of the day salad days just feels like a hit of the reset button it's a record that acts like its predecessor never even existed even the songs that I like off of this thing I feel like I'm merely enjoying them just because they sound just like moments off of Mac's previous album like with the song passing out pieces which initially grabs my ear because of its shimmering synthesizer arpeggios I do love the increase in the use of synths on this record overall they do add a really nice touch but as soon as the twinkling guitar solos pour through on the course I get this extreme shot of deja vu and then a pretty surprised fade-out right after the second chorus on this track and this isn't the only track this happens on unfortunately and in this song in particular it's like it's really truly over and done with 30 seconds before it decides to completely and fully fade out it's moments like this that make me feel like Mac DeMarco isn't putting as much effort into this record as he did his last record and I'm kind of sitting here wondering why I feel the same way on the incredibly underwhelming acoustic ballad let my baby stay or the song go easy where essentially the hook is done to death the intro to the song treater better extreme deja vu there overall with the groove on the song blue boy to either Mac is just unashamedly repeating past successes in his musical career that all have occurred very recently or he's indulging in some really unenjoyable ideas like the end of the track Blueboy which is one of the more sedate tracks on the entire LP and then all of a sudden at the very finish this shoegaze II wall of guitars is hit with this horrible off pitch falsetto that is not pleasant to the air in any way whatsoever honestly I'm pretty on the fence with this LP I do like the vibe I do like the sound that Matt continues to bring to the table but I feel like this record overall is the sound of not succeeding not failing horribly but settling just settling instead of shooting for something more ambitious Mac has settled he's settled for dishing out the kind of tracks that play between your favorite songs on am soft rock radio in the 70s he's settled for a redo he's settled for sounding like a sleepytime aerial pink and in the process didn't even finish some of the tracks here that he started did not give strong endings to some of these tracks like I know he has on his previous efforts there's just a lot of loose ends on this LP even on the last track of this LP which is just a kind of forgettable instrumental we're finally as the song just decides to stop Mack pop sentences hey everybody thanks for listening bye bye which is is is pretty cute and does show Mack DeMarcos personality this is something I wish more artists did however you know I would much rather have succinct well-written memorable songs than sort of this really nice goodbye message so in its best moments this record is is very pretty on the ear it's seductive but in its worst it's redundant it's stale its unimaginative and it's it's kind of short of breath - I'm feeling a light - decent 5 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Mack DeMarco salad days forever

the bangers on the Hellfire Club mixtape I mean I prefer no can do is give a over this tracks for example even with the hilarious refrain on this track we don't play we know blue there are some tracks on this LP that are genuinely catchy as well like the song zero hour which has a beat that's helped along by mono/poly insanely psychedelic track on this thing I love how eerie the organ sounds on power on this LP is the Hellfire Club anthem which has a great hook sung by open my Eagle I think one of the better moments of him singing on a rap song ever the instrumental sounds like it samples like a really sad soundtrack moment from a kung-fu movie which is totally totally awesome it's a bit of an underdog track you know it really is the perfect anthem in my opinion for Hellfire as a collective there are a few pretty funny sketches on this thing as well one of which comes from Eric Andre who has one of my favourite television shows on Adult Swim right now but overall I'm just sitting here with a pretty decent LP overall while I think no-can-do is is versatile you know he does display versatility on this record there is a lot of variety on this record I do think that's one hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a letter from a fan dear Anthony I've seen your videos around YouTube while I'm looking at my favorite artists and I have friends that watch your stuff too that's pretty much all I know about you because I avoid your videos like the plague the reason I don't watch your YouTube page is because I don't see the point in taking whatever you have to say seriously you're just a regular guy what do you know that the rest of us don't do even play music what insight could your views possibly hold as far as I know you're not an expert you're just an opinionated nerd with a camera so why should anyone be watching your reviews Derrick Ross PS I also remove your review scores from Wikipedia pages when I see them because they don't deserve to be there sorry but it's the truth PPS your hair sucks everyone Derrick is right right right right right I may have shot and edited hundreds of music reviews since I started this channel earned a quarter of a million subs as well as respect from fellow critics musicians music fans as well as industry professionals I may have interviewed makjang I may have been interviewed by NAR doir as well as the wire magazine I may have won a beyond the blog award from MTV spoken at Wesleyan University had my own radio show that aired on about a dozen stations written for NPR music on numerous occasions I may have been front page Don YouTube and BuzzFeed as well as numerous music forums across the internet publicly and privately insulted and praised by the artists I review as well as some that I don't review but Derrick has seen through the big fat facade that I wasn't even trying to put up in the first place to realize I'm just a regular guy yes as hard as it may be to believe I am just a regular guy unfortunately God did not come down from the heavens when I was a child and gift to me the power of an infallible opinion what you all will agree with no matter what no instead I'm just a passionate music fan who's heard a lot of records loved a lot of bands and has some pretty strong opinions that I spend a lot of time forming writing editing sharing I started this thing with absolutely no industry ties whatsoever and have continued to be able to do what I want on my own terms with it as it has grown into my full-time job you might not always agree with what I say but at least you know or at least I promise you that there is nothing in forming my opinion of a record other than what I sincerely feel about the music on it all that being said I can't tell you why - like my videos I just make the content it's the audience who decides what they get out of it if I had complete control over why people watched my videos I would love nothing more than for everyone to go through my entire review list and only watch the reviews of bands that they haven't heard of sort of just taken my opinion and then go into the record and try it out for themselves and see if they love the band and if they do either buy a record or go see them live support them in some way continue watching leave a comment like a video share it with a friend but that's not really how it works some people only watch my mainstream reviews some people only watch my obscure reviews some people only watch my hip hop reviews some people only watch my metal reviews some people only watch my negative reviews some people only want to know the records that I love some people watch the reviews for conversation a second opinion or reinforcement of whatever their opinion is some people are into the debate of the whole thing some people are in it for the new artists some people only watch my videos for couch' chesta who we all know is pretty much the reason why we have any female audience whatsoever you if you don't take me seriously or if you don't have any use for my reviews that's on you man don't act like you know something my audience doesn't just because you don't see my reviews as being anything worth your while because I fully understand that you are an independently thinking snowflake who is constantly in awe of his own uniqueness you cannot be influenced by anyone and I really do appreciate you taking a moment to step away from the mirror to write this email but it's not like I grew up as a kid reading reviews and worshipping some of these great and informative opinions came in the shape of music reviews I think one passionate music fan who is just a regular guy can be an entryway into some life changing music for another music fan hmm if I hear the greatest record I've ever heard in my entire life I'm not the kind of person who just kind of sits there like hmm this is really good I think I'll just sit here quietly by myself and just listen to the record over and over and over until the day I die no I gotta kind of tell somebody you know and the thing is getting on my rooftop with a megaphone just was not working hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new wild beasts album present-tense these guys are a uk-based art pop outfit and this is their fourth full-length album a band that's known for its whimsical songwriting and incredibly theatrical and dramatic singing from dual frontmen tom fleming and hayden Thorp the singing on their LPS really is wild beasts most defining characteristic however across many of their records the most persistent issue for me has just really been the sound of their instrumentation the sound of their music in general I think the Achilles heel of the band's last LP smother was that the instrumentation sounded so plain on that record while the vocals and tunes are fantastic and really sharp a lot of the time I find the guitars and the drums and occasionally since to be just a little too dry a little colorless a little lifeless however it is their sound that the band is Overhaulin on this newest LP of theirs as I heard in an interview I did with frontman Hayden Thorpe earlier this year he said that this new LP from the band does not rely quite as much on live instrumentation and explores a lot more synthetic electronic textures and I suppose in a way present tense is wild beasts electronic record however this album wasn't really the shift in style or sound or aesthetic that I thought it was going to be based on the conversation that I had it's not like this was the kind of change that Liars made for example from their LP sister world to wishyou which was a significant change in the band's sound and how they wrote songs while beasts however even though there is a bit of a sonic change on this LP they still rely on a lot of the same slower smoother sexier grooves more sensual melodies and they bring their usual vocal style along for the ride as well on this LP - and the inclusion of more synthesizers on this new record of theirs isn't real that overwhelming of a change since the drumbeats and the vocals are really what kind of take reigns on these songs anyway which isn't necessarily a bad thing since that is exactly what is made wild beasts sounds so seductive over their past few albums anyway for the most part the band's strengths remain the same but I think their weaknesses do as well the dynamics between the band's two lead singers are still really impressive the songs on this LP overall are very enjoyable a lot of the tunes here continue to set a kind of sexy tone however I'm still pretty lukewarm on how wild beasts approaches sound and even though there are some tracks here where it seems like while beast x1 synth sound on top of another I'm not finding this record to be nearly as colorful as the cover that they've slapped on it and I think they're really touching vocals and tunes and occasionally very bold lyrics do kind of get hindered by the sounds that wild beasts lair into these songs like with the opening track the lead single from this LP wanderlust I think they're really still flat rough bass synthesizers that just sort of warble away in the background on this song don't really set that great of a tone neither does the very numbing drum be in one stiff synth phrase after another it just makes the songs momentum feel non-existent by the time the track is halfway through again if it weren't for the singing and the fact that the song has a pretty epic ending I don't think I would have dug the track at all I think the stiffness pervades other tracks on here like daughters and then there's the closer on here which to me sounds sort of like a Kate Bush 'like eighties tinged art pop ballad that could have ended a movie and played while the credits rolled despite really blunt lyrics on this LP like don't confuse me for someone who gives a I think there are a lot of sounds on this record that feel a little sterile occasionally I just get the feeling that wild beasts did not dig too far or manipulate too far the synthesizer sounds the electronics that they actually went into this record using it felt like the band just went down another Avenue to execute what they typically do as opposed to use this opportunity to find a plethora of entirely new sounds to build their songs off of for someone who is hoping for more of a significant change on this new record of theirs it's a little underwhelming but for somebody who loves wild be sounding exactly the way that they typically sound that it could be a good thing I guess at the end of the day wild beast is never going to be that kind of sonically spelunking sort of band and that doesn't mean this record is disappointment to me merely because of that because again they do deliver good songs like the song Mecca I love the descending vocal melody on this track because a serious highlight on this record for me and I love the stuttering guitar solo in the second half of this track - there's the song pregnant pause a really powerful piano ballad delivered by Haydn Thorpe on this track really beautiful singing across the song and I love the way that the instrumentation builds from the beginning to the end of the track it does show a significant amount of
