hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Liars record mess whoa it's a great looking record yeah it is a really cool record beautiful it's actually really interesting it is it is blue blue man yep it is a good record experimental music outfit liars has just dropped their seventh full-length LP P and they're a band that's kind of hard to put into words or at least a couple of words they've been creating really abstract adventurous rock electronic and dance punk music since their formation in the early 2000s and their sound has been in a constant state of evolution ever since their inception and even though it's been a little while since I've all out loved loved a liar's record maybe not since 2006 as drums not dead it has still been interesting watching the band's progression from one record to another because of how dedicated they are to changing from album to album the closest they came to really exciting me since the release of drums not dead was their last full-length LP wish you a record that showed the band making a sudden and hard shift into a really electronic and minimalistic sound it is easily Liars bleakest moment on record with a few exceptions on the tracklist like the song brats a track that was actually so good just loaded with throbbing electronics a faster pace in tempo just a little more upbeat but grimy er just more aggressive I vaguely remember wishing more songs on this LP sounded like that particular track and the thing is Liars do exactly that with mess the band does not hold back in a single aspect of this record they essentially deliver a series of alternative dance tracks on this LP that mix elements of techno house ambient music synthesizer punk and we with lots of twisted keyboards delivering sinister melodies or just some really rough unsettling textures the songs on this LP like liars previous albums continue to be fronted by these really unaffected disembodied vocals that range from just really low lose to really oddball falsettos and I actually think the deadpan delivery of the vocals matches the instrumentals on this LP quite a bit because the instrumentals are just so bombastic they're just so aggressive to have vocals there that are just really chill and maybe a little eye widening and weird as a nice touch and the beats the rhythms the grooves on this LP range from monstrous massive industrialised nightmares to kind of upbeat high tempo glitchy and strange dance tracks there are even a series of songs on this LP that head back into that ambient direction that you remember from wish you but with a lot more colors and layers and like the album wish you I think Liars comes through with a record cover that matches the music perfectly the sounds on mess don't feel organized in a really kind of clean and succinct way they are matted they are grimy their while their uncompromising ly colorful but even though the record is kind of hectic I think lyre still comes through with some songs that are kind of catchy like the song mess on a mission which has one of the more lively tempos on the entire LP punchy snare and the song also features some of the most memorable vocals on the entire LP especially on the course which just burns like a forest fire for me anyway I love the wailing synth leads in the background and the speedy refrain on this thing and the song Pro anti anti maybe one of the more attention grabbing songs on this entire LP with it's kind of chilly catchy reverb organ riff playing at the very start and then immediately busting in all of these heavy bass synthesizers in this gigantic kick and snare drum a beat that I can see almost rocking on a Nine Inch Nails record except way heavier I love the eerie eerie falsetto background vocals I love the lead vocals which are fantastic and so there's and the very last verse on this track as well just brings up all this imagery of like a a robot army marching in to dominate the human race and then there are tracks on this LP that I wouldn't necessarily say are catchy but function more on just creating a really enthralling sound set and an irresistible groove that I can kind of just get lost in and then like the opening track on here mask maker which has all these bubbling synthesizer arpeggios keeping a really tight pace and there are some pretty weird vocal samples playing throughout this track too like my face but their placement into the song seems so much like I don't know just like electric body music from the 80s or something like that and the song actually transitions into the song immediately after Vox tuned EE D making these two tracks feel like one long continuous tracks since they kind of keep up the same momentum although this song does to me is as fantastic as it is with its groove and its synthesizer layers it does expose kind of an issue on the record and that is the vocals though I think they're eerie eerie delivery is is is really good a lot of the time occasionally I feel like they're they're a bit of an afterthought on this record whether it's with the lyrics like the people tell me why or with so many songs on this record just featuring elongated moans or on the song can't hear well which is a bit of an intermission a pretty slow burner that is kind of short thrown into the middle of the LP I like the synth line on this thing the the patience that it requires to really enjoy it but the vocals on top of it just sound like I'm cupping the microphone with my hands and doing a cartoony boy to me the vocal delivery on this track is a bit of a stretch but if vocals are an issue for you on this LP the band actually goes without them on the song darkslide which is a bustling busy piece of electronic music very dense and the way the song progresses it doesn't really make a huge significant change in the midst of its runtime er anything like that it just progressively gets noisier and noisier and noisier I wish there was a bit more change across this tract though it feels more like a motif than anything but the last third of this LP is really where liars makes the creepy kick in the song boy zone grabs an international groove and then throws some moaning vocals on top of it with a set of incredibly unsettling dissonant synthesizers both high and low and it creates one of the weirdest spots on the entire album and there's the two closing tracks on here too like perpetual village the longest song here at 9 minutes long there's some pretty minimal atmospheric beats on this thing the falsetto vocals return it's again odd it's unsettling it's just so out there and yet the production seems so close the grooves seem so close to something like nicolas jar could have made and then the closing track on this thing is a bit of an ambient ballad which i love the really pretty melodies playing in the background of this thing but it's met with this wailing buzzing synthesizer that's so just wool and I mean wool in a good way because I love how this record is just so just so twisted again twisted throughout oh man is it sick this record is one sick puppy and even though that is kind of a constant thread I do think that the songs here do a great job of transitioning from one vibe one feel at the start of the record a more aggressive feel to something much more relaxed at the finish I really love the flow of this album I love the grooves I love the vibe I love the sounds on this record I think the way Liars treat create and manipulate sound is so great to me in no way has Liars half-heartedly transitioned into electronic music this record really is a true-blue blend of techno house and some kind of undefinable third element that can only be described as liars because even in a different genre entirely the band's appreciation for eerie atmospheres and sound manipulation dissonant tones and strange ass vocals still rings true there are a few underwhelming songs along for the ride on this thing but I was massively impressed by what the band had to deliver on mess I'm feeling strongly to a light 9 on this thing transition if you view in this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it y'all that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Liars forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Skrillex album recess Skrillex is an electronic music producer most known for being a leading figure in the rising popularity of noisy drop centric dubstep aka brostep love him blindly as an EDM fanatic or hate his guts as a slightly snobbish fan of more refined genres of electronic music Skrillex is rise to the top has made him a pretty polarizing figure and I personally have never really even hated his sound right from the first moment I ever heard it on his scary monsters and nice sprites EP a handful of years ago at the time when I dropped my review of that EP I was actually pretty surprised at some of the negative reactions to my positive feelings on the thing and while drops and very noisy bass frequencies do play a pretty huge role on the songs from this EP a production technique that a lot of people equate to pure buffoonery these days I personally not only enjoyed that but saw beyond that to see a lot of very jittery detailed rhythms I loved the fact that these tracks always seem to be shifting and sound and groove and also brought a lot of color and texture to the table I thought a lot of tracks on the CP were fun energetic hard-hitting and detailed too however even though I do like what Skrillex was doing here I'm not ready to really defend every move he's made in mainstream music since then for one there were a few potholes on his bangarang EP even though I think he did come through with some of his hardest bangers yet on that thing did not really care for the Dores track they're also really didn't dig Skrillex's work on the dubstep infused Korn album path of totality and he actually dropped an incredibly weak EP last year titled leaving where out a few tracks here if felt like Skrillex was trying to emulate the airy more atmospheric more subtle sounds of underground tone down dubstep producers like burial and while in a sense taking on these sounds felt Cincy it really sort of came up short in terms of being as entertaining as some of those artists so last week out of the blue Skrillex decides to just drop his debut full-length album with this kind of tacky alien cover and title however as far as party music goes I feel like you could do a lot worse the Skrillex so I didn't go into this thing with maybe the same level as anxiety some of the people who hate listen to this thing did I'm sure but for Skrillex what I think this record comes down to essentially is versatility versatility he's really pushing himself on this record to work with a variety of artists and musical styles incorporating his typically loud drop centric heavy party-ready sound to different styles of music he's really pushing himself on this record to work with a variety of different artists and sounds seeing how many different places he can take his typically loud heavy production style and apply it you know to different genres and sometimes it seems like he's taking just a really weird sonic detour as well I think this is maybe his least cohesive record yet I don't think there's a whole ton of strings these tracks together and I would say the single power of this record isn't quite as strong as it was on some of Skrillex as earlier releases as well I think the closest Skrillex comes to dropping a track of that intensity of that quality is rageh bomb with the ragged twins I love the distorted vocals all over this track their really attention forcing the groove on the song is fantastic and the drop is insane the eerie synth arpeggios that float throughout this tracks at a really nice tone and I love the way that the bass and the rhythm sort of go double-time toward the end of the track I love the song but Skrillex doesn't really concentrate on churning out a massive banger with each track on this thing which like I said earlier does leave this LP feeling less heesu than previous projects but I guess it's sort of a silver lining in a way that you know nothing kills an albums listen ability like taking a great idea and then just copying it 10 or 12 times instead he brings a lot of variety which does lead to some hit or miss tracks like usual Skrillex does deliver some heavy dubstep bangers with some ear worm vocal samples or contributions maybe some bright screaming synth leads as well like on the track try it out or the song recess - although the incessant vocal samples on this track of put your hands and weed okay and the fake crowd noises on this song making a sound like the song is being performed live or being played to a crowd or something like that it really kills what little is enjoyable about the rhythm and they're really sweet just candy candy sweet vocal samples on this track and there's another track on here that features the ragga twins as well the opening track on here all is fair in love and brostep a song that unfortunately while it does embrace all the tenants of brostep that we have come to expect from a guy like Skrillex it's just kind of an inconspicuous sort of average song for school unfortunately however there are tracks on here where he does show that he has some tricks up his sleeve and he's not just a one-trick pony for one the song stranger a pretty chilly subdued piece of dance pop that has a really great vocal contribution on it I love the melody on this track the vocal melody that is however the beat the groove just the overall tone of the song seems like it is the result of having listened to our upon hour upon hour of the new disclosure record settle with the very choppy groove in the background on this track and the boyish lead vocals I think this song might have fit pretty snugly into settles tracklist along with the song fuck that too and even though the influence on this track seems really a parent I think Skrillex puts his own play on this thing once the heavier drums come into play and he throws this absurdly squeaky ridiculous synth lead over the track that as weird as it sound I think I love it it's great the song coast is clear has chance the rapper which is another huge surprise on this LP and while lyrically the song is pretty trashy it is really surprising to hear Skrillex come through with an instrumental that complements chance so well and sounds like something straight out of the acid rap mixtape that came out last year except maybe a little bit louder brighter punchy er featuring the kind of dubstep rhythms that we typically expect from Skrillex and then there is sort of a surprise remix on this track of the Nicki and the dub song DJ ease my mind which is titled ease my mind on this record and while I think the song is really great I loved hearing it on the record that they put out a little while ago I don't really see what Skrillex does with the track here other than just sort of make it more appropriate to play in the midst of a DJ set other than that in my opinion he's really added nothing to the track and made a really great song a lot less dynamic than it originally was but my least favorite of all of the surprise tracks on here easily is the song dumpy pump a really dinky piece of glitchy electronic music that has these just weird cartoony sound effects in it that sound like they were lifted off of just like a general sfx CD or something like that it's colorful but the pace of is really slow there's nothing much about it that's all that memorable and it kind of creates this very unnecessary intermission toward the back end of the album as nice as it was to hear Skrillex just go down some different avenues on this record I mean the songs were he's experimenting the most are among my least favorite here unfortunately while I think the more heavy brostep tracks on this record are sort of average for him they were at least passable for the most part I mean the song that he has Diplo on dirty vibe is this fantastic piece of moombahton with this killer rhythm high-energy and I love the insane vocal sampling on this track and as the vocals are being sampled the the crazy paradiddles that are being played with them and I love the way these trap high hats fly in as some of the rap versus start on this track its its highlights like this that for sure will have me coming back and listening to each new Skrillex release at least into the near future just to see if there's some killer bangers in the playlist and I think Skrillex could potentially continue going down that road if he brings these bangers together onto an EP and is just sort of concise with his releases and isn't putting a lot of filler onto them and unfortunately I feel like that's kind of what we got with this record while it does show that Skrillex is a more versatile producer than I think a lot of people give him credit for you know he really does kind of push himself out of his comfort zone proving that he can do one thing do another thing do another thing I think he's considerably far away with all the potholes in the tracklist on this thing from putting out one of his better releases I'm feeling a decent two strong five on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it Anthony Fantana music review forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Big Ups album 18 hours of static New York Bands big ups this is their debut full-length album which they have built up to with from what I understand a split a 7-inch and it's a record that I love the more I listen to it there's a lot of noisy punk rock on this record a bit of old-school lo-fi indie rock as well and with these influences the band essentially delivers a series of songs they have some really strong in-your-face very opinionated lyrical content reflections on the world at large the fast pace of life really spittin some big fat loogies into some societal norms it's angry its rebellious and it's looking for the first person that's gonna give us some crap because right away it's gonna say hey I'm not gonna take this crap the band might seem like they're kind of looking for a fight but at least they choose their battles wisely the song wall being about what seems like self trickery the lyrics sing about pulling the wool over one's own eyes on the slow burner of a track that features some guitar leads and some vocal deliveries that sound pretty akin to something from like a slant record I love the very tone down subdued verses on this track and how they're matched with a really passionate vocal delivery on the chorus and the explosive finish on this song too we should switch this we've gotta get the drive Like Jehu in here man for this one the lyrics on this track and others here are very simple they're straightforward the rhyme schemes can be pretty basic as well however the sentiments for the most part do feel powerful I know there's a better way but I just can't say what will make it okay if I could have just one wish I would wish for this I would wish for justice or maybe my favorite lyric on the entire album people say it's always getting better all the time but it's bad still bad I love the song disposer with these very subdued guitars in the back goes through this take-out-the-trash mantra disposable camera disposable razor disposable income disposable wife everything we throw away the song is essentially really quick to point out how many things we buy into knowing that we're just gonna be tossing them in the trash months days weeks maybe years down the road and the drum groove in the background of this track is a little funky to kind of in a Fugazi sort of way the song atheist self-help is another track on here that while the guitars the drums are good they're punky they're noisy we get some lyrics that are satirical hilarious in a way where the singer of the band is saying that you know I don't need religious doctrine to tell me what a jerk I am I sort of do that pretty well on my own the song goes black has all these speedy guitar riffs and drums matched with these lyrics that are just going a million miles an hour talking about the fast pace of life and how life is just going by so fast that manat really living in the moment or enjoying the little things in life then there is the song TMI which essentially sings about being a self medicating emotionless numb to the world robot my operating system runs on complacency I think it's fine it doesn't really bother me then every track on here pretty much delivers a very plain as day message and occasionally there are songs on here that sort of segue into one another really well really kind of feel like one track or just complement one another where one track sort of carries the momentum of the one that came before it like the song little kid which switches right out of TMI with these insane spiraling just dizzying noisy as hell guitar riffs we're against them the singer of the band is saying stop it almost as if he's pleading with the instrumentation itself as he is singing and the sound of the record the sound of the instrumentation on this thing is just so great it's just so top-notch for this kind of songwriting I mean the guitars are so brittle the drums just kind of get lost in the mess a little bit the bass guitar is really guttural it feels like every pick being stroked onto the strings it's just like killing the guitar and in a way that kind of reminds me of Minor Threat the band toes this line between being very fast precise and sort of having just enough looseness and enough chaos to just make it feel like the group is just on the verge of total destruction there's just a rough around the edges quality to this LP that I really like Plus for a record this noisy the vocals are very readable which again is great because messages do play a pretty strong role on a majority of the tracks here there's nothing too esoteric about the lyrics on this LP and while I think many of the tracks here really are in your face with what they're trying to say there is an element of cleverness and and satire that keeps these songs from feeling too preachy or like they're trying to jump down your throat or look down at you or anything like that the downsides for me on this record is that there are a few songs on here there are a little short of breath and don't really leave an impact on me because of that or feature such a simple lyrical approach that hmm I'm left groaning a little bit like the opener body parts or some of the verses on the track wool other than that I think this is a fantastic short little noise punk record that has a lot to say and will definitely go down as one of my favorite rock records of the year I am feeling a strong eight on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it Anthony Fantana music review forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new future islands record singles Maryland via North Carolina's synth pop outfit future Islands has come out with their fourth full-length record whoo I have been a follower of their exploits for a while now ever since I heard some of the more popular cuts off of their 2010 album in the evening air songs like tin man and welcome through that duel and on this record and the band's next record as well I found some really simple straightforward sort of bare-bones drum machine backed synth-pop that made up for its simplicity with some very solid good song writing strong melodies and the incredible vocals of frontman Samuel T herring which have kind of been a selling point for the band lately ever since they did a surprise Letterman performance a few weeks ago what was jaw-dropping about this late-night performance was the level of intensity that the band especially Samuel performed with there were plenty of tight dance grooves in the performance rushes of synthesizers as well as Samuel singing over these tracks with his trademark very soulful rasp that went through a range of pitches but the real high notes of this performance are when he sort of pulls into these guttural death growls that really are something different for the genre Sam really does have a set of pipes that could possibly rival that of some of my favorite death metal singers which is a move I suggest the band go into if this whole future islands thing does not pan out either that or dancing anyway with this electrifying performance of the band's lead single from this new record it seemed that a lot of people were kind of finding out about this band for the first time and my faith in them as a band was rekindled a little bit because with each record of theirs that I have been following so far they've always dropped to three or four songs on to it that I loved but then the rest of the record I can kind of take or leave so I was kind of hoping that singles would just push me over the edge into full-on loving a future Islands record from front to back especially with such a lead track off of this thing and an album title that kind of insinuates that maybe every song is going to be as catchy as the next however singles does not really deliver on the level of intensity that people might be expecting from future islands given that they may have seen that letterman performance or have caught a bunch of live dates that the band has performed at recently I mean truth be told their live sets have kind of been notorious for being just a bit more energetic than what they do on record because here with a lot of the tracks I feel like they play it kind of safe instrumentally and vocally while a lot of tracks here are catchy there are really only a few spots where future islands come off as fierce on top of that I feel this record does exemplify an Achilles heel that I think has been following future islands through nearly every record of theirs and that's the production to me a lot of the songs here feature a pretty flat mix of synthesizers drum machines and bass with Sam's vocals sitting atop all of it pretty comfortably nothing sounds too bright I think overall the instrumentation on this thing is a little sapped of color the beats on this record constantly sit on the back burner not even on the back burner but on the back of the back burner I wish they were louder or even just had a crisper tone I wish they were propelling the instrumentation more aggressively especially as these songs explode in two choruses where it seems like it's really only the synthesizers or maybe even some distorted bass that gets louder and I'm not that crazy about some of the synth texture is used on these tracks to like the really squeaky high-pitched tones wailing away in the background of Sun in the morning or some of the watery reverb tones on the song spirit which very messily color the background and I feel like on synth lines like this and others on here too there's a lot to be desired in terms of placement I feel like there's not a whole ton of precision to the way these synths are played and the bass tone leaves a lot to be desired as well it's either this very flat hollow sound or kind of this bland distortion that brings a bit of heaviness when the band's trying to thicken up a chorus occasionally I feel like the instrumentation here shoots for something sort of quaint light a little more spacious reminding me quite a bit of like a beach house record there we are this is especially true of the track like the moon however even though the beach house comparison even though that beach house sound is very apparent it stirs up nowhere near as much emotion for me here as it does here once again on this new record future Islands essentially deliver a record that has a really solid unbreakable chassis and a souped-up engine of great songwriting and really fantastic vocal performances but the body sitting on top of these things is like that of an economy car I actually didn't even start enjoying this LP fully until I listened to it strictly on headphones numerous times because the mix of this album the instrumentation is just not very full it's not very warm and and I felt like the only way to really even give the record a bit of punch or make it seem like it has a bit of punch is to just bring it into a very close intimate setting then I was able to appreciate how good some of the songs on this thing really are even though like I said some of the performances are reserved but that doesn't stop songs like seasons from just being really good no seasons change wonderful track sweetly ringing with synth melodies a very live snare drum with some tambourine mixed in there too and a killer refrain and vocal melody way to know you Sun in the morning as well I mean just really solid song she gives me a daily so and the vocals even though the instrumentation is not that fantastic they continue to be powerful moving very dramatic theatrical doves another great song I love the collective whoo-hoo on the chorus really nice rush of sound with the hook there if there's any way that singles really does live up to its title it is that the record tracklist overall is pretty no BS there are no songs on here that kill the momentum of the record we have one concise succinct verse chorus verse track after another even the slow burners on this LP the ballads don't lose sight of a really straightforward pop appeal one of my favorite slow burners on here song for our grandfathers is not only a sweet song in terms of melody but I think it is the sweetest song on this entire LP in terms of sentiment it's a pretty touching song speaking directly about our elders the influence that they continue to have on us their guidance their guardianship that they have on us possibly beyond the grave again song for song I really dig what future Islands is dishing out and again I mean this band features one of the most interesting vocals in underground or independent whatever you want to call it pop music today it's just that I'm still not very enamored with the sound of their instrumentation and the production they use to present their songs and while I do think this record is an improvement and is much more focused than future Islands last album I'm still not in love with this one I'm feeling a light too decent seven on this thing transition what did you think of this thing did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana future Islands forever

got the old red on hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new war on drugs album lost in the dream Philadelphia rock band the war on drugs this is their third full-length LP following up what was pretty much their breakout album back in 2011 slave ambient an LP that I did not love but did appreciate for its puncher tracks like come to the city as well as it's pretty novel mix of genres like psychedelic rock folk rock krautrock Americana and the singer-songwriter stylings of artists like Tom Petty or Bruce Springsteen in a nutshell this record to me was kind of like combining the music of Noy with Bob Dylan I thought the combination was a great idea I thought these sounds were really trippy as well as vivid I thought there were some great songs on this record but all too often I found the tracks on here sort of getting distracted and lost in the very haze that made this record such a unique piece of music in the first place and as a result of that the band sort of was losing track of interesting songwriting and and was just sort of making music that was a bit too comatose for me and considering ex band member Kurt Vile left the group a little while ago to sort of improve upon the sound in his own records I think in a lot of ways he's kind of beat them at their own game with this more psychedelic approach to Americana folk rock singer-songwriter music so I really wasn't sure what to expect from the war on drugs on this latest LP but still I ended up coming out of this thing pleasantly surprised yes the band does tend to wear their influences on their sleeves there are some occasionally uninteresting moments on this thing too but I still think lost in the dream is a noticeable improvement upon what the band has been doing up until this point the production is far more lush more colorful more layered a bit more saxophone seems to make its way into this sea of delayed panoramic guitars and the band also continues to deliver fast ethereal rockers barnburners with fiery guitar solos and really tight drumming tracks like red eyes and an ocean between the waves two of my favorites on this entire LP really explosive moments on this record that I like a lot but some of the more toned-down songs on this new LP from the war on drugs specifically the song disappearing sort of has me feeling like I'm listening to an extended version of the Miami Vice theme song just a really lackluster eighty style new wave slow jam however the very blatant New Wave influence that the war on drugs showcases isn't always a bad thing for one I think these aesthetics are embraced and executed really tastefully on the song burning which immediately as the track hits it feels like I'm listening to a new order song and not just sort of in the way that they're oh they're emulating it but it hits me with the same rush of emotion and power that a great new order song does except of course there is a completely different vocal delivery to the whole thing its tracks like this that actually make me wish that the current set of bands out there that are writing such hazy blissful music actually went this very tasteful route the music here is joyous it's feel-good it's intoxicating and yet the instrumentation is lively you can actually hear things going on it feels like I'm listening to a band of people who are engaged with the music that they're actually playing they're not about to go to sleep I feel like I'm listening to a revision of Bruce Springsteen's dancing in the dark with a fog machine blasting at it from every single direction and like maybe some laser lights or something and while I'm not always totally in love with what frontman Adam grandis seal is is doing with his vocals I can't really deny that what the war on drugs does with the momentum of their tracks the colors the effects the layering the progression of their songs it's all pretty enthralling for the most part like with the opener under the pressure which starts off with just a guitar some drums vocals kind of feels like I could be listening to a Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers track it's passable it gets a little drab after a while but in the second third of the song synthesizers some horns come in the drums really start to pick up and that's when the track really starts to become just Who I am really starting to fall for it to become seductive it becomes enveloping with all these sounds that it's presenting it's like an ocean a wonderful ocean of wonderful sexiness and in the last third of this song there is a pretty relaxing buzzing ambient outro that's a very nice on the ears it's a decent start to the record what actually ends up captivating me the most on this LP though are the slower more straightforward ballads and this is actually a spot where I feel that the war on drugs separates themselves significantly from Kurt Vile they step past the reverb a little bit deliver some very vivid detailed passionate lyrics that have sort of a sense of place like eyes to the wind I love the court pression on this track the vocal melody is nice as well the pedal steel in the background nice touch and the closing song in Reverse which starts off with these really icy tones some vocals it's very spacious that's very open vast it's icy as well I would say listening to the song is like just glass shimmering with sunlight just gleaming through it and as the song moves along the instrumentation really picks up keeps things engaging from front to back it's a strong close and to a lesser extent I do enjoy the ballad suffering on here it does get a little too hazy for me at some spots and a little too drawn-out but it is one of the prettier tracks on this LP as well especially with the very beautiful expressive guitar solo in the second half of this track and outside of that there aren't a whole lot of other songs to address on the cell P other major highlights and that's because there are just 10 songs on this record however it takes up more than an hour of runtime because the war on drugs does not hit you with a ton of songs they hit you with songs they have a ton of length and on this record much more than their last record I think they're doing a better job of justifying these lengths of songs that run almost nine minutes or eight or seven because a lot of the time while there are some pretty simple straightforward verses and choruses on these tracks the band really takes their time building them up jamming leaving space in between them there's not a lot of urgency to move from point A to point B on these tracks the band sort of takes it at their own pace and I don't really mind them waiting and sort of letting the tension build to shift from one area of a song to another since the instrumentation the performances on these tracks typically are so tight and nicely put together again the vocals aren't the most enthralling in the world and I do think there are a few tracks on here that run pretty mundane but the songs are definitely of a higher quality on here the hard-hitting and fast-paced tracks are fantastic overall it sounds like the band really did a much better job of adding detail into their music on this thing and it really feels like they they fussed over the material on this thing longer I'm feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it Anthony Fantana music review forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Tycho album awake this is the 4th full-length LP I believe from California based music producer Tycho cool it has been a little while since we last heard from this guy I believe back in 2011 with his last flight they'll be dive which at least in my opinion seemed like one of the last dying breaths of what we remember as chill wave really light summery Pleasant easygoing electronic instrumentals on this thing loaded with atmosphere and feel good vibes sweet melodies shimmering synthesizers nothing too gripping nothing too offensive in my opinion music for those who don't want their buzz harshed for me it's music that sets a mood it's not bad for a song or two but it tends to just fall in the background for me as I listen to an entire record of this stuff overall the LP is just a little too pastel for me given that I was not really looking forward to what Tycho was going to do on this new full-length LP of his especially since it looks like it I don't know it's kind of like a different version or a rather a rendition with the repeat of the sunset album art but just kind of in a more minimalistic way however I will say that awake is a pretty impressive change of pace for Tycho he moves from what sounds like a single lone bedroom producer to a full band there are a lot of tight instrumental grooves on the cell peace snappy crisp drum sounds shimmering twinkly guitars warm bass lines I love the tone of the bass on this thing a lot of the bass lines are driving and have kind of a picked sound to them not fingered and for the most part taiko just kind of keeps it instrumental as usual and this time around instead of just feeling like an average chill waver just hazy electronic music project taiko seems a lot more like a more pleasant on the ear version of post-rock act sixty-five days of static or maserati or maybe like battles with zero eccentricity or experimentation and that's essentially what this record comes down to for me Tyco has made a major change to the instrumental qualities of his music but he has maintained that really sort of chill laid-back vibe I think the instrumentation is a lot more tangible which overall makes these very chill Pleasant instrumentals more engaging for me but there are still a considerable amount of songs on this record that to me are nothing more than kind of uneventful I do think that live more raw instrumental element does add positive qualities to this record like on the song die where I'm here a lot of explorative synthesizer leads playing on the track I also love the progression of this song from it's very subtle start to some of the more heavy beats and layered synthesizers on the back end and I actually think there's a decent amount of variety among these tracks to like on the song apogee which surprisingly incorporates some drum and bass breaks into its rhythm section but even with all this production quality being improved and some different stylistic influences coming into the recipe on this taiko album I can't say that this record goes out on a limb even once or even stirs up a really exhilarating moment and still I I don't think that is Tycho's mo I don't really think I can expect that from a taiko record into the future but who knows I didn't expect sort of more tangible instrumentation to turn up on this record and here we are while I do think this record has a lot going for it I prefer just a bit more grit and eccentricity in my music that's all at least what taiko continues to do in terms of his style and his sound on this record is sounding a lot more intricate and engaging I'm feeling a decent strong six on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it Anthony Fantana music review forever

ah hi everyone ouch the knee cramp tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Freddie Gibbs in Madlib car driving by album pinata this is the long-awaited full-length LP from DJ producer rapper Madeline aka Otis Jackson jr. aka Lord coifs aka the loop digger aka the bee conductor and Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs my love for Madlib and hip hop just run so deep he's been the architect of some of my favorite songs and albums in this genre like mad villainy and the unseen he's worked with numerous emcees who might have a lot of respect for like mos def many paths blue Talib Kweli there's so much I can say about this guy and I feel the few artists out there right now define hip-hop quite in the same way that he does he's prolific he's unique a great deal of his output is impressive despite the deceptively simple approach he takes to sampling and beat assembly his instrumentals are jazzy they're smooth they're colorful they tend to be a little dusty a little grimy and occasionally he will put an instrumental out there that is incredibly experimental or off-kilter however I've never really been as crazy about Freddie Gibbs I never thought he was a terrible emcee maybe a little redundant with his flow sometimes and his subject matter he tends to kind of tow this gangster rap line and simultaneously is also self-aware enough to kind of give an objective look at this lifestyle that he leads and not only love it and embrace it but kind of critique it as well however on his most recent projects I think here and there he is dipped into some trashy hooks I've always heard a song or two that I liked but never anything more than that really which kind of kept me on the fence as Freddie Gibbs and mad live announced the fact that they were going to be teaming up coming out with a record and they were putting out some pretty good song and EPS like deeper and shame as well as thuggin because even though these songs were really good who knows if it's actually gonna pan out to a great record it's not like Madlib hasn't dropped lackluster collaborative projects before OJ Simpson but I came out of this record incredibly surprised oh man this thing is good it showcases everything that I love about Mad Libs instrumental style and on top of it Freddie Gibbs seems to be on his best behavior when it comes to the lyrics and these songs the concepts that he has in these songs just generally being focused on the subject matter at hand and consistently he delivers the more thought-provoking side of his typically gangster persona as far as the beats go on this thing there are so many highlights like the very grimy funk groove on the song Scarface the tinny synthesizers on this thing the weird kind of police sirens or what sounds like gunshots going on in the background this thing sounds like it was lifted straight out of a 70s exploitation film and with mad lib while the appeal continues to be the assembly the composition of the beat it's also how he treats the sounds within the beat to this instrumental as if this could even be the case but this instrumental sounds like it was made in the 70s and it sort of has gotten more wrinkles and just sort of flabbier and more experienced over time in a good way I mean it's kind of like a finely aged wine or cheese I love the warm base and the stuttering high hats and the analog synthesizer lead pricks on the Songhai the twinkling guitar leads on the songs thuggin are fantastic this instrumental to me is is really top-notch when it comes to the more psychedelic side of Mad Libs instrumentals and that's another thing I don't think he gets enough credit for while he is you know very very strictly a hip-hop producer I think his beats have always had a very subtly psychedelic quality to them sort of triggers triggers trippy very textured they're Shitsville which is maybe my favorite beat on this entire LP with it's really classical string arpeggios playing throughout the track I love the groove the beat of this song - really one of the more cinematic instrumentals on the entire LP and there are some other instrumentals here as well that the sort of shoot for that glassy high-class soul sampling like robes this instrumental is so beautiful it's like one sample one beautiful sample of a song cascading over another it's so layered it's so beautiful and I think the song shame with bj the chicago kid features a lot of the same characteristics - but BJ's guest vocals on this track are so well mixed into the song and also kind of have a vintage quality to them that I never really took notice of until now just so silky smooth so Golden Age soul that as he's singing over the song is his contribution of the track actually sounds original to the sample there's a really great set of synthesizer arpeggios and some very punchy horn hits on the posse track that ends this song out that features verses from Mac Miller Miche Darko Casey Veggies Domo Genesis gee Wiz and Sunna and the song real the beat that kicks this track off is probably one of the most hard-hitting insane trunk knockers on this entire LP not only does the beat hit hard but I love how noisy the instrumental is and yet Freddie Gibbs just has enough space to kind of do what he does it just sounds like there's so many twinkly guitars or maybe even sitars just piling on top of each other with this track and what I suspect are maybe xylophones or vibra phones kind of littered in the background - and then the track just kind of stops and kicks into this surprise beat transition which is an incredibly blissful piece of hip-hop magic it real highlight on this LP and then there's the song bomb that has a number of different synth sounds watery synthesizer leads a kind of really bright shrill wall of synthesizers that pop in occasionally and yet the song is eerie and spacious enough to give Freddie Gibbs just the perfect stage for what he's trying to you lyrically and that is the number one most important thing about these instrumentals they complement what Freddie is doing and that's important his delivery tends to run a little monotone and and that is part of what has made me so unenthusiastic about his past projects but Madlib does such a great job of setting the emotional tone of each song that it's like almost as if I can kind of predict the sort of track that Freddie Gibbs is going to come through with before he even starts spitting the sound of these beats just fits the tone of these songs so well like for example the track deeper a song where Freddie Gibbs essentially used to be in love with this girl the relationship is over and it cut him deep and every single time he says that on the hook of this track I'm just like damn essentially this woman matured beyond him and his thug life and wanted to date a guy who was just in Freddie Gibbs account more Square and he also makes know that what does this guy got that I ain't got he's just trying to be an astronaut although astronauts are pretty cool but with the twist ending toward the back end of this track this is easily one of the most impressive tracks I've heard Freddie Gibbs pulled together and then there's the song thuggin where essentially Freddie Gibbs is like addicted to this street lifestyle he doesn't see himself leaving it he says he's going to be sagging his pants when he's 40 and even if he does leave the streets are still going to be in him and while he does seem to again embrace this lifestyle he doesn't really paint a very pretty picture of growing old in this world this is a sentiment he expresses again but I think with even more vivid lyrics on the song broken and then for those who are looking down on Freddie Gibbs and the life that he leads there is the track Shitsville where essentially he's kind of putting haters in their place not only with one of the most relentless flows on this entire LP but with the mantra that you're just like me with all the cheating the drinking the drugs he just kind of sees himself as being someone who is making the best of the situation that he's in like anyone else and agree or disagree the passion that he has for this on this track is undeniable and simultaneously this track is a bit of a welcome to my world kind of anthem - with a killer hook that shows off a pretty strong Tupac influence not a comparison I usually make because so many rappers are quick to already compare themselves to Tupac hmm but this is one of the few moments where I think not only the sound of Freddie Gibbs voice the way that he delivers this hook and the level of skill that he shows on this track as well I mean the comparison is legit their tracks for Freddie Gibbs is not quite as conscious and and goes right for the aggressive jugular like on the song bomb where he's kind of putting himself into this coke dealer persona selling drugs getting people addicted of course Raekwon the chef is on the back end of this track delivers a very appropriate verse and the last line on Gibbs first verse of this track is hilariously violent talking about how he's going to be leaving these people's thoughts on his shoelaces and then there's the song reel where immediately right after the intro Gibbs goes in on Young Jeezy really hard for mismanaging him when he was on his CT world label he's pretty unforgiving about the whole thing and he takes some hard shots and then there are some other tracks on here the feel really relaxed laid-back kind of blissful like Harold's where it seems like Freddie Gibbs kind of reminisce is about the past his favorite fast-food fried chicken orders and then there is the song shan with bj the chicago kid again while this track is a bit of a heartbreaker relationship-wise it is a very relaxed laid-back beauty on the first half of this LP Gibbs really holds his own track for track 4 track the only real bump in the road is the Danny Brown feature on the Songhai which doesn't really ruin the track for its lyricism but the song is just so laid back and smooth and then Danny Brown comes through with no disrespect to the delivery or the flow obviously I have already dug it on numerous tracks but for this particular song I think Danny Browns more toned delivery would have done just perfectly but as far as the second half of this LP there are a load of features that seem to pile in all at once and and bring this record to a pretty strong close there's damo Genesis and Earl on robes again and again Damo seems to be just improving with every new feature that I hear him on I respect the hustle then there is Earl's verse on here which I mean you can't really expect a bad guest verse from earl scarface sounds great unbroken then Freddie Gibbs and absol actually come together on the track Lakers and sort of do a tribute to the west coast I can't always expect a great guest verse from AB but he does it on here and the basketball references continue on the track Knicks immediately after which in a way with Lakers here and Knicks being right there afterwards is sort of a nod to New York but this song topic wise is a lot less geographical and more about Freddie Gibbs history his past kind of repeating the violence that he's been living with for so long again Freddie Gibbs comes through with a really focused idea concept message on nearly every track here Madlib comes through with some really great instrumentals every track here there are a few moments that are maybe a little inconspicuous like the intro could have been more hard-hitting I think the song you know does not stick out quite as much as other tracks on here however this is still a hell of a hip-hop album and no question that it's going to go down as one of my favorites of this year I will actually go as far as to say that this record is kind of like the second coming of Mad villain and I can only hope that with time this record becomes just as infamous and that we all kind of sit here with blue balls waiting for these guys to follow this record up this is the best thing I've heard Freddie Gibbs on period and I could only hope into the future with new mixtapes and new albums that he is able to keep up this kind of focus this kind of passion and this kind of captivating storytelling I'm feeling a light a decent 9 on this thing transition if you give in this record listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Freddie Gibbs mad lib pinata forever

hiya everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new la dispute record the rooms of the house these guys are a Michigan band ten years going strong this is their third full-length LP and over the years they have evolved to become one of the most idiosyncratic bands an emo and post hardcore pairing the punk spirit and a lot of guitars of these genres with some incredibly vivid and wordy storytelling and this storytelling really reached a peak in the band's career on their last full-length LP wild life dropped in 2011 and is still remains one of my favorite albums of that year grows on me with every listen oh God such a good record if you haven't heard this record please freaking listen to this record really powerful tales all over this album backed with some great rock instrumentation there's a track on here the kind of details the decline and hopeful restoration of a church losing a child to cancer the destruction of some teenage kids life by anti-depression medication a deadly shooting and then subsequent arrests frontman jordan Dreyer's lyrics and singing are winding they're powerful they're loaded with just rollercoaster emotions climaxes plot twists and the instrumentation the band conjured to go behind these lyrics felt like they complemented the storyline of these tracks at every shift in gear that was made it's not like listening to a rock band cycle through a simple series of verses and choruses and even though all the tales laden into these songs are different it is the themes of emotional exorcism and catharsis and metaphorically getting things off of the chest that brings a lot of these tracks together and leaves this album feeling kind of like a concept or very thematic now widest pews back with the new full-length record rooms of the house and on this LP it seems that the band continues to take underground rock music and apply very true maduk wordy thought-provoking lyrics stories poems to it but there are some somewhat obvious changes that La Dispute presents for example this is the band shortest full-length LP so far and is a little more concise than the records they have put out in the past there's not a single song on here that approaches the five-minute mark and there are a few tracks on this LP as well that have faintly catchy and very straightforward guitar riffs or chords on a lot of songs here instrumentally anyway la dispute is no longer indulging in these winding evolving pieces of rock music in fact there are a handful of songs on this LP that instrumentally are kind of subdued which in one breath is kind of disappointing but in another I do think that has led to rooms of the house being the most varied lot of speed record today take the kind of subdued hypnotic drumbeat hanging in the background on the track woman in mirror these strung out guitars and the sort of lacks spoken word vocals seem faintly Slynt esque on this song and then there's the song extraordinary dinner party which opens up with this winning set of melodic chords that if it wasn't in this track I think could have played well into a an old-school dinosaur junior song production-wise la dispute sounds roughly roughly the same there are quite a few tracks on here where the guitars are noticeably legally louder than they have been on previous LPS and I would say with any other band that could have been a great thing but in this particular instance it makes at least on some songs to me especially the second track here it makes the lyrics it makes the vocals so much more difficult to read to make out there are moments where I really think it makes them kind of unintelligible and again for any other band that might not necessarily be a horrible thing but for La Dispute the lyrics just carry the songs so much it seems like the spotlight on this record even more than usual is being shifted away from Jeremy and to the characters that he's singing about it's again a very slight change not big enough to signify a huge in the band sound which could be a good or a bad thing with rooms of the house because for some coming into this record it may seem like La Dispute is just kind of putting together a by-the-numbers sort of LP which I understand could be kind of a hard feeling to avoid considering how unique and specific La Dispute sound is and on top of that any changes they make to their usual sound could seem really great sort of like the downstroke slow and kind of punky guitar chords on the track the mayor and splitsville outside of the context of this record when I was first exposed to this song and many other people too it seemed like this track could have been a grab for a poppier sound or even an attempt at just a stronger element of accessibility but in the context of the record I do like the song a lot more and I do kind of see these guitar courts kicking off the first verse of the album as sort of reclaiming a rock lovesong cliche because as the song progresses it does reveal some really great chord progressions and pretty explosive moments too now like la disputes last album this LP too seems to just kind of be a mixed bag of different tales however these don't feel strung together by the same themes of incredible emotional and sometimes physical trauma still it does not make this LP any less powerful as it kicks off with the track Hudsonville michigan 1956 a song that sets a scene with a woman who's in indiana her husband is over in michigan there's a tornado there's a storm she's shuffling the kids downstairs for shelter there's a bulletin over the radio the song gets really intense as does the track 35 a song that I believe is actually referenced on this opening track here and on this track Jeremy gives us a view of this incredible car accident involving many vehicles and people falling to their demise on a bridge that seems to give way it seems that this incredibly horrific event is actually a bit of a centerpiece on this record I actually think this records king Park if you will and it is referenced on these stay happy there as well as the narrator of this track is sort of contemplating this relationship he's seeing demise in front of him thinking about everything that could have been in the future whether or not that everything occurred in the past throughout this relationship was sort of a waste of time however there are some tails on this record that do not feel quite as grand in topic but it doesn't seem like the band puts any less effort into the storytelling or doesn't try to put any less urgency into the instrumentation for example scenes from highways from 1981 to 2009 which seems to contain a lot of intimate reflections on the past with this particular character that we're following on this record and while this track and no other track on here as well don't feel like a huge disappointment to me it's very clear that this record overall is not quite as elaborate or as extravagant as a lot of spews pass to falling kelpies the gap here isn't huge but it's noticeable and I think it's due to the Bands more concise approach on this record I feel like they are trying to make their instrumentation a little more straightforward on these tracks and a little louder a little brighter a little punchier and yet they don't try to alter their lyrical approach significantly and I think what they've ended up is just trying to put ten pounds of magic inside of a five pound bag to me this kind of lyricism in this kind of instrumentation needs more space needs more time it does not need a really hooky looped drumbeat it does not need a really obvious attempt to try to pull everything together on the closing track which while conceptually interesting is kind of an anti climactic finish and it doesn't necessarily need slightly louder guitars either overall I do think that this is a very good record from La Dispute but I didn't come out of this thing as infatuated with it as I have been with their two previous records still there are plenty of clever metaphors on this LP and allegory involving rooms houses furniture material things a dying relationship and of course there are a few detours as well into personal and widespread disaster I'm feeling a decent of strong seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you maybe you hated it but well why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana La Dispute forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Pharrell record girl super producer singer and songwriter Pharrell he only has a few albums to his name yet he is so widely known in the world of popular music through his fantastic production with the Neff Tunes and any Rd and he's also been kind of the architect of numerous pop R&B as well as knurl hits over the years both minor and major and he's been doing especially well this past year singing and producing some pretty major songs like blurred lines get lucky he had a hand in Beyonce's latest record as well as my favorite instrumental from the new schoolboy q album and he's essentially taking advantage of this latest success streak with a new record that I was kind of looking forward to once I heard the lead single from it happy a song which the tracklist of this record is quick to remind us is from the Despicable Me 2 soundtrack and even though the song is most likely one of the most feel-good songs of the past 365 days and really delivers on its title with some fun lyrics as well as some awesome vocal layering toward the back end of the track great drumbeat but what makes this track stick out to me the most is it is one of the few songs on this record where Pharrell's songwriting and singing actually pleases me I apologize but outside of my favorite any Rd tracks Pharrell's vocals his singing especially his falsetto I've never been a fan of it I personally find his falsetto singing to be a little too weak frail kind of boyish and oddly enough it's something that Pharrell has been relying on a lot lately and it's no more appealing for me here actually it becomes less appealing because I'm listening to her for 40 minutes in a series of songs that are nowhere near as good as a lot of the hits that we've heard Pharrell appear on lately in a nutshell for me listening to Earl is a lot like giving a listen to Justin Timberlake's latest full-length LP in the 20/20 experience I actually think the production on these two records share a lot of the same qualities however girl delivers hardly a shred of lyrical class not nearly as much extravagance or vocal ability and even though I do find a lot of similarities between these two albums the only track I think would have fit on to the 20/20 experience or at least the 20/20 experience part two snuggly and tastefully is the opener Marilyn Monroe the instrumentation is similarly ritzy expensive sounding and danceable there's strings all over this track there's a great drum beat these soaring vocals on the chorus it's got a strong disco vibe and despite all these instrumental characteristics that I'm talking about somehow the production on here still ends up sounding kind of plain kind of lifeless sort of colorless it just doesn't feel like I'm listening to real instrumentation it sounds like I'm just listening to thin synthesized just gutless Ness and even though I do sense a certain amount of variety among the instrumentals on this LP I think girl ends up being kind of homogenous from the subtly African music influence track lost Queen to the kind of reggae tinged Alicia Keys track toward the back end of this thing which is a favorite of mine on this LP but really only thanks to miss keys Justin Timberlake actually turns up on the second track on this LP brand-new and the song is alright it just kind of sounds like an off-the-wall era Michael Jackson riaj the loop bass horn and drum groove and for those that still think that Pharrell is a decent singer I I ask you listen to the song the hunter on this record excruciating it seems like on the surface it was going for a legitimate disco funk vibe but the gutless base and the strung-out guitars and the weird drum groove on this track leave this song feeling more like a Delta 5 song or like a slit song or something off of the disco not disco compilation series where you're getting these bands that are essentially Punk groups but taking the sounds of disco and kind of bastardizing them and making weird tongue-in-cheek pop and dance tunes and to kind of add insult to injury on this track Pharrell just dishes out some lyrical trash duck dynasty's cool and all but they've got nothing on the females call I'm a hunter you're a hot man I'm a hunter you're a hot guy and a hunter you're a hunter I'm a hunter I'm a hunter and this tasteless lyrical streak continues on songs like gush which for me is one of the most unsexy words you can apply to a sexual situation and yet it happens here and then there's come get it BAE with Miley Cyrus we're essentially using motorcycles as a metaphor there are some sexual situations being described idea free idea free idea here Pharrell go on tour behind this album and get a motorcycle shaped bed or bed shaped motorcycle whichever one you can get your hands on for the least amount of money and then have Miley Cyrus twerk on your face on the bed and then ride away into the sunset because it's also a motorcycle unless it's just a bed shaped motorcycle because then it's just a bed the vocal harmonies that Miley Cyrus and Pharrell have on this track just sound really cheap and and fake and just so thin and just so boring to listen to oh and on top of it the groove the bassline the drums on this track just sound like a really lazy reappropriation of like a classic New Orleans funk beat from like a band like the meters or something like that I could go into nearly every track on this LP pointing out what makes it so unappealing but the truth is is that you know this record doesn't really need to be appealing it's not good it doesn't need to be good and it doesn't need to be good because Pharrell's bread and butter has never been his albums Pharrell is going to continue to great songs I'm sure it's just that a lot of them are not going to have his name in front of them that's all it doesn't make him any less important or influential though some artists are best on the stage and some artists work best behind the scenes and Pharrell is one of the few artists who has made a really successful career out of having a foot in both these worlds girl however is clearly one of those moments where Pharrell tries but both feet into the spotlight and the end result is just silly or really arduous listen really lackluster songwriting production lyricism there's a terrible song on this record for every okay one that there is I'm feeling a light two decent three on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it did it make you happy I do like that song this is a really good song though [Music] Anthony Fantana Pharrell girl forever

Super's hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new me goes mixtape no label to me gose is an Atlanta rap outfit they've been active since the late 2000s however it wasn't really until last year that they really started to blow up catch some major attention it was really off of the back of a new single titled Versace Versace Versace Versace Versace Versace Versace Versace a section for such a Versace easily one of the most gimmicky rap songs of 2013 and while I don't really mind dumbed down simplistic trap rap songs like this and Hannah Montana make me feel like there is a subset in hip-hop music right now that is currently in a race to the bottom to see who can write the most effortless lyrics and right now after that single has blown up me ghosts are trying to pull off a one-two punch by putting out this mixtape coming out with some of their most hard in-your-face hype material yet and hoping to actually capitalize and draw out the popularity that they received as of late essentially this mixtape is their attempt to let this new audience of theirs know what they are all about dealing dealing dealing and you know there are different storylines and song concepts occasionally on some of these songs and peppered throughout these tracks to our peaks at the rags to riches story that migos has coming up really from from nothing and then all of a sudden blowing up in hip-hop music being rich being famous although they say numerous times that they would rather be rich than famous and on top of these things there's also constant accusations toward all other rappers out there saying that hey we started new Atlanta we did this whole new southern sound thing first everybody else is copying us there are just a lot of really vague call-outs toward other rappers for stealing their constant triplet flows that get used to that flow if you listen to this mixtape and it is 25 songs long you're gonna hear it a lot and while they seem pretty passionate about this accusation and asserting that they've done this first and they're not getting the respect that they deserve they've collaborated with nearly every major hip hop artist out right now that could potentially be sitting in the middle of the crosshairs of this target that Mego seems to be waving everywhere they worked with Drake they've worked with ASAP ferg they've worked with Chief Keef it did something with Trinidad James as well as French Montana they're kind of whittling down the pool of rappers that they can successfully sneak diss and making all these accusations and all these call-outs of other rappers being unoriginal sound kind of silly whoever these accusations are pointed at they really get annoying since migos don't really put a name to any of it or go into that much detail into it it's just suspect along with the fact that they constantly debate their one-hit-wonder status on these tracks however it doesn't look good for you if you're constantly referencing your only major song that's blown up and you're trying to get people to stop thinking that you're a one-hit wonder I think migos is confused between the significance of starting something and popularizing something because if they've done either of those things it's clearly not the latter and to be completely honest four three guys who might be originators of the sound that we're hearing it doesn't sound all too different from a lot of the other hyped overly simplistic trap rap that you might have caught on to over the past few years still migos do bring some decent songs to the table and they do bring elements to their style that feel kind of unique this thing is easily one of the most energetic mixtapes that you're going to hear all year and on top of it I think migos ad-lib game is the top notch they're all these really odd cartoony jarring shouts in the background behind tons of verses either highlighting a word that was set in a line or actually contextualizing a word or giving the meaning of a word or a piece of slang that was said in the song it's like listening to a really loud rap genius annotation in the background of a song that you like and even though their style may be pretty simple and straightforward and just really blunt I do think there is an immense amount of chemistry between the three dudes in migos takeoff quavo and offset it's so much chemistry I can't really deny it I mean they just bring so much energy to the microphone and just pummel with these very fast triplet flows one dude after another it's really intense it's really high energy I know they're not rapping about the most deep of topics but there's something really visceral to the way that they deliver on their songs combined with the very nutty clickety clackety bass heavy trap beats some of which are produced by Brick Squad affiliates like Zaytoven and there are moments on here where I think that migos are really electrifying in their very direct / simplicity like on tracks such as ounces for example houses houses asses asses whole lot of Alice's or even contraband and among these 25 tracks there are songs where me goes actually managed to stick to a storyline like on the song hot boy where essentially we're getting a tale of a drug dealer who is being extorted by the police or freak No More which probably has one of the most hilarious courses on this entire LP don't try to run game on me I'm not a police station essentially a tract about the stripper who falls in love with one of the migos and essentially wants to give up
