hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review the new real estate LP atlas this is the third full-length LP from new jersey van real estate they started making waves back in 2009 with their debut album that came out on Woods's trekkers in LP that didn't make as big a splash as the beach fossils record that was put out in 2010 but was still a major route when it comes to a lot of that faint reverb heavy soft jangly inoffensive wallpaper pop rock that has been turning so many heads in the indie rock world for the past few years and outside of the beach fossils LP that came out last year there has been much in this new rock sound that has vibed with me plus I think the only reason I loved that record is because it did deviate from the usual very bland formula I feel many of these bands take this help he was a touch more aggressive the guitar tones were a bit meteor and tangible as well as the drums being punchy Beach fossils while they do have music that is pretty hazy and strung out their live performances are a lot more aggressive and I feel that that aggressive magic came through on this LP bands like real estate however are constantly in that chilled relaxed laid-back mind frame and I don't mind soft music but if all of the instrumentation is going to melt together into this blobby uniform colorless haze that emotes nothing then I just have hard time seeing boy I'm really sad that that's what passes right now for feel good and relaxing rock music essentially deprive the listeners of a lyric that sticks out that they can react to or be moved by deprive them of a vocal that might be the slightest bit emotive deprive them of a bold melody deprived them of an infectious groove literally give them nothing to react to give them no reason for any emotion whatsoever to be stirred up in any which way and then it'll have to be relaxing right if bliss is really bony guitars and drums thinned out with reverb delivered with Hale musical performances then give me hell there are a few moments on this LP to stick out to me like the cutesy synthesizer melody on April song a pretty decent instrumental on this thing and the guitar leads that open up the song primitive make for one of the sweetest spots on this entire LP there's not a bad chorus melody on the song - and the song how I might live is pretty droney but it's one of the few tracks on here where the vocals are a little pained a little emotional and the lyrics are actually very intelligible on the song and there's a bit of a folky chord progression to this track - it's an interesting falling in love song but what really holds this track back is the tempo and the execution the band plays this song so slow they play it so daintily that the overall sound of this track is more awkward than it is natural or moving it's like listening to a recital performance you know it's really left-field comparison but you know what exemplifies like a really relaxing sweet on the ears very feel-good pop or rock song to me dancing in the moonlight dancing in the moonlight the King harvest track dancing in the moonlight what a stellar song what an easygoing very nice to listen to intoxicating very chill piece of music and yet the bass line is grooving it's got a melody that's worth remembering it's got a chorus that I can't help but sing along with this does nemenyi that and you know there are some contemporaries that do come to mind when it comes to this particular sound that I do enjoy like I said Beach fossils I dig them and maybe the new Kurt Vile record as well but in terms of the psychedelic quality of that record the length of the songs some of the weird lyrical imagery - I find a lot of ambition on that record with Atlas none overall I didn't like the last two real estate records and I see no reason to like this one either I'm feeling of light too decent three on this thing transition if you've given this wrecker to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why I imagine that many of you probably don't agree with me and if you don't voice your piece you know I'm interested in hearing what you think cool cool Anthony Fantana real estate atlas forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new white suns record totem these guys are new york rock outfit and this is their third full-length LP i dug on their sophomore album sinew back in 2012 an album that was one of my favorites of that year an LP that I thought was really refreshing in its chaotic approach chaotic approach to noise rock yes noise rock bands from this genre that you may love or remember like Sonic Youth or flipper Boris big black or Jesus Lizard all bands that have far more composure than white Suns and while white Sun songs do have an element of composition to them there's a lot of very visceral guitars and drums that seem pretty planned out and pre-written on this thing lyrics that go from really wild twisted dark poetry to unadulterated anger and there are some pretty ambient interludes where the sounds the noises that run throughout them seem so specific and so treated and so I guess fuss over that they couldn't possibly have just been made up right there in the moment as the band was just playing or performing this record so there's really a mix of the sounds on this album being just so unpredictable in sporadic and very purposeful there's a very structural element to this LP and many of the songs on here have a variety of different parts however the tracks that white Suns pull together on this record are so psychotic and overwhelming that it makes it almost impossible sometimes to even concentrate or make note of these things or even think about things like technical ability or guitar tone well I think has consistently been so impressive with white Sons is how they mix noise and rock music typically a lot of the bands that I enjoy to sit in the genre just sound like rock music or punk rock music with a very strong noise element white Suns blend these two genres together so well that it never really sounds like I'm listening to you just won or just the other I think they're also great a bringing about the emotions I typically expect from and and feel with both honors as well I mean this album to me is it's visceral it's exciting it's aggressive like a great Punk LP and yet it's disorienting and grading like a very good noise album to totem to me is just a clash of raw adrenaline and the most bleak and tortured of human emotions the band is constantly shifting back and forth between these overwhelming noise rock pieces and these very subtle eerie more ambient tracks on the album that really seem to segue these heavier more hard-hitting spots and these softer moments make for some really eerie interludes and I sit there paranoid waiting for the band is going to come back at me swinging with a spiked bat of aah so there definitely is an element of surprise to this record that was there when I was first listening to it and this surprise element is something that I do find a lot of Noise music records rely on that wish to sporadically jar the listener by just introducing them to all these new and wild changes in pace and sounds over a very short period of time however I also felt that many of these songs were sticking with me they had elements that were worth remembering or had kind of a spotlight on them or were presented in a way where the band really wanted to make an emotional impact on the listener with this part of the song the listener has to really gravitate to this part meaning that while disorienting yes white Suns make sure to pack this album with highlights Plus on top of it I think the band's done a really great job of building on the sound set that they had on their last record I'm finding more layers on totem I'm finding more colors overall some really dissonant grading just ah torturous Electronics intense feedback this LP opens up with priests and laboratory killer opener for this thing later another heavy track on here clairvoyant which is one of the most pummeling spots on this entire LP the intro of the song eventually this heavy intro gives way to these noisy wall of sound that seemed so huge and so monstrous that it's actually difficult to think of them being created by the human hand much less regular rock instrumentation it's so noisy it's so layered it's so impenetrable and yet there's sort of an element of warmth to this as well that I feel slightly comforted by eventually this wall of sound dies down I love the over modulated bass rumbles that are kind of coming in and the strong out guitars and then the most amazing vocal on this entire LP pours through my gods face is made of bearers my gods faces like my father's this song to me is is easily one of the most twisted displays of human expression I've ever been an audience to especially as the song just goes into this insane downward spiral of noisy guitars and drums and just repeated shouting of pleading out played it out this album is no hawk in the park there's the Csonka thesis has a really spaced out rhythm sort of primal slow-moving groove this B is stacked with layers of dissonance that are kind of difficult to decipher the origin of and the manic vocals all over this thing are just so passionate to me they just reach down in the in the most fed-up of emotions and then amplify them a thousand times typically that that just raw impossible to ignore emotion is what I like so much about the very shouty generally screamy vocals on white Suns records even though there are more toned-down vocals on this LP just very stone-faced flat lines spoken word and even though if you take the vocals and just separate them out of what you're hearing musically on this record and just analyze them for themselves they don't sound like much I think the music does a great job of just setting the stage for what the vocals do and just complements them so well I mean the vocals sound like hell and the music sounds like hell and it's just hell on hell on hell now these heavier noisier more eventful tracks like I said earlier are segwayed with softer her songs which if you listen to them by themselves they don't really sound like much but they do provide some much-needed breathing room between these very tracks and that's not to say they should immediately go into the background in your mind as soon as they come on because the sounds on a lot of them seems like white Suns really really concentrated on creating some weird strange out-there textures for these interludes and then there's the world of lock 2 which is a track that features an incredibly soft moment paired with a louder more intense finish it actually goes over really well it makes me wish more tracks on here mixed these two worlds together though I do think that you know it works really well in the context of sort of looking at the entire album as a whole overall I got to say I think white Suns really did it again on this record they came through with an even more impressive combination of noise and rock music to the point where with their last album yeah there were moments that felt more noisy there were moments that felt more rocky but here it really feels like they've blurred those lines to the point where I mean it doesn't really sound like either I think the production on this thing is better there's more sounds it's heavier I think the lyrics the poetry the vocal delivery is a lot more stunning and emotionally impactful they really fine-tune their ability to bring together eye widening sonic weirdness with just explosive punk rock energy I'm feeling a decent too strong eight on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and and that's it Anthony Fantana white suns forever

slowly stalking serial killer corners his victim and I appreciate the vibraphone the saxophone the drums the piano just the slow pace of all the instrumentation all the space all the vastness just the a I don't want to say poppier but just a more sweet on the ears easygoing alternative rock style which is fused with these progressive rock sounds and complex performances and even though this album hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a letter from a fan dearest Anthony first off I would like to say I'm a huge fan of your reviews and you are my favorite youtuber I appreciate how you truly are the busiest and you really do a lot to cover so many bands I like you're welcome and thank you the reason I am writing you is because I am in a very dark place right now my most recent relationship has ended horribly in other words I was left by someone I was very very close to this has been something extremely hard for me to cope with but music is something that has always helped me through struggles in the past so Anthony do you think you could suggest a good album or two with post breakup emotional devastation I would greatly appreciate it heartbroken in Ohio okay dear okay first off I'm really sorry to hear about your relationship ending I hope you're able to get through it it's going to take time for these emotional wounds to heal and then afterwards it's going to take a reassessment of who you are as a person and what you're going to want out of relationships into the future for right now I would say just have faith in the process of self exploration and self to not only find out what you need out of a relationship into the future but also find the strength to carry on and love yourself and in the process of doing this music can be a really big help a lot of people after a breakup they decide to listen to what many categorize as break up albums a lot of which are tagged with that breakup tag because there's either some well documented or inside information that the artists creating the album was going through a breakup of some sort over the course of the writing of the album or the songs on the album or went through a breakup immediately after or during the release or something LP is like Beck's sea change and what I believe is the last Abbott album or even Fleetwood Mac's rumours or Bob Dylan's blood on the tracks even the Marvin Gaye LP here my dear and then again there are people who you know don't really care about whatever the backstory is behind the album they just want that subject matter that break up love loss subject matter to just be up in front and in their face so that they can sympathize they can empathize they can just feel with feel camaraderie with the story that's being told in the music and there are numerous records that do this some of my personal favorites as of late being like PJ Harvey's rid of me or the last Fiona Apple album any number of bright eyes LPS but especially lifted a lot of people prefer Elliott Smiths either or and I'm actually really really partial to mountain goats albums like get lonely as well as Tallahassee or even the of Montreal album a bedside drama which i think is a criminally overlooked breakup album it's sort of like a cute bittersweet vaudevillian concept album about the course of a relationship that sort of doomed from the start beginning and then finally ending but for me personally I don't necessarily need a story there that I relate to or I don't need to know that the artists on the record has been going through a breakup in order to actually have the music helped me through some kind of emotional trial I may be going through I mean I prefer just to listen to sad slow or somber music on this kind of occasion and I mean there are any number of instrumental rock or instrumental electronic instrumental whatever albums that fit this bill experiment with listening to artists like Godspeed or Tim Hecker or other artists that may have vocals but very powerful instrumentals as well like Seguros and why couldn't the sun album be the soundtrack to your post-relationship despair or Joy Division or depressive black metal or the sort of emotional jangling pop music of the Smiths I personally have more of a strong passionate emotional reaction to sounds melodies and chord progressions then I do simply lyrics and I think a lot of people are that same way too I mean how else could you explain the fact that so many misinterpret the song I will always love you as a love song when it is in fact when you read deeper into the lyrics a breakup song so sure the message the backstory can be really important but I think the sound is just as important if not more important for example I could be going through a breakup and you could put on some Taylor Swift who actually has a ton of songs about love on the rocks and breakups but that may not be the sound that I want to hear or will actually bring me comfort and then again there's tons of emo and screamo bands out there that you could listen to that perfectly depict the emotional state of despair but maybe a lot of people don't want some dude whining or number of albums out there that I think could be that shoulder to cry on thank you for writing transition if you care to head down there in the comments on this video and post what you feel is is your forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new BEC LP morning phase beck singer songwriter multi-instrumentalist producer and musical eccentric who came up in the 90s with a pretty diverse sound on hit records such as mellow gold and odelay these albums essentially being mishmash 'as of alternative rock funk hip hop and low phi music as well and Beck's entire discography reflects that very same diversity as well from the really oddball musical experiments and the strange tape recordings on stereo Coleman or - the very freaky funk on the album midnight vultures and then there's the Freak Fulke record one foot in the grave personally my favorite of vex then there's the really odd poppy appeal of his biggest records and then there's the information and yet Oh albums that take the sound of Beck's nineties output but give it a slightly more electronic edge on a lot of the tracks and then there's the very funky singer/songwriter esque toned down and somber sounds that come through on albums like mutations and sea change and with all these shifts and sound and style and mood of course there are some personal low points and high points for me throughout Beck's discography I personally have always been more of a fan of Beck's poppier side of his more eccentric and freaky side not so much the syrupy slow-mo sad songs that make up a majority of a few of his records however this era and Beck's career is a favorite for a lot of people and I get it sometimes songs in that mood are just what you want to hear and on top of it I think Beck's voice is very deep voice lends itself to this kind of songwriting a lot of people do consider records like sea change to be one of his best and the record is definitely his biggest success when it comes to making music in that gloomy er full gear style and now with this newest record of his Beck is revisiting that sound with what I've been told is kind of the companion record to that record and going into this LP part of me is psyched because of course this could be an opportunity for this side of Beck's persona to finally click with me and unfortunately once again that was just not the case while sea change and mutations a lot of the time don't really move me emotionally I do see the appeal in those records and it just wouldn't feel right to me to call those albums bland or uninteresting however those descriptions somehow feel right when it comes to me talking about this morning phase is essentially the equivalent to waking up after a long nights sleep and quickly realizing that absolutely nothing cool is going to happen today that's pretty much the tone the album sets on its forty second introduction which has all these very turgid overinflated string sections kicking off the album that while they do feel really huge and lavish there's absolutely no emotion to be pulled from them at all they may sound pretty in theory but they're a little too reserved to convey much of anything and to me that is many of the songs on this record in a nutshell I think Beck and I think these tracks overall are just a little too concerned with their own sense of bliss to actually pull off anything worth remembering even on one of the lead singles from this LP blue moon which I think is one of the most underwhelming tracks on this LP Beck starts singing I'm so tired of beard and it just comes off so melodramatic just pulling for something that's that's not there this track and many others on here just emotionally gutless and and compositionally when it comes to the melodies as well as the chord progressions and the rhythms the songs on this record feel so incredibly basic and yeah for sure the aesthetic is intentional Beck is not trying to make any kind of sudden loud or shocking moves on this record because it would not be in line with the blissful and very soft and easygoing tone however with its softness with its blissful Ness I don't think this record is that so duck - it's not that intoxicating either so because Becca's trying to keep things simple a lot of the time he does not build on this very basic foundational instrumentation rarely does the instrumentation on this record feel tangible or or meaty because for the most part the inoffensive sounds of reverb and Moaning vocals are pretty much what's on the menu occasionally on these tracks there is a bit of a stylistic shift with some of these songs showing off a bit of a 60s psychedelic pop vibe like on the track blackbird chain and the song wave was one of the few tracks here that actually gripped me because it had this very huge minor tone orchestral string section hanging in the background it was easily one of the darker tracks on this entire record the strings on this track really make this thing a highlight on the entire LP and occasionally there is a drum beat or a guitar part that just feels a shade sharper than usual on the song sort of like on the track say goodbye but because a lot of the instrumentation tries to take such a simple approach what's being played feels kind of cliche because the chord progressions the very basic melodies not that I think they're directly ripping off any one track but because they're so simple in their approach they kind of sound like everything the song turn away which in comparison with the other tracks has just these driving finger pick guitars is actually a bit of a saving grace on this LP and actually gives one of these songs of pulse whereas most of the other songs on this thing are flatlining still I love the eerie lead guitar melodies on this thing the vocal melodies are great as well the tight vocal harmonies are nice to me this track reminds me of like a Fleetwood Mac song or something but with a much darker tone and there's a really detailed melodic progression that sits through two of the verses on this track in the first half it really is a song that I love and the only song that I loved on this entire record but the thing is a lot of Beck's fans and Beck as well obviously feel that there is something to playing songs this speed with this level of sparse and I've been seeing it get rave reviews as well and it's just I don't know either flying over me flying under me it's just not hitting me at all I'm feeling a strong three tool like four on this thing transition if you've given this wrecker to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and where does this album sit in your ranking of your favorite BEC records let me know also are you a banana man I'm a banana man Beck morning phase forever

hi everyone Anthony Phan tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Saint Vincent record self-titled st. vincent record this self-titled record is the 4th full-length LP from singer-songwriter and guitarist extraordinaire Annie Clark whose music deals heavily in art pop chamber pop indie pop with each new release getting a little more abrasive abstract experimental little noisy not too harsh not too experimental because on some of st. Vincent's best records like actor and strange mercy she maintained her pop appeal I think Annie sort of hit a creative peak on her last LP with a number of songs like cruel and Cheerleader and Northern Lights tracks that bring buzzing bulky and sometimes brittle guitars together with Annie's beautiful voice and some really heavenly effervescent strings and since so thus far I've never really had a reason not to be excited for a new st. vincent record especially with each new album getting a shade weirder and i've been head over heels for nearly every song that is dropped from this LP thus far songs like digital witness and birth and reverse tracks that are lyrically and conceptually clever and instrumentally glitchy textured and groove wise sort of perky jerky the song bertha reverse has all these really jagged punchy guitar riffs that remind me of something sort of like off of one of the first two debo records of but pushed past the edge of insanity and a lot like Devo the music here is most definitely rock but very electronically tinged there are drums on this record that sound live and sound intense but there are moments here where the beats feel sort of looped or stiff or even synthetic maybe a feel that sort of carried over from the recent collaboration saying Benson did with David Byrne there are really prominent synthesizers all over this record and the guitars wild I mean they sound like guitars for the most part they are just cooked down to the point where many of the guitar tones that you just feel like nothing but ultra grimy digital Distortion it's interesting that some of Annie's most animalistic lyrics and vocal deliveries land on such cold rigid instrumentation while there are some songs on here they have great grooves and are really catchy like digital witness I think for the most part st. Vincent tries to intentionally suck the viscera out of rock music and for the most part I think it's a really great success like with the opener here rattlesnake where the drums feel like they're being played through a sewer pipe there's some really rough distorted since sequences that are pretty funky playing throughout the track - and then on top of that there are all these sound effects littered across the song but even in all of this chaos we get a really catchy concise tune that does a great job of setting the tone for the record and to mention digital witness again maybe my favorite track on this entire LP really smart lyrical satire about the internet generations vanity this track has one of the grooviest bass lines and rhythms on the entire LP and it's easily one of the most colorful songs on this thing - even though there are a lot of sounds on here that feel so rough and just manipulated heavily the grimy guitars and scents it really nicely against the horns and Annie's beautiful vocal harmonies the harder and poppier tracks on this record for me impress again and again and again like with the song Huey Newton a song that I wasn't too in love with at first but eventually the the very beautiful unsuspecting intro grew on me and the way that it explodes into one of the heaviest riffs on the entire album in the second half is really gratifying and with the song regret the guitar riff being played throughout this track feels like a Led Zeppelin riffs sort of turned inside out retweet for a noise pop record which I guess it is I love the blissful hook on this track - I think it's a really beautiful contrast from the distorted heavier spots on this track even though I do think st. Vincent is putting out her most experimental record yet here I don't think she loses sight of making sure she balances these harsher moments out with at least some elements of beauty and I also love the song psycho one of my favorite tunes on this record and I love the really repetitive driving krautrock s beat on this thing too I think the only song on this record where Annie really goes overboard a little bit is on bring me your love's which essentially sounds like an alien race of st. Vincent's coming down and violently abducting everyone in a spaceship to take them off into a very faraway galaxy to love them until the end of time oh oh baby you're right that sounds kind of nice but the music itself feels so hellish with it's grimy bass lines and tractor beam synthesiser leads and he manipulates her vocals on this track pretty heavily with uh with a very dissonant chorus vocal hanging in the background and then the rhythm on this track is like a combination between a marching band and an amazonian drum circle and the lyrics on this track maybe some of the most eye widening or gripping on this entire LP in that they are very forceful and subtly kinky part of me feels like this track is just freakish fun other parts of me it sort of leaves a bad taste in my ears either way I think they're really apocalyptic ethereal synthesizers toward the back end of this track really sort of brings this cacophonous instrumentation together really nicely however the Zayn eNOS really takes over on the track every tear disappears which has one of the weirdest instrumentals on this entire LP and along the way in making this mess of a musical backdrop st. Vincent fails to bring a decent tune not only are the farty synthesizers and the really stiff drums not that interesting but hearing st. Vincent's sings so beautifully over this instrumental just feels kind of awkward I guess there are moments on this LP where really harsh rigid cold backdrops of music fit against the very human vocals and create an interesting mix there are other moments on here where I think that's the case for nearly every single ballad - on this LP unfortunately songs like Prince Johnny and I for your love I love the tunes on these tracks and I think st. Vincent does a great job of singing on them as well not to mention that prefer your love is probably one of the more lyrically gripping tracks on this LP too but when Annie is singing on these tracks in search of that theatrical spotlight that's typically there in her songs the instrumentation in the background is just way too stiff to embrace her and lift her up where she belongs the closest I think st. Vincent comes to doing a great ballad with this colder icier style is the closing track on here which despite its very stiff instrumentation is also sort of heavenly and pastel-colored it's very synth heavy like many other songs on here but there are some great vocal harmonies some huge ringing bells in the background and some wonderful plucked arpeggios too and all of these things fill in the gaps that are typically there on some of the more toned-down songs here it's also a song where I find myself sort of curious and wanting to dig into the backstory behind the lyrics on this track too overall I did like this LP I think this record has some of her best songs yet but also easily one of her worst and while I admire st. Vincent greatly for coming together with this really experimental pop and rock record not every experiment in my opinion goes over really well I do prefer actor to this I do really really prefer strange mercy to this which still continues to be my favorite Saint Vincent record but I don't really feel terribly let down by what happened on this LP I did get at least a few of what I think are some of the best songs of the year out of it I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh st. Vincent self-titled forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new schoolboy q album oxymoron schoolboy q is a West Coast rapper member of the infamous black subject matters on this track it could be the way he's delivering over these songs but he was just sounding way bolder more confident on this LP he is just going in on some of these songs and oddly enough I know that a lot of songs on this LP emphasize delivery over lyrics and substance a little bit and I know not everybody is going to like that but I don't think it was a bad move for him if a more extreme delivery is going to be what makes schoolboy q more memorable then do it because I think he's gone from sort of scatterbrained and forgettable on his last LP to versatile and gutsy I really think schoolboy q is coming through the record where a lot of the tracks bring back that vivid vulgarity of 90s gangsta rap but with progressive production and just a more bizarre delivery at hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new / / Sun record terrestrials terrestrials is the new collaborative project from two huge names from the darker side of music drone metal and doom metal titans sun they've been coming out with some of the boldest heaviest and most uncompromising records in this genre since the early 2000s and considering they started out as an earth tribute band I think over time they've really come together with their own unique take on the style of music through records like black 1 monoliths and dimensions and alter and on this record Sun is coming together with over one of the most diverse bands that Norway has to offer whose lineup over the years is just as sporadic as their sound their discography is filled with songs that fit snugly into black metal dark ambient electronic music and trip-hop folk music chamber music dark jazz and after every stylistic turn over has taken over the years they've put out at least one or two records that seems to have been a big hit with the band's fanbase and the metal world at large but my personal favorites from the band's discography are their first three records all of which are black metal classics in my opinion and I guess in 2008 over linked up with Sun in Norway in over studio while son was in the country for a live gig and while getting together so spontaneously to just lay out some sort of improvised pieces sounds really awesome I was kind of apprehensive about this album when I went into it after reading the back story of it because on the one hand if this music was really some of Suns and overs best wouldn't the LP be longer it really only stands at 30 minutes and wouldn't there be more tracks wouldn't they have put this thing out earlier considering it was recorded in 2008 I was sort of afraid that this record wouldn't be anything more than just a fan favourite or collector's item versus a pinnacle in either band's discography but on the other hand the last major collaborative LP that Sun came out with altar with bore this is one of their best albums one of Boris's best albums - so there is reason to believe that putting son together with a group that's just as creative and interesting if not more will just create amazing results no matter how long the record is no matter how many tracks are on it and while I wasn't disappointed in this thing I did end up sort of on the fence with terrestrials on the whole I ended up wanting more length out of this thing I ended up wanting some of the tracks here to just be a little bit more climactic but still I think Sun and overcame together and made something that was sort of unique something that they wouldn't have done separately which is really one of the best things you can hope for when going into a collaboration between two really established artists so if you are even a casual fan of either band here I do think terrestrials is at least worth checking out just for the exploration 'el aspect there are moments on this LP where foundationally and conceptually it feels like a son song but over comes through and lightens up the drones a little bit making the sounds more ethereal harmonious and delicate like on the opener here let there be light this song is not really the massive overpowering wall of sound you typically expect from a son album but I still thought the track had its moments and and really eased me in to the record there are all these high-pitched tones swelling in and out of the mix as well as these tremolo tones and underneath this horns and strings are slowly introducing themselves into the mix and all of the instrumentation just slowly grows and fills in the gaps that they're creating until the song just becomes massive vast all of this sort of becomes a foundation for this wandering fluttering trumpet bring in the song kind of a jazzy flavor and that's fine it's it's not bad it doesn't ruin the track when I think the song really gets a little underwhelming is toward the finish line when drums are introduced and they're so blue body lists there are these heavy guitars playing against them too and you know while I appreciate the idea of coming together with an explosive finish payoff is is really hardly there on the flip side there are moments on this LP where it feels like I'm listening to an over song which son is bringing in some really meaty heavy elements like the closing track on here eternal return probably my favorite track on this entire LP I love the icy vibraphone on this track if that is vibraphone that I'm hearing I'm loving the strings the ethereal guitars this track is just so wide and expansive and panoramic it's like standing on top of the mountain just looking down and out on to everything that just stands before you and below you and the chords on this track just have a really really strong jazz influence to them and the pace that they're played at sort of reminds me of boron doc rah-rah and the transition this track makes from the first half to the second half is stellar string sections pop in and they're skipping very lightly against the tempo that the band is set for the track there's some heavy piano chords some cold synthesizers and Christopher rigs vocals come in sound so smooth yet a little unnerving after hearing this track and hearing this side of the Sun over spectrum eternal return is really the the place that I think this record could have explored further explored for more tracks or at least for more time there is the song western horn on this LP as well which is sort of a meaty middle ground between that over sound and that Sun sound it's not bad but it's not really a stunner either it's heavy but not that heavy it's got a lot of layers of instruments but I wouldn't call this track beautiful or anything like that this is really one of the darker more disturbing tracks on this entire LP the guitars are so grotesque they're all these mangled distorted tones calling out throughout the song - there's some really cold synthesizers there are some really cold keyboards as well and a really odd whistling sound that feels like a mix between the baby from Eraserhead screaming and a teakettle going off and this sound weaves in and out in a really weird way and is most apparent right at the finish of the song I like this LP I thought it was good I didn't think it was amazing it's got its moments I don't feel like it pushes the fringes too hard for either artist or the genres that these songs play in but I still do find terrestrials appealing for the sort of improvisational lightning in a bottle appeal that comes with Sun and over deciding to collaborate so suddenly the production is great it's well-balanced it's colorful the music is big it's Moody it's slow it's monolithic it does what it's got to do I'm feeling a strong six to a late seven on this thing transition if you given this new Sun over collaboration to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should I don't know review next hmm Anthony Fantana son and over terrestrials forever

Oh 'banahna hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new temples album Sun structures this is the debut full-length LP from uk-based rock outfit temples I've had a lot of people suggesting this record to me usually tagging it with something like whoa hey dude if you like Tim and Paula then give this record a listen because they're both psychedelic pop and you're gonna like that but the thing is while I do like a lot of tame Impala's songs and I did love their last record there's always been something about their unapologetic in-your-face nostalgia that has always sort of rubbed me the wrong way on their second full-length LP I feel like the van really upped the quality of the songwriting and the melody writing and the production too and it was so good that the blatant 60 psych pop worship wasn't so distracting however in the case of temples at least for me it is incredibly distracting even if the Basie kick drums and the watery guitars and the lavish keys are all executed and mixed really well and just sound gorgeous my biggest issue with the instrumentation on this record lies in the vocals I feel like they give in too easily to the temptation to play the revolver card and they deliver very little in terms of personality as a result if this album were a play I would say that Wow it has incredible production value really top-notch set and costume design everyone and everything looks really good but many of the scenes and the personality traits of the characters and the and the lines that they're speaking seem painfully familiar to productions I've already seen from the zombies and The Flaming Lips and and the Beatles and The Beach Boys all of whom have put out records that are a lot more ambitious larger in scope more exciting and in some cases a lot more raw meanwhile temple's comes through with really huge booming drums and some ultra fuzzy guitars hoping to recreate the same kind of electricity and I don't think it happens especially since many of the tracts on this LP seemed so uniform and sound even if the band does offer a bit of variety on the introduction to these tracks or some of the guitar tones across the LP I feel like temples have sort of neglected to acknowledge a major characteristic of some of the best records in 60s psychedelic pop and rock and that is their spontaneity the band really leaves that characteristic out of the picture and instead plays it pretty straight and pretty bubblegum across the 12 tracks here still I think the band sonic emulation of this style of music is really good they have most of the characteristics down that you would expect from a record in this style and each tune here has a pretty sharp yet slightly derivative melody to it like the tight syncopated guitar riffs and drums on the title track here and there really schmaltzy organ leads and chords on the track the golden throne which really is one of the better Tunes on this entire LP they're really bright and sunny guitar soloing at the start of the song mesmerize is like pure ear candy and I'm pretty impressed with the instrumental the heavy instrumental layering on the track move the season there are a lot of very simple straightforward feel-good psychedelic pop tunes on this record that are very pleasant to the ear but as I listen to the album more and it draws on the more impatient I get waiting for a single novel idea to seep through the guitars the bass lines the drums the vocals and it just doesn't happen and the more I listen to this LP the more apparent it becomes that the group's approach to song structure is pretty unexcited as well I don't know if it's the lack of surprises in these songs or if it's just that the performances on this thing are just so lacks they're just so smooth and unexcited but there's just something about many of these Tunes that by the time I've hit the halfway point the song has lost its flavor a little bit because I kind of know what to expect overall to me this record is just simply put pop with a psychedelic veneer and that's it it has great sound it has great production it has a lot of attention to detail in terms of the aural experience of this record but I feel like temples puts all of their eggs in one basket on this thing and totally neglects the idea of adventure and expansion I think this record is just a little too limited in scope and ideas to be all that exciting or interesting to me I'm feeling a strong 5 to a light 6 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it temples son structures forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a lotto from dear and I love your interesting views and thoughts and your ways of articulating them in such a clear is this the reason such talented musicians struggle to appeal to the majority should musicians dumb down their music in order to go mainstream does this apply to the Beatles Pink Floyd Queen and other respectful and highly popular mediocre average bands or am I not intelligent enough to realize oh boy I'd love to hear your thoughts John Partin Dear John I think you made some valid points in your Flaming Lips The Strokes nas Kanye West Outkast The White Stripes Radiohead Black Sabbath David Bowie Miles Davis Bob Dylan The Clash Pixies Hendrix and The Doors new order the list goes on all of these artists are pretty popular and I don't think anyone would argue that their music is dumbed down I think people tend to look at the music that is coming out today and topping the charts and being forgotten about since then I'll sugar sugar boo boo boo boo boo boo oh honey honey yummy yummy yummy I got love in my tummy a Nucky bond over new there are lots of great musical artists that were very popular in every decade that we can cite but also in every decade the charts have been topped with sappy love songs really simple pop songs novelty tunes this is nothing new in the early 1970s the German experimental rock band and kraut rock outfit Faust released their album the Faust tapes an album for the price of a single believe it or not this actually caused the band to sell tens of thousands of copies of this album that they wouldn't have otherwise because the Billboard charts don't tell you if an album is good or creative or artistic all it tells you is that a lot of people bought this and as we all know there's a lot of different ways to get people to buy things all of that being said that doesn't mean that when something is popular that it sucks I do agree though that a vast majority of the music on the charts does have a sort of simpleness to it a certain level of accessibility however that does not mean I agree with your second statement here that links hi everyone a nanny for to know a year the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new artificial brain record labyrinth constellation this is the debut full-length LP from New York metal outfit artificial brain it is a death metal record really you ill why would you say you when death metal is such a good genre okay it's neck chord in years away one it spool tool it's p3 it's point P you know I could argue with you but instead I'm going to change your mind with the power of music is that a big empty three player no it's the sound of opening your mind in one two four four people are terrible because they won't give death metal music a good fat shake they hear that music is death metal music and they don't even to listen to the music they assume they're gonna hate the death metal music before they have even listened to the death metal music come on people give the death metal music a nice fair shake be a good person to the death metal music you might like it so it's not a big empty three player I hate count your chesta so yeah death metal just like the song set doesn't always get a fair shake and with the genres really heavy use of distortion and really gruff guttural gruesome vocals blast beats I can sort of understand why most people shy away from it I personally am not really even a huge fan of every single sub-genre that this style of music has to offer I'm not huge on a lot of the more progressive and more technical stuff that comes out of death metal usually I'm not moved by those sounds I like my death metal a little more bloody and visceral but artificial brains new record here labyrinth constellation does sort of seem to sit further on that more technical side of the spectrum in case you didn't know this record actually features revocation guitarist Dan garrigue yellow but me personally I was most excited to hear that recording and production was handled on this record by Colin Marston multi-instrumentalist songwriter and member of bands like gore guts ball the arcticus dysrhythmia Crowell Asst and he typically doesn't record or write with a band unless they're doing something pretty forward-thinking and I do think artificial brain lives up to that expectation they do have a lot of the foundational qualities of death metal but they push many of them to an extreme or they experiment with them in some kind of significant way for one the really angular and difficult guitar riffs on this record tied together into a web from which there is no escape and these riffs lock in perfectly with some really intense and busy drum patterns artificial brain always seems to be looking for that next get changed they can make to the song and yet all the tracks here feel really fluid and cohesive it's not like they're so herky and jerky that you're hearing all these miscellaneous parts that don't really sound like they have anything to do with one another so I wouldn't say that this record is too jarring and yet it's not like all of these flashy technical guitars and drums sounds so uniform that everything here blends together into this formless flavorless soup of guitar and drum noise I think what really makes this record special is the really shrill and bright and strange guitar chords play throughout this thing they're really mutant melodies played on the leads they're weird but oddly catchy as well there are moments where the melodies on this LP feel pretty authentic like the title track on this LP and the closer moon funeral and sometimes these guitar leads build up to an explosion of melody that is sometimes eerie or even triumphant I like that artificial brain really appreciates contrast on this record they're always putting moments that are really chaotic and nasty and disgusting and just really difficult to pull apart up against spots that are a little bit more accessible and again melodic and often these more melodic guitars are layered on top of one another like a very noisy ear tickling pig pile in the same way that they would be multi tracked on like a Krauss record and even though I do see common ground between artificial brain and bands like Crowley's I think what happens on this LP is much more violent and sort of unpredictable and on top of being compositionally adventurous I think that some of the songs on this LP are sonically adventurous - there's a good handful of tracks on this LP that features some kind of sound experimentation and whether or not it's a big experiment or a small one it does add something significant to the song like the song absorbing black ignition which i think is my favorite track on here has a very eerie set of organ chords at the finish line or the track Frozen Planet which has all these strange icy tones hanging in the background backing up the guitars and the drums and the bass there's some chilling tones hanging in the background of the song hormones go as well which makes the song not only feel like a death metal track but like a sci-fi soundtrack feature as well and the song bastard planet right in the middle point of the song there is this giant explosion of drums and bass that's incredibly heavy really a highlight for me on the record this moment in the song is so dense and so saturated it's hard to tell one instrument from another with just out condensed it is throughout this whole LP the vocals consistently push the envelope of low guttural and kind of gross and overall the recording on this thing I'm really happy with it really impressed with it I like that it's so clear it's punchy the performances the execution on this thing is great the drums sound fantastic of the guitars sound fantastic it's also honed and together the music here reaches such a high level of virtuosity without shooting for a recording that sounds overproduced really quantized or digital the instrumentation on this record just feels so organic and in the moment and add it on top of all these really good sounds it's great recording these interesting and well written death metal tracks there is kind of a theme behind this album between the song titles and some of the more experimental sounds I mean there's a bit of a science fiction thing going on here with planets and moons and constellations in that regard there are elements of this LP that remind me a bit of vector if you're into a metal band with more of an intergalactic sound then check this LP out because I do think that like vector this record does have melodies that feel kind of from another world entirely as far as shortcomings at this LP has I do think that this thing is a little one-sided in terms of intensity and chaos a lot of the songs on here tend to just sort of bust in when they start I wish that the band showed a little bit more finesse in that regard and there are moments on here toward the first half of the album like worm harvester and frozen planets that blend together a little bit still I think the playing and the writing on this LP is great I think that this record is really creative take on the technical death metal style there's a lot of power and dexterity and Enter to the playing on this record and what's most exciting is some of the sonic experimentation that these guys bring to the table I would love to hear them keep up this technical edge into the future but maybe dive even deeper into some of these sound experiments I'm feeling a light to decent 8 on this I'm feeling a light to decent 8 on this thing transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why and what do you think I should review next also shout out to Matthew loft for the death metal song you're the best anthony Fantana artificial brain forever

hi everyone agony sad tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for us to get together relax and partake in a review of the new Sun Kil moon record Benji Sun Kil moon is the long-running singer/songwriter project of guitarist actor and lyricist Marc cosmic too many fans of underground music and indie rock and slow Court he is most famously known for his part in the band red house painters Andy has a pretty sizable catalog of albums under his own name along with a few collaborative LPS as well the guys had a really steady output since he was originally signed to a record label in the early 90s a little fun fact that I know because he sings about it on this record among many other things Marcus had a very long career of writing songs some of which are very long detail-oriented and kind of wordy and this is a role he's grown more and more comfortable with as he's released more material under the Sun Kil moon name and now he's at a point where it seems like if he writes a song about two lovers fighting that he would spend at least a verse or two telling you what time of day it is what the weather is their cat's name he would list out at least three movies from their DVD collection he's put out songs recently as well that seemed to be just unashamedly meta and singing about his mindset when writing songs are sort of the songwriting process or the lifestyle it has put him in or he throws out these personal stories that seem almost completely unedited in terms of information there isn't anything that mark is afraid to put into these tracks in terms of wow this is too personal oh this might be embarrassing there are tracks on this guy's last LP like among the leaves such as track 8 which is actually not track 8 on the songs track list but it is still a song about his life as a singer-songwriter the business the process he touches down on some of these same themes as well on the track UK blues where he is singing about just not having a good time while touring internationally being heckled having difficult performances being homesick among the leaves was a really in interesting record for mark because of how deep it sort of let you into just about every thought in his mind but it was a less direct album when compared with other red house painter records and Sun Kil moon records as well also marks vocal style on this LP felt really tired Haggard kind of aged but this album also had a really uniquely intimate charm to it as well the songs on this LP meander and Mark's thoughts wander and I think that makes these songs lose a little bit of impact however with this new LP from Sun Kil moon Benjie this LP is like a more gratifying take on this incredibly long-winded songwriting style every song on this LP seems so off-the-cuff and yet all the tracks feel so purposefully fantastic it's almost as if this LP is the result of Mark writing hundreds upon hundreds of very wordy rambling songs just like these and then whittling all of them down to just the best ones I think Benji is so good that it could potentially become one of those gateway drug albums into the rest of Mark's discography in which there are a lot of great records but you know every great artist every once in a while will put out one record that sort of seems to stand tall as a pinnacle and sort of grabs them a whole new fan base I think Benji has tons of charm and tons of appeal even if on the surface it seems like mark is only doing half of the job of what we expect from a singer-songwriter and what we expect is for a singer-songwriter to go through a significant emotional experience and then report back with the most interesting bits and then condense them down into a metaphor that we can relate to comforting us as we move through this journey called life where we have no idea what we're doing instead of this Mark gives us an incredibly comprehensive account of something that may have happened to him or another event of some sort leaving in pieces that may not necessarily be all that interesting or purposeful and then asking the audience to draw some kind of message or metaphor or meaning from it like on the closing track here Ben's my friend where Mark seems to be singing about just having an average day eating out with his girlfriend ordering crab cakes he goes to see the Postal Service play live he's kind of in the midst of this middle-aged funk and I think the song dogs is worth mentioning off of this LP - which seems like a list of every significant sexual experience that Mark had growing up keep in mind much of the time mark is singing these songs with a vocal delivery that only seems a shade or two away from spoken word and all of Mark's words are backed up with very warm classical guitars that nice nylon string sound and very gentle folk rock instrumentation background vocals upright bass drums all feels really tender and sort of rickety and organic and I think overall this LP is really well put together instrumentally there are a lot of parts here musically that that hit me that move me like the dreary vocal harmonies on the track Carissa the Erie harmonized guitar leads at the end of the song Newtown the the booming drums that pop in on the second half of the song dogs the electric piano on the song Jim wise has a really nice slow patient pace to it that sets the tone for the song perfectly the sax on bends my friend stellar and the layers of fluttering guitars that create this beautiful interlude on the end of the song the song remains the same all this instrumentation is a fantastic foundation for the stories on this record which essentially are what captivated me the most they're all heartbreaking they're all thoughtful and and relatable - when given some contemplation like on the track Carissa where he is singing about the sudden death of his second cousin and even though he has very few and faint memories of her he still feels compelled to write a song for her and create some kind of tribute in memory of her and he's singing about her kids and how she died and how his family is grieving oddly enough she passed away in roughly the same way that marks uncle did as well an exploding aerosol can in the trash a story he tells a little deeper into this album on the track truck driver mark tributes his parents beautifully on this record as well with two separate tracks I can't live without my mother's love and I my dad the song about his mother saying he needs her love there he needs her friendship her companionship he defends her and he dreads the day that she's going to pass away and on the track about his father Mark's angle changes a little bit to something more nostalgic where he's singing about all of these life lessons and experiences he had with his dad it's more of a musical portrait of his father and mark's past with his father versus what he gets from his dad right now and all this reminiscing over the past seems really great but these tracks really seem to make sense with the theme of the album and what mark's mindset is when these songs are sort of backed up against tracks like ben's my friend and richard Vermeer's died today of natural causes songs that are mired in a slew of fleeting thoughts and personal musings but are really reflections on one's own mortality via aches and pains and fatigue and sudden death and the song bends my friend in a way is sort of about being in that funk created and caused by all of those things and pushing past it being competitive even the satellite stories on this LP that don't directly play into these themes are fantastic like the song Jim wise which is essentially about a friend of marks fathers who mercy killed his wife and now is sort of under house arrest and will most likely be in jail very soon due to the choice that he made and mark describes Jim wise from beard to ankle bracelet and the song Micah lean is a beautiful little track about three different people in Mark's life over the course of different ages who were only wanting to live like anyone else but for whatever reason they sort of incurred serious misfortune Micah lean herself being disabled mentally one of mark's friends dying suddenly a bit open mark's grandmother being diagnosed with cancer nothing not to make this entire LP just seem like this really depressing terrible awful melancholy thing i mean you know there's definitely sadness on this LP there's definitely moments on here where no matter how old you are you're going to be facing your mortality a little bit on this LP not everyone gets a fair chance in life or a fair shot some people's opportunities are sort of cut short unfortunately but there's something sort of comforting about mark tearing open this middle-aged man thoughts closet and just ripping out all the skeletons he's just getting a lot of things that people actually think and feel and experience out there in the open and again it all feels so relatable and it all feels so real despite mark being so specific with these stories that he's the only person a really experienced or you know saw heard any of it firsthand we're only sort of experiencing it through his lyrics but still oddly enough with a really low-key instrumentation and Mark's rambling very wordy lyrics on this record this LP is one of the easiest hours of music I've ever sat through not a moment did I feel like wow I really want this to be over there there are a few moments on this LP where I wish the vocals were a little bit more intelligible I do wish overall that the instrumentation was a bit more varied that the end of the closing track on here was a bit more final and I do think the song remains the same like the movie itself is just a tad long-winded but still I thought this was a fantastic record and will no doubt be one of my favorites of the year I'm feeling a decent a strong 9 on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Sun Kil moon forever

a song that has a great vocal melody really sweeps me off my feet at the beginning but then it doesn't build on what it started toward the finish musically and compositionally I think tracks like this are just a little too safe and uneventful ptoo because I don't think this album and strong for me the title burn your fire for no witness is a little misleading because I don't feel like this album is this intense lonesome unsuspecting exorcism of emotions instead I think quite a few tracks on this LP production-wise anyway kind of pander to some really uninteresting underground rock trends going on right now and when this record isn't doing that I think it's dousing what little fire has in ice water unfortunately on this LP I felt like there were a lot of songs that were painfully unmemorable hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Shu album Angel guts red classroom it has not been a very long time so we've last heard from long-running art rock experimental rock indie pop in the experimental pop weirdness music outfit Shu Shu toward the end of last year they put out a full-length LP of Nina Simone covers titled Nina which I highly recommend for its raw instrumentation unorthodox approach and very eerie vibe the band just dropped their 9th full-length album right here angel guts red classroom and on this record they go back to their roots a little bit once again making very noisy somewhat tortured post-punk music doing a bit of a 180 on the glitchy and 8-bit sounds that have appeared on their past few albums but this new record from Shu Shu is more than just a rehash of the past it is easily one of the weirdest albums they've ever put out so far it's grotesque it's absurd and incredibly vulgar at times - the instrumentation is kind of stripped back and a little unsettling there are a lot of stiff throbbing drums on this record that for the most part are electronic dissonant synthesizers orser's the vocals here for the most part are really freakish sometimes they reach really highs generally I would say this album is pretty uncomfortable it's difficult to really snuggle in and get cozy with this LP even after multiple listens there are all these rhythms that remind me of of suicide and the vocals on this record as well just like with Shu shus last LP do remind me of Scott Walker a bit there's not a lot of layers to the instrumentation on this record but every piece of sound does serve a very bold and dark purpose like the very shrill synth freak-outs on a knife in the Sun or the pig squealing samples on the track adult friends or the very noisy and explosive vocal samples and manipulations on the track Lawrence lickers all the songs here have their own little thrill to seek and I wouldn't call them cheap thrills but they are sort of just thrills all the same there are some exceptions on here where a melody may stick out of a track or shoe shoe actually delivers a song like stupid in the dark which i think is legitimately one of their catchy it's the most well-written tracks they've ever put out but but a lot of the time what makes these tracks memorable are moments like the very fetishize lyrics in the track black dick or the shrieking vocals on the tracks Cynthia is a unisex or L NACO and the result with tracks like these are songs that I do like a lot and find very interesting and stimulating but there is a good handful of tracks on this record that I do think underwhelm a little but merely because they're not much of anything but freakish short and unstructured tracks that don't really leave a long lasting impression on me especially since they seem to cut out right when the song is at its most intense even some of the songs on here that I really like like adult friends I just wish were a little bit longer and there are some other songs on here that are less abrasive slower more ballad like but are pretty underwhelming as well because they don't have much in terms of structure or a climax or a progression new life immigration or the track bitter melon overall I think this new shoo-shoo record is just kind of a very weird group of vignettes some of which are very good but a lot of the song is here do significantly pale in comparison to others on here still I do think this record is a vast improvement over what Shu Shu has done on their past two original material studio albums I'm feeling a decent of strong seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why Anthony fan Tiano Shu Shu forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new glitch mob album love death immortality these guys are a West Coast electronic music collective who dropped their full-length debut drink the sea just a handful of years ago a bunch of tracks that were a collaborative collection of glitch hop and electronic music hybrids a lot of touches of glitzy sort of Club centric dubstep and dance music on this record the group built these tracks on a lot of very large epic sounds and song structures popular dance music was definitely an influence on many of the tracks here but I thought that much of what glitch mob did on this record was too detailed and complex to be just club music I thought some of the songs on this thing we're pretty headphone worthy as well glitch mob has just put out their second full-length LP love death immortality I've always been pretty neutral on the group until now because this latest full-length LP of theirs I did not like not even a little straight and simple I think this new record from glitch mob is Club fodder it's pretty much nothing but songs that feature melodies that get old before the song is even over and dubstep inspired rhythms that are pretty much dime a dozen there are things on this LP that remind me of other things that I like there are some very bright melodic synth leads that remind me of artists and producers like deadmau5 or rusty there's a lot of rumbling bass on this LP and sporadic drum breaks like on a Skrillex track and there are some very epic grand builds to these songs to that slightly remind me of Daft Punk record or a justice record if you're in all of those artists then you might want to check the selfie out you might come out liking it it does have all the loud visceral sounds that you would want and expect from music in this style pretty detailed drum breaks it does follow that modern electronic dance music blueprint to a tee but I think this record came up short because in the process of doing all those things Glitch Mob forgot to actually add some personality to this music or actually penned melodies that are worth remembering there are some pretty cliche vocal performances on this record as well that do nothing but add to the very generic electro dubstep vibe on this LP and when the group does go for something kind of interesting it only ends up like a watered down version of what could have been like the song can't kill us which has this buzzing bass and drum beats that feel more rock centric and these synth leads that feel almost as if they're kind of going for a guitar type sound I mean it's it's better than what Muse did trying to fuse dubstep and rock together but it only feels like it's interesting in theory this combination of dubstep and rock and the song becoming harmonious with vocals from metal mother was a pretty interesting track for me because about slow and brooding it was and I actually thought that with the very epic and sort of sad synthesizers behind this interesting vocal it was sort of like a combination of the knife and dubstep together tracks like this aren't amazing but they're definitely a welcome change of pace from more average dubstep electro house fusions like sky toucher I think the only track on this entire LP that I wholeheartedly liked was fly by night only which features a vocal guest who's singing reminds me of churches a bit and I wasn't really into this track for the loud and buzzing and bombastic production or anything like that I just thought it was a legitimately good tune that would have sounded catchy and sounded enjoyable no matter what kind of beats are synthesizers you put against it I dub the really tender vocals from sister crayon as well in the plucked harp strings on the closing track here too but the really tiring blasts of bass and drums have gotten old at this point and just prove that this record is not all that dynamic or interesting it just feels like a really taste north north north north mix of these really beautiful vocals and tender instrumentation and then all of a sudden this very loud in your face electro pops in and it's just a really silly transition back and forth and back and forth overall I I thought this new glitch mob LP was offensively uninspiring and uninteresting despite trying to be the exact opposite with how monumental some of these songs feel but pretty much every song on this LP is just too overblown for how unsubstantial the sound play and the songwriting is I'm feeling a decent two strong three on this thing try ambition if you given this wrecker to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony fan tanto Glitch Mob forever
