hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review the new step brothers album Lorde stepping to old steppin tin is a West Coast hip hop duo which consists of seasoned MC and producer evidence aka the weatherman you may know this guy from the handful of solo LPS he's put out over the years as well as his work with groups like dilated peoples and the alchemists a West Coast producer DJ and MC who has a very long running and successful track record has worked with a ton of different artists over the years from huge guys like Eminem to smaller and newer dudes like down-low Genesis and he's actually worked with evidence already numerous times in the past providing instrumentals for his solo LPS as well as various dilated peoples tracks and with The Alchemist recently doing these album length projects with particular artists like damo Genesis and Ono as gangrene and Action Bronson as well as prodigy so it only makes sense that he would go back into his past and do something full-length style with evidence assistants and when I heard of who was gonna be on this project when I heard the name of the project I was and wasn't excited for for several different reasons for one I haven't really loved every project that Alchemist has put out as of late with a single artist in mind and evidence I can kind of take her leave sometimes I'm familiar with his earlier stuff and there are records in his past that I enjoy but man does his voice sound maybe just a little too monotone after a while he's just got a very very icy delivery however I do dig some rock Marciano tracks occasionally I did love that album that Cod just put out last year so maybe there's something to his delivery that will hit me this time around and I'm glad I ended up checking this thing out because the first single to drop off this album step masters awesome track there is a nasty instrumental on this thing really grimy bass rumbles chunky percussion horn samples some really nice DJ cuts everything is on point with this track and I feel like alchemists production just complements evidence so much it's really the fire that complements his so cold stairs the beat on step masters and other tracks here to just make them sound much more eerie and and sort of menacing I think evidences bars are really thoughtful a lot of the time they are occasionally braggadocious they references past and music however lyrically and and delivery wise as well alchemist is a lot less subtle he's more aggressive he's more in-your-face as he's delivering these bars that are loaded with cartoony violence and sort of exaggerated threats and much of the time this dynamic does work it's kind of like a bad cop badder cop thing each MC has their own distinct personality on this LP it's really clear when one takes the reins of a track and one doesn't but I do occasionally feel like alchemist should have done sort of a rewrite on some of these lines the flow brings me more dough than creamy krispies or change your shitty drawers cuz your pants got dumped in sometimes he's talking about the crosshairs on his scope site or saying he's gonna smack someone out of their hoodie sure I just think there are some rhymes on this LP that line up awkwardly and don't really fit with the gritty dramatic tone of the instrumentals or alchemist super serious delivery I mean when I pull lines out of some of his verses and just read them they sound like they would be more fitting for a really kooky trap beat in a riff raff song or something at least then the comedy would have felt intended and you know don't get me wrong sometimes it does like I'm a big boy don't give me no snacks animal head no plate fresh off the axe and there are numerous weird interstitial vocal snippets in between these tracks that bring songs together a little bit there's sort of a weird narrative going on at the end of one particular song where this composer person hears sleigh bells and is amazed by the sound and then begins to travel the world searching for different sleigh bell sounds even though a lot of these songs are tough talking there are plenty of moments on this LP to sort of remind the listener that what's going on here is just sort of for fun I mean album's title is Lord stepping 10 and to me that does sort of create another very small weak link on this record though there are some weak bars on here it's not that distracting but another thing that does underwhelmed me occasionally is the lack of ambition on some of these songs like on the song Byron g-good bars on this track all around very good features as well from hooligans and damo Genesis but this instrumental sounds like a slightly slower rehashed version of the Sylvester Lungren beat that Alchemist gave to Action Bronson for their collaborative project together and the song tomorrow - two good features from blue and raka but another instrumentally underwhelming track with all of these really dinky synthesizers playing throughout the song the track to me gets kind of redundant and as 1mc trades places with another it doesn't really feel like the beat is showcasing or complimenting any one of them whereas I think this track like others on here such as swim-team Rastas could have done a better job of throwing these verses up on a pedestal Plus this entire LP is bookended with two of the weaker tracks structurally weak I mean four won the opener more wins it has a really smooth tone I love the beat but it's not really that much of a barn burning or interesting start to the album it's pretty short of breath and so is the last track on here - just step which is such a footnote of a song I'm surprised it ends the album out I actually think Lorde stepping to deliver Zitz most unique hard-hitting and exciting tracks right in the middle of the LP like with the song legendary mesh which has this trunk knocking beat really murky kind of psychedelic bassline lots of guitar solo samples and a plethora of sound effects just dancing around in the mix playing throughout the instrumental and I think this song actually features one of evidences best verses on the entire LP and in his lyrics as well as the vocally sampled hook on this track they're tons of A Tribe Called Quest references and the beats get even bigger than this one like on swim-team Rastas a beat that actually undergoes two instrumental changes over the course of its runtime and the song really changes moods every single time the beat shifts and lyrically I think this one of the few moments on this LP where Alchemist is actually on the same level as evidence and is actually saying some stuff that is not as overly blunt its tracks like this that made me wish the step brothers were this ambitious on every single track here though there are some songs that do impress me because they have a lyrical concept sort of running throughout them like see the rich man play which has all these references to casinos and gambling as well as draw something this LP gets super aggressive on one of the next tracks here mums in the garage one of the most hard-hitting instrumentals on this entire LP and some of the most aggressive verses as well there is a feature from Action Bronson on this track too but what surprises me even more is the track banging sound which has one of the most off-kilter rap instrumentals that I am positively sure you will hear all year I mean it's mostly based off of this drum fill it seems that is just not in a very fluid groove but guys like evidence on this track just ride the beat without flinching even for a second I mean listening to this instrumental I just had the feeling that he's the sort of guy that you know a grenade could go off somewhere near him and he wouldn't even flinch and I love how noisy and layered the instrumentation is on this b2 with the chimes and the strings and all the vocal harmonies too and for the most part I love all the instrumentals and the the lyrics that come along with the more subtle tone down tracks - they have a really strong moody vibe this LP does offer quite a bit of instrumental variety I think even if evidence and alchemists start changing their flows or their lyrical styles up too much on this record though I don't really think they need to I mean they've got a solid flows they've got personality they've got their sort of distinct voices my only major complaint with this record is that there were just a few tracks at the beginning and at the end that I wasn't that crazy about I actually loved a great deal of the tracks on this thing and could see myself returning to this LP in the future I do think this record is still kind of an acquired taste it has very little in the way of pop appeal but the beats are spectacular I feel like they pair really well with the very relaxed flows and I feel like overall these guys couldn't have gotten a better set of features here - this thing is just a really great mixed bag of tracks I'm feeling a strong seven - a light eight transition if you've given this up he'll listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana stepbrothers murmur

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new behemoth album the Satanist kaljaa chesta you stop that right now this instant making silly growling noises and devil horns is patronizing to metal fans hey the more you know they really do prefer that you go to my knowledge behemoth is the most infamous metal band to come out of Poland they've been active since the early 90s back when their records had a pretty old-school slightly run-of-the-mill black metal sound the songs on these records were pretty low five filled with archaic melodies and even though there was a lot of punch to these albums in this part of behemoths career there was something kind of charming about how the compositions on these records felt centuries old now as the band's recording quality got better with every new LP they started bringing in elements of death metal the band went even further down this road coming together with a string of metal records in the early 2000s that to me were just straight death metal though personally I've never really been a big fan of these albums I do think that at this point in behemoths career the band was sounding really savage and loud but they didn't have much in the way of memorability or finesse but this latest LP the sameness comes five years after the release of behemoths previous album Evangelion which I believe is the largest time gap in between behemoth records which may have something to do with the fact that the band's frontman and guitarist primary songwriter Nergal was actually diagnosed with leukemia and has fought it and recovered since maybe that had something as well to do with the change of pace that behemoth takes on this LP musically the Satanist is easily one of the eiements most ambitious and dynamic records yet and their black metal influences come back in a big way really dark melodies shine through these massive walls of blast beats and tremolo guitars and there's some pretty epic arranged instrumentation added to the mix on this LP as well with horns being the most stunning and exciting a the vocals on this LP are still pretty gruff not a huge change from the band's earlier output if you've been listening to their death metal releases but I do think the singing on this LP is a lot more raw definitely a huge improvement over the more barbaric on records like here and beyond and there's some variety on these tracks to some left hooks here and there like on the track in the absence of light which has this polish spoken word interlude on it with a very distant sax solo hanging in the background there's missing noir we're right at the start of the track I can hear the vocals just cracking with intensity as they're being delivered right at the start of the song on pong then there is the closer which has these really harmonious background vocals just erupting in the background just bringing this song's emotional qualities to just a higher level of intensity it's so beautiful the production on this LP too is fantastic I can't really find a complaint about it the the drums are punchy the guitars are loud but they're not overpowering the vocals as well the guitar tone is is very bright it's burning the bass is a little obscure but when the band is playing riffs it really does seem to to shine out a little bit though bass has never really been a lead instrument in black metal music it's not really a huge loss the metal instrumentation on this record creates a huge wall of sound but there's just enough room left over for just a touch of reverb a little bit of atmosphere and all the additional instrumentation when and if the band decides to use it the brass the strings the organ the chorus vocals and whenever stuff like this pops in it doesn't really ruin the vibe of the song to me it always adds to the very grim and hellish quality of this album for a straight black metal record the songs on this LP are really grand I mean there's nothing on here that is quite as epic or symphonic as let's say an early Emperor record but I like that behemoth was able to find a really satisfying compromise between subtlety and force and the entire album itself actually plays with this dynamic with tracks like fer de vinius as well as ahmen which has one of the most freakish endings on this entire LP with these layered vocals and just such a loud wall of guitars but me personally I mostly prefer the songs on here that have a stronger melodic element like missing noir and there are tracks on this LP too that I think are catchy I mean behemoth really tried to write some strong choruses on a few of these tracks moments on here like the title track and or a pro nobis Lucifer that track has a really sort of unashamed rock guitar solo on here I do like that behemoth is so dark and is so intense on this record but I think bringing in elements of just you know straightforward rock and roll elements of more accessible shades of metal music does sort of show that behemoth does want a visceral response from their listeners as well and I have to mention that I do think there are some very sticky and memorable and enjoyable guitar leads that play throughout these two tracks too I think the Satanist finishes off pretty well too with three very dynamic tracks especially the closer which is one of the best on the entire LP and the longest song - I mean it just feels like such such a final moment on this LP it feels like such an accomplished finish for this record which is a relatively short LP I mean it's just about 45 minutes long it's not really going to overstay its welcome or anything like that my only major issues with this album overall is that the two shorter tracks on here while they are very good songs they do move at such a pace that they were a little bit of a blur on some of my initial listens to this album outside of that I really loved the selfie even lyrics which I think some people may have issues with seeing that they could easily sort of shove them into the corner for being a black metal cliche with all this satanic content however I don't think what behemoth did on this record was write a really tasteless spit in the face toward God and religion I'm not saying this record isn't sacrilegious it is I took the lyrics on this LP as being more allegory more of a narrative more of a character portrait of Satan himself in some instances another thing that I could see people potentially getting down on with this LP is how progressive it isn't this record is definitely not as experimental as some of the really weird black metal fusions that we've been seeing these days with rock and roll progressive rock post rock shoegaze industrial music but I think behemoth does a fantastic job of justifying their more straightforward approach on this blackened death metal record with some very good strong solid memorable writing great sound great vocals very good performances intensity some fantastic drum fills and just a really concise record with a good amount of variety that flows well from beginning to end I think that behemoth really lived up to their name on this record I'm feeling a light night on this thing transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana behemoth the Satanist forever

incredibly steady beat the song modest or menthol or r.i.p Kevin Miller but I do like these tracks but only because of what were shot brings to the table lyrically and flow wise as well these are some of his most impassioned tracks I think these songs have some of the stickiest hooks on this entire project too but the hooks are a totally different story they tend to be just as hit or miss as the instrumentals hooks that are real honest-to-god snoozers that feature either were shot or another vocalist singing so inconspicuously that you might as well just tune out until the next verse comes around like on Webby whoa and menthol and to a lesser extent Ronnie Drake though I do like that trach scissors very fragile vocals on this song do sort of pull me in though I do feel that that may not course that sort of puts assassins and leaders up against one another as being in this sort of symbiotic relationship with God and Jesus and Brutus and Caesar and though I do like this track one of my favorites on here is one of the songs that just kind of cuts the fat just glosses over the choruses and brings a hard beat with very serious tone the song soliloquy this song is one of the few moments of excitement that I feel that this project brings there are a lot of songs on this thing that I do think brings sort of a stoned aesthetic and while sometimes that does lead to Rashaad kind of letting go of his inhibitions being really over-the-top and energetic but too often I think the other tracks on this thing are a little middle-of-the-road which keeps Rashad from digging deeply into a well thought-out concept or idea or theme in a song Rashad keeps hitting me with one surface-level expression after another I think that this project is not hyped enough for a party or feel-good atmosphere but yet it's not thoughtful enough to be dug into that deeply it's sort of hops back and forth between the two a little bit doing neither and incredibly well for that long I do think the hi everyone amp tummy fan tango here the Internet's busiest music nerd and now it's time for a letter from a fan dear anthem my name is Tommy banglar and I've been watching your reviews for a very long time you're my favorite reviewer and sometimes me and my friends play bad review where we take turns giving new albums decent fives and then scream homophobic slurs at each other when we disagree there is so precious I know you just did classics week and it was great but you know the really big influential album you reviewed that week the one everyone likes well I don't like it at all I keep listening to it but I don't get it I've heard it 20 times and I just can't seem to enjoy it no matter how hard I try everyone at school makes fun of me my dad fails to acknowledge me as his son my mom wonders where she went wrong what do i do Anthony please help me like this album tommy banglar aka the & Co Oh hmm Tommy music is one of the most popular art forms there is and I think because of that the art form suffers from a lot of trendy BS that other art forms don't at least not to the same degree certain albums and certain artists might get all this acclaim and might get all this hype and and this can create some pressure to jump on the bandwagon and like whatever everybody else is liking but you're not going to like what's classic and what's popular all the time and that's because you're human this is okay this is not a big deal you should try to be as open as you possibly can to different genres especially the biggest ones out there but but but but but not enjoying specific albums in these genres is perfectly natural even if these albums do happen to be wildly popular just try to listen to the music understand why you don't like it understand why it might be popular and why it might appeal to other people so much and if it's a new LP that you're having a hard time enjoying then you know just don't try to force it let it hang just sort of wait until the album has a few years grown on to it and see if it becomes classic into the distant future and if that ends up being the case then try it at that point in time and maybe then it'll appeal to you there's always a chance that something might end up sounding better to you further much further down the road of life not like six months down the road of life not even like a year down the road of life and if other people can't understand that and still hate you for your musical preferences they're probably human garbage anyway transition listen to whatever you want to listen to like whatever you want to like don't feel like you have to like something if you don't enjoy something like I said just try to understand why you don't enjoy it and that's it liking music Anthony Fantan Oh Tommy banglar forever

is the catchiest song on the entire LP maybe because the refrain is repeated so liberally but lyrically it's not really one of the more gripping songs that young fathers have have pulled together there's only one real track on here that I outright disliked and really let me down and that's mm-hmm a song that moves into really strange sonic territory with an abstract song structure and is really spacious and just does not end up engaging because of that you know majority of the songs on here aren't terrible but they just don't go that step further to really wow me there are some songs on here though where I really do love the lyrical imagery like on dip and no way and especially low did I see you planting seeds in the forest is it for the green or the dollars now don't go telling me it's for the needs of the poorest now I'm going to take a shit in your palace the imagery on the song war is really vivid as well and am I not your boy is a sort of interesting song that seems to be written with a mother in mind and it's sort of confessional in a way telling her that the boy that you once were is dead now many of the songs do have gripping nice characteristics and I think young fathers have maintained their personality over the course of making this album as well I mean there aren't any groups out there that I can really name that have a sound quite like young fathers but the biggest hindrance to this LP is that there's just not a lot of variation to these the better sound and the better singing on this LP do balance out what I don't like about it in a sense but really dead is a step down for me in terms of memorability and enjoyability I'm feeling a light to decent six on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why did you feel either and what should I review next young fathers dead forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new actress album ghetto ville this is the 4th full-length release from actress aka Darren Jai Cunningham a uk-based electronic music producer I enjoyed the really minimal stripped-down approach that he took to genres like house and techno on his earliest LPS but he sort of lost me a bit on his last full-length album r.i.p an LP that showed Darren's sound moving into some really abstract territory and stringing together a series of tracks that weren't exactly cohesive as an album to me and obviously having an album that was really uniform and style and sound was not the goal of this LP instead Darren seemed to focus a lot more on trying to explore as many sounds textures and moods as possible and there's nothing inherently wrong with a disjointed record but it's the track specifically that didn't end up grabbing me on this LP some of which I found to meander a little bit too much were maybe a little bit too skeletal just weren't putting out anything sonically that was gripping to me I think actresses scatterbrained approach ends up working out for him on this new record though it's sort of a strong change in feeling for me I mean after listening to this record I'm sort of seeing actress in more of the same light as artists like Autechre or Flying Lotus but to me they're only similar in the sense that they make electronic music that is rhythmically driven and is filled with relentless sonic experimentation and another thing that shocked me about this record is how instantaneous it was for me I know that there are a lot of weird ambient abstract challenging sounds on here but even after one listen to this thing I couldn't help but find it really dark moody and gratifying to me this record is simultaneously genre embracing and genre deform an album that shows its influences very obviously but takes that manipulates them twists them into something where it's difficult to tell where something is coming from where something is going away it's cool to see this dude take something as simple as the parameters of house music and break them down and build them back up with dusty drumbeats and textures that remind me of things like asphalt concrete moonlit nights cold hard steel some of the tracks hear loud they're hard-hitting they have strong grooves others are a little bit more ambient and style but still feature some really strange and vivid sounds that that have a really strong sense of place each one of the 16 tracks on this LP has their own unique personality that I could go into pretty deep detail describing it all together these songs spans 70 minutes the song bird cage has this insanely stiff loud and robotic hi-hat kick drum pattern there's a breathy vocal sample on this track some deep bass and I love the sharp sounds of the drums on this track and the track switches back and forth between these robotic drum beats and these drum fills that seem a little foreign with these cheery woodwinds synth leads dancing on top of them I love hearing these really lively pieces of percussion mixed with just this hard-nosed techno beat the opener on this LP also a song that I love incredibly slow a beat that really lurks it's heavy with bass and there's all these stretched out fizzling ride cymbals that play on top of it - there's some icy scents on this track some metallic chimes that just ring out eerily it's a great atmosphere to kick this record off with but it does require some patience because it is a long track it is a track that doesn't exactly come out and bite you I'm sure this song is going to scare away as many people as it pulls in there's another track on here that I love that also hits a super slow stride the song contagious the beat on this song it sounds like a train a coal engine train from Hell just pulling out of the station to bring its passengers to a lifetime of Tom ends and after a lifetime and the really muffled deep slow vocal cuts on this track lead me to believe that these rhythms might just be a part of some larger sample from somewhere else taking what could potentially be just sort of a sexy slow jam and playing at this slow is kind of vaporwave but to me actress takes it one step further by surrounding this track with some really ominous rhythms and synthesizers where actresses take on this sort of budding genre gets a little old as on the song rap where to me the song doesn't feel much more like just a sample of a song sort of played and looped and chopped and whatnot actress does a good job of catching that vaporwave vibe but the song is a little underwhelming on the detail side there's some tracks on this LP that have a gentler side of sorts like the track hour which with these really light light rhythms and these just sparkling thumb piano melodies I'm reminded a bit of people like Pantha new prints or bonobo or the song time which while it isn't really a heavy track it is an incredibly eerie song with a very sour drone hanging in the background with some very tense high hats playing in the foreground there's some odd synthesizer keys that play on this track too and longer this song goes the more frightening it is and some of the tracks on this LP display a somewhat goofier side of actress as well like the song corner which is a bit of slow paced synthesizer funk with these melodic leads that are played so awkwardly over this groove it's kind of hilarious and they're really just overbearing heavy bassline is really what makes this track and the song rims - with these sort of weird upward and downward sliding lead melodies on the track it sounds a little silly it's got these gurgling bass lines as well and I do like the track even if it is less impressive than a lot of the other songs on here my favorite tracks on this LP is where actors might approach just a really simple house 4/4 rhythm with a pretty experimental flare like the really murky track front line where it seems like he tries to strip back as much treble as possible with some pretty nice bass lines on this song - and then there's skyline which is incredibly minimal it's glitchy and there are some weird metallic drones hanging in the background of this track - and I love gays which is maybe the most accessible melodic and celebratory track on this entire album really great undeniable beat with some incredibly bright sense and there are also songs on here that of course contrast this brightness this upbeat attitude in a great way like the song Street Corp which is so robotic with its off-kilter rhythm that it feels like I'm listening to some kind of machine whose job it is to just crank away on some assembly line day-in and day-out the track seems so simple in concept but to me it it says a lot I love a majority of the tracks on this album even if overall the LP is a little scatterbrained and you know at the end of the day this is a record that perfectly reflects its cover art in that it feels sort of like a musical sketchbook something I think the album r.i.p was as well but that album was masquerading as something that was a little bit more refined and was a little bit too reserved because of that get oval nose it's a personal indulgence it does not hide that and it ends up bolder and more intimate because of that even if some of the bridges on this LP lead to nowhere even if there are some tracks on here that do feel a little redundant or inconsequential overall I ended up loving the experience I had with this pretty jarring set of tracks I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think as your review knows and that's it Anthony Fantana actress get oval forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and in this video I'm going to review the new have a nice life record the unnatural world have a nice life is a Connecticut basic music duo featuring Dan Barrett and Timucua they have been active on and off since 2000 and their music has earned this incredibly passionate cult following that's slowly been growing since 2008 that's when the duo dropped their 85-minute powerhouse of a double album death consciousness it is not a record that made a huge splash initially but it is still a sonic Titan that thinks nothing of violently slashing apart drone noise post-punk industrial rock and shoegaze and then reassembling them into an uncompromising lead Ark set of songs with pretty tongue-in-cheek song titles a quick one before the eternal worm devours Connecticut waiting for black metal records to come in the mail to me track titles like this are a bit of an emotional defense mechanism of sorts after exercising songs that have so many legitimately tortured moments in them I imagine that the first thing you want to do is kind of shrug it off but even though Dan and Tim moved on past this record artistically through other collaborative projects and bands and solo efforts it is death consciousness that has continued to be their most popular record to date I can only imagine following this record up could be a really daunting task could be really intense but at least for me personally the pressure isn't so immense considering that I've been tuning into a lot of these other projects that the Dan and Tim have been involved in and to me a lot of these projects carry a lot of similarities to have a nice life the darkness the lo-fi recordings the dissonance and plus there's all the bands that Dan supports through his record label enemies list home recordings and even though he doesn't involve himself in any of these projects I believe artistically a lot of the bands that he puts out sort of seemed to be musical kindred spirits in a way abusing noise and reverb and genre boundaries and their releases as well and that joyous tradition continues on to this new have a nice life record as well an LP that is noticeably shorter than its predecessor about 40 minutes shorter which is a bit of a disappointment at first glance but I do think Dan and Tim have pulled together a sonically mature record with the unnatural world putting out some of their most vivid and dismal sounds yet the songs on this record have a loud booming depressive impact yet so many of the details are smudged obscured and purposefully hidden by loads of effects and really weird mixing practices think the microphones Mount Erie record but with a goth rock obsession and way less disregard for readability for me this is lo-fi indie rock that was written for the end of the world and has the oppressive volume of a doom metal record and this heaviness swallows the songs that have a nice life creates it's like they're trying to drown out their own self created musical apocalypse if there's anything that's sort of a positive of the unnatural world just being about 48 minutes it is that it makes have a nice life a little more digestible this time around and I feel like this record is more focused as well the songs here tend to range from really noisy post-punk barnburners to incredibly droney ballads and I think have a nice life has success on both sides of the spectrum one of my favorite hard-hitting tracks off of this LP defenestration song as this driving distorted bass line cavernous drums and just a really thick cocoon of tones and noises surrounding all of it the vocals are tucked away in this haze of sound but it makes the melodies that they're singing no less catchy and their passion still rings through as well as you're getting these really fiery screams and shouts coming out of the background I just love the growing sea of dissonance on this track as it progresses I really dig the track dan and Tim reunited by fate as well the song is cut from the same dismal post-punk cloth and has this bassline that doesn't feel like it would be out of place in some kind of 90s alternative rock tune the track starts off with a great groove but in Stanly the song is smothered in this really warped wall of tones that I just cannot describe is it synthesizers is it guitars I have really no idea all I know is that the explosion of this sound is so just sudden that it feels like being plunged into a frigid pool of water I love the dismal guitar interlude in the second half of this track and the song slowly just depletes in sound and just sort of gives up on itself by the end not in a disappointing way but in a way that sort of reflects the depression that is so palpable in most of these tracks then there's the track unholy life another more upbeat hard-hitting rhythmic song on this album but one of the most emotionally neutral tracks as well with this sort of strung out twangy guitar line that kicks the track off that sounds somewhat like a Beach fossil song I think the only thing keeping this track from being a Beach fossil song is how it grows so noisy and dissonant as it moves along a lot like the track defenestration song which to me is so Joy Division so Bauhaus but to me that track is long enough the melody is catchy enough for me to just okay this is a this is a unique atmosphere this is an interesting song unholy life however is just way too short of breath for me to be impressed with it as its own sort of composition it feels like a bit of a cliffhanger to me and unfortunately there are other songs on here that do give us somewhat similar vibe as well songs that build things to a really impressive crescendo or have a great sound but sort of fizzle out into a really unimpressive close for one the track burial Society which I love up until the mid point where we're getting all these falsetto which really take me out of the mood of the song unfortunately and after these vocals come and leave the songs coast downward is is pretty underwhelming and the track music will on tune the sky to some really beautiful droning guitars on this track with some soaring vocals over them and it's it's really a blissful moment on this album that is a bit of a breath of fresh air from all the darkness I love the guitar tone I love the ringing bells on this track but I wish it went more places compositionally there were tracks that I really did love on the drone e'er side of this record though like Guggenheim Wax Museum the intro of this album and the last song to Guggenheim is one of the most powerful crescendos on this entire album I love the blaring guitar solo toward the finish - and the song works really effectively as an introduction to this LP as well and glides into the next song very nicely and the closing track on here really one of the most dynamic songs on this entire album the longest song on this entire album - takes its time growing a mood growing the drone building the tension it really puts me into an emotional state before it floats away into the abyss assist and I've got to mention the song corpsey as well another track that does a great job of taking its time to set a mood starts things off with some really depressing vocal cuts of an interview with a child who was living at Pennhurst asylum and sort of talking about why he was being punished there and whether or not he liked it there and so on and so forth and I love the guitar riffs on this track and how they switch back and forth between this loud and louder sounds I just wish a natural world dabbled in dynamic tracks like this just a little bit more still despite that complaint I did end up loving a majority of the tracks on here but part of me does wish that there was a massive timespan to this record to match the massive sounds and massive emotions I do have some love for this LPM feeling a strong 7 to like 8 on this record transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next man for the love of for the love of God have a nice life the unnatural world forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new an autumn for crippled children review try not to destroy everything you love this is the 4th full-length LP that hails from an experimental metal outfit that hails from the Netherlands they've been dropping a new album every year since 2010 this band started as a really depressive black metal outfit with a super noisy and claustrophobic recording and even though that recording style has stuck with them on each new release that hasn't really stopped them from experimenting with sound and additional instrumentation like strings and scents the strings played an especially big role on their last full-length LP and I think these guys have grown compositionally as well writing songs that are a lot less dismal this record is pretty rich with melody melodies that are triumphant occasionally or even pretty and sweet on the ear despite the recording in the end the vocals on top of this instrumentation being so harsh typically I don't really mind the grading harsh wretched black metal vocal style but I do wish the singing brought some more variety to the table on this record and I wish it wasn't so buried in the mix on numerous songs here too but still how claustrophobic the recording on this record is it brings a bit of a unique challenge it's interesting to see how Magnum of an opus the band can pack into such a tiny space with guitars and drums and vocals and strings and since all clashing against one another violently however it's not like the mix or the way this recording was assembled is messy the band makes room for essential sounds when they need to like the wispy string melodies that pop in on the song never complete as soon as those introduce themselves it seems that everything else is absolutely quiet so that you can hear the theme melody that they are introducing and even though the sound of this track is really low Phi it doesn't stop this musical moment from feeling so huge and cinematic it's like watching autumn leaves fall dramatically in slow motion as someone who you've loved so much for a good chunk of your life is walking away into the distance some tracks here features some really innocent chiming piano chords that kicks the song off and and really sets a fragile tone like on the song sepia mountains for her lament these pianos play through the introduction until basically a wall of guitars comes down and crushes them after which the band moves through all these slow fuzzy guitars and I think with how beautiful and delicate and grainy some of the sounds are on this record a lot of people are going to hear what's going on with this LP and compare instantly to the latest LPS from deafheaven or I'll say and I do think these albums have common ground I think they could share common fans but I also think that an autumn for crippled children finds a way to make themselves stick out in this lighter shade of black metal we've been seeing lately why a lot of tracks on this LP deliver some epic builds that that tug at the heartstrings not a single song on this album goes over the six-minute mark over all the songs on this release are pretty straightforward direct and to-the-point and these guys pack just about as much detail into their songs as the other two artists I just mentioned but they stick so passionately to that Lofa aesthetic and I think this band actually experiments a little bit more with genre then it would seem simply on the surface of these tracks - for example with a really strong icy sense in the driving bass and drum groove on the opening track here the only thing that is stopping the song from being a post-punk track are the vocals there are a lot of moments on this LP though that drink from that black gaze Punchbowl as well really thick walls of instrumentation swirling into itself really dreamy harsh but seductive and the band manages to build the tension really high with guitars strings keyboards and drums just playing more and more intensely as the track moves along songs like the woods are on fire and never complete and these tracks feature some really memorable melodies - however I do get let down a little bit by some of the songs here when I feel like the track maybe cycling through sort of a stereotypical post-rock build or chord progression with a lot of blobby syrupy instrumentation that feels a little formless it's a bit like a build that go to nowhere it's a bill that loses its flavor about halfway up the escalation issues like this create a bit of a dry spell in the middle of the LP for me but the album does pick up again with song closer the song that features these slowly ascending guitar leads that are tremolo picked going up and up against these thunderous drum beats eventually these harmonized whaling guitars sort of scream into the mix and create a really nice change of pace and even though I like tracks like this that are constantly moving upward and onward I do wish there were some more songs here that were just more direct and visceral and aggressive and immediate like the opening track on here I can't help but feel like on the whole this album is just one bill that leads to another bill that leads to another bill which isn't necessarily a bad thing especially if the instrumentation is played well I mean after all that deafheaven record that came out recently does sort of seem to thrive off of that formula as well but with the builds and the instrumentation being raised so high on this record right here and the low-fiber cording just crushing it to such a low it does dampen a little bit of the excitement of the potential excitement all too often I think the the haziness of the recordings on this LP leave some of these songs feeling just a little too Sammy Sammy even if the sound is very appealing to an extent even if a lot of the melodies on this thing are really catchy I dug this record a lot I do think these guys could be a band to watch as far as this musical style goes I'm feeling a light a decent seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next the heat forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Indian album from all purity Annie what's going on with your tip over there here it's not a big deal it's just hair well it's on your head too we're we're we're Indian is a metal outfit from Chicago this is their fifth full-length LP their second for relapse records I first heard of these guys back in 2011 through their previous full-length LP guiltless and album that showed a huge jump in recording quality from Indians old stuff and their newer stuff the band took their already booming and abrasive sound and made it heavier and more hard-hitting and this larger grander scope in fidelity also allowed them to experiment more with melody and noise too now anything in Indian songs that might be the least bit catchy or accessible is only ever a side dish too brittle harsh guitar distortion that's melted in with the bass guitar which is incredibly heavy and these two instruments are fused together to the point where the guitars just create this pummeling white noise wall of sound a lot of Indians tracks have some really primal drums wretched black metal influenced vocals that are very throaty and disgusting yeah and all of these things are played at a tick or two slower than they were on Indians previous LPS the band really sought out to create this harsh overbearing atmosphere that slowly scratches away at what little hope you have left for the world and it works the most notable change in pace on this record in terms of Indians sound is their use of noise a lot of tracks here make use of additional effects and just ear piercing sounds making the six tracks here incredibly unpleasant to listen to and I definitely would not call Indians previous records easy-listening and they are one of those bands that slowly fine Tunes their own record to record but if there is any one element that you can pull out of this album and say whoa this is where they're headed it is with just a noise torch held high even the track clarify on this record is this four minute and 30 second noise interlude with all of these harsh tones and pieces of distortion and just dissonance creating this putrid landscape while vocals are thrown on top it's very hellish and as vile and as disgusting and as unsettling as some of the tracks are on here they reach this level of nastiness that is kind of inspiring like on the track directional which behind the very huge monolithic riffs that play in the foreground there are walls of distortion and feedback screaming away in the background and as the track progresses some of this noise hanging back there gets kind of glitchy and keep in mind the riff that is playing in the foreground it does not change up in a significant way as the track progresses this is a very mind-numbing soul-crushing song there are slight changes of pace from track to track like on the song the impetus bleeds which is easily the most melodic song in this entire LP a bit of doom metal with some very sad mournful guitar leads it reminds me a little bit of that pallbearer album that dropped a few years back and even though the song is incredibly harsh I do think the very sad sad guitar playing and chord progressions on this track do make it a little more digestible and then there's the track rhetoric of no which is easily the most visceral exciting hard-hitting song in this entire LP you really picks up the pace in the tempo a little bit and deliver some riffs that really you can Bob your head to but with how aggressively this song starts it should be no surprise that the ending of this song is one of the most ear-splitting moments on this entire album and then there's the finale on here disambiguation a track that I wish lasted a little bit longer I wish didn't cut off so abruptly the album overall is 40 minutes long and with something that really kind of tries to draw your lifeforce away from you very slowly I do wish it was shit but she added ten minutes of soul-sucking misery either way this is one of the most extreme tracks on this entire LP with the song the riffs the noise getting louder and harsher and just ooh just every bar that passes by the song just incrementally gets more and more and more the riffs just get heavier and heavier there's some black metal style melodies that sort of introduced themselves in the second half of this song - I like that on this song and some others here too like the opener as well Indian does manage to take some of these very very harsh songs and just raise the heat on them so slowly that you don't even realize it's happening unless you compare the end of one song to the beginning of one song and while that doesn't sound all that pleasurable in theory and I'm not promising that everybody is going to like what Indian has to offer on this record it does create a certain emotional or auditory sensation that I find to be very powerful very disturbing in a way overall what Indian does on this record is take doom metal fuse it with Noise music for an incredibly hideous set of songs what I'm hearing on this record really reminds me of the music of bands like I hate God but push to a more dismal and grating extreme and while a lot of the sounds on this record do make me wince I simultaneously have a bit of a morbid infatuation with what goes on with this record as well I do think some people will have issues with this record seeing it as being redundant or kind of OneNote and that's fine there are no rays of sunshine that peaked through the clouds but personally I wish there was a bit more diversity on this thing a bit more experimentation maybe Indian could let go of some of their metal roots and sort of dive more wholeheartedly into Noise music or see what space could actually do you know sort of leaving moments of quiet in the midst of their very hard-hitting songs and see what that does for making for a very jarring auditory experience because they were seeking to do anything it was that something jarring I am feeling a light to decent 8 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Indian forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Mogwai LP rave tapes these guys are a famed instrumental rock band this is their eighth studio full-length LP an album that I was anticipating even though I forgot to put it on my anticipated albums of 2014 list but I was anticipating this LP because I did enjoy the band's last full-length LP so much hardcore will never die but you will Mogwai his music for the most part has always been herded into the post rock genre a mostly instrumental brand very dramatic rock music they are also considered to be one of the originators of the genre however the band never really felt the need to stick to the confines the borders of this genre that were sort of set in stone after they put out such defining albums like young team and happy songs were happy people and come on die young the band's drive to experiment has always kept their next album interesting but I haven't always been in love with every release that Mogwai has put out and recently what seems to be the direction of Mogwai sound as they've been stepping away from some of the drawn-out builds and really heavy loud crescendos that they're most known for simplifying their tracks making them a lot more direct straightforward and to the point like on the 2008 LP the hawk is howling however I don't really think Mogwai succeeded in this direction until they came out with hardcore will never die however this particular LP also saw the band bringing another change into the fold as well and that is electronics and since things that are definitely not strangers and MOG wise music but the emphasis on these things felt so much larger on this LP especially with some of the tracks on here that felt almost crapped rock influenced and to me rave tapes is just another part of this ongoing transition and even though Mogwai is still definitely making rock music the synthesizers seem to be what really gives this album direction especially on the first few tracks here even though there are some very prominent since in the mix on a lot of these songs though I wouldn't really say that Mogwai is coming from a different place compositionally on this record they're still at this point in their career where they are writing these rock tunes that they are too loud to be ambient they're too allowed to just be background music however they move it's such a slow glacial pace I would never call them exciting or explosive the music here are slow it's it's repetitive and maybe that is going to cause some people to tune out understandably but I also think these tracks in a way are hypnotic they are seductive plus I do think these songs have a strong sense of emotion too I can really feel moods coming from these tracks that are beautiful epic uplifting or even bleak and dismal and depressing and even though I do feel these moods coming from these tracks they can be a little ambiguous to some of these songs feeling like a mix of all of these feelings all these emotions just brought together into these very very patient songs that to me are just like this very aggressive tranquility like the opening track on here heard about you last night a song that has these delayed chime synthesizers that ring out really beautifully in these gently wailing guitars soaring over some very slowly moving bass and drum grooves it's legitimately relaxing music however it's not terribly memorable and I think the obvious reaction to this song and a lot of songs on here is well why don't they play faster why isn't the play more lively why isn't it louder why isn't it just more and while I do feel that way to an extent I also don't want Mogwai to abandon their very clear relaxation mission because I do think they're on the cusp of making music that is very gentle on the ears is very soft but is also engaging and incredibly enjoyable even though every song on here isn't exactly Wow I do think that Mogwai does bring some variety to the table the song SIMON ferocious is one of the noisier tracks on here faintly psychedelic with its wailing wall of guitars and the song features these really rough saw tone bass sense as well that sort of buzz and gurgle their way through the track and the closing track on here which has vocoder vocals on it also something Mogwai has done before but this track does feel a little refreshing in that it is the most electronic song in this entire album some of the drums in the background feel like they're synthetically generated and the since really take the wheel on this track to songs like this ride the border between blissful and mundane so hard that it actually blurs the lines between the both of them a little bit and even though I really admire what songs like this are aiming for the tracks on here that are going for something completely different are the ones that I admire and remember the most like the song reamer dird which feels like something that could come out of a progressive synthesizer rock album soundtrack for some sort of sci-fi film from decades ago if you're into the music of goblin or zombie I could definitely see you enjoying this track and then there's the song MasterCard which has these really sharp shrill rhythm guitars that grab my attention right from the start it's got a great groove and for a song this slow there's a lot of force to it there's a lot of power to it it takes me back to Mogwai albums like mr. beast the only major letdown for me on this LP was the song repeal --is-- a very moody instrumental rock song with this vocal snippet of a guy talking about subliminal satanic messages in Led Zeppelin's Stairway to Heaven which in concept sounds like a very epic idea but when this guy talks it feels like he's giving an oral report in front of his classmates at some Catholic school that he's enrolled in overall I think rave tapes is a decent release for Mogwai not quite as underwhelming as the hawk is howling but nowhere near one of my favorites of theirs I admire what they're doing with the sense and the electronics on this LP but I do think some of the songwriting is a little lackluster forgettable the fact that a lot of the songs on this LP are so reserved does sort of make it a mood album and it's not like mood albums don't already exist in mod wise discography however for an LP that is so driven by emotion I don't find it to be particularly moving and that's all I'm feeling a light a decent six on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Mogwai forever

mmm hi everyone Anthony Tanna here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new against me LP trans gender dysphoria blues this is the latest full-length LP from Florida rock band against me a group who rocked me to my core when I was in college with records like reinventing Axl Rose and their acoustic EP and disco before the breakdown and crime a lot of these records featured a blend of folk music punk music a narco politics delivered with incredibly passionate vocals and poetic lyrics and even though against me had some really rough recordings in the early years once the year 2000 2001 2002 came around they hit this musical stride that was incredibly captivating to people who were still searching for a counterculture message in contemporary music the music here felt Punk it felt rebellious it felt like it was standing for something without sounding like just another 80s hardcore knockoff and of course it also helped that the songs on these records were really well written they were incredibly catchy lyrically they dealt with the world at large but they were also very personal as well talking about things like love or lack of confidence or personal anguish there were also a lot of songs that dealt with spinning in the face of longtime rock cliches against mieze music at this point in their career was really large in scope really ambitious but also sort of down-to-earth and relatable and the recordings even though they were raw the performances were very intense it was hard not to get just wrapped up in what the band was playing in the moment records like these made me feel like the world was going to hell in a handbasket really quickly but at least we were going to be singing a really fun loud chorus along the way then after reinventing Axl Rose I believed wholeheartedly that against me was going to go on to do something really bold and genre defying in the near future but I couldn't help but feel like I got the bait-and-switch routine on the band's next record as the eternal cowboy on this record against me moved on to the fad Records label and in the process they sort of took on the typically pop punky production sound that many bands on that label had against me sound was definitely a little cleaner it was louder it was punchier on this record but I couldn't help but feel like their raw sound and their folk influences were sort of being erased in the process now don't get me wrong the songs on this LP still have really clever politically charged lyrics and the tunes are really catchy and this is what made eternal cowboy enjoyable but against me made the path they were going to be moving into on their future albums really clear now on against meas next three studio LPS they continue to gain fans they actually moved on to a larger label with sire records however I personally was feeling that the sound of their instrumentation was just growing more and more tame that wild spark that was in many of the Bands early recordings was just vanishing completely and against me was sort of sounding just as overproduced as any kind of commercial radio friendly rock band just with more obvious Punk influences but there have been some significant changes going on in against me as music that has caused a lot of people to pay attention to the band once again for one the band's longtime drummer Warren Oakes decided to leave the group two against me has actually recently dropped a lot of demo and b-side albums based upon earlier releases of theirs and the founder of the band and once frontman Tom gable came out as a transsexual woman and admitted to having dealt with gender dysphoria since childhood and changed her name to Laura Jane grace now considering that Laura's songs have always been the foundation of against meas music and these songs tend to be so personal it's no surprise that publicly admitting something like being a transsexual woman would stir up interest and against meas next album without a doubt fans were expecting Laura to kind of give them a front row seat to whatever she was feeling during this transition or address all the social issues that come up during a gender identity crisis and even I was interested in hearing what would happen if Laura marched bravely into these subject matters especially once the title of this new against me LP came out trans gender dysphoria blues obviously this LP was not going to be tiptoeing around transgender topics but that is also now what every song on this record is about so trans gender dysphoria blues might not be the shocking tell-all album that a lot of people might have been expecting and even those songs on this thing like the title track are great she tunes I wouldn't say they bring much insight to the life that Laura may be leading now it's a pretty simple straightforward rock song about being judged by others on sight being spotted as a man despite dressing like and feeling you are a woman but the thing is most new against me songs don't really delve that deeply into the politics and the issues that they deal with anyway the language is typically pretty simple its poetic its personal it's not like there's any kind of solution hidden in the lyrics here I mean if you're a person who is sympathetic toward LGBT issues then what you're going to get on this record are a bunch of rowdy rock songs that affirm your already established feelings you can Bob your head to the music and nod your head to the message and this is not necessarily a bad thing I like to listen to songs that I agree with ideologically and tracks on here like the title track and my life 666 and true trans soul rebel are my favorites my issue with this record sits on against me not really making music that I find to be stimulating anymore the band's recordings their instrumentation and their melody seemed so tame in comparison to their early stuff and just about any other rock band I would rather listen to for example the song unconditional love it is obnoxiously sugary in the same way that a Green Day song is and the wordy lyrics barely barely hold the rhythm against this incredibly stiff set of drums and guitars I can barely stand this song and the same thing with the track dead friend - it seems like the subject matter of this track would be something that would affect Laura very deeply emotionally however the vocal delivery and the instrumentation the guitars the drums here just seems so inappropriate with the way the instrumentation sounds on this song it feels like I could swap the lyrics out for a story about a cute girl at a coffee shop and it wouldn't really be that unfitting and the song two coffins another track that I can't stand an acoustic ballad that should really see Laura letting loose but unfortunately it feels just as rigid as any of the louder rock songs on here the track just feels like from beginning to end Laura is trying to squeeze emotions out of this incredibly dry lifeless instrumentation even the loudest most hard-hitting song in this entire LP drinking with the jocks has its aggressive limitations the only tracks that actually overcome these production issues are the ones where the songs the tunes are so catchy and well written that they're impossible to deny like the tracks that I mentioned that we're my favorites and the closer on here black me out one of the most legitimately moving songs on this entire album even without diving too deeply into the lyrics Laura's vocal delivery on this track is just so impassioned it's a very beautiful change of pace trans gender dysphoria blues the recording is really clear some of the tunes on here are memorable the lyrics here have direction and they focus on valid topics and I think in a sense musically this record does have variety too it has ballads it has more aggressive tracks it even has moments on here like Obama bin Laden as the crucified Christ which instrumentally feels a lot like a 90s alternative rock radio tune all these things are not bad things and they are things that have also been qualities of against meas past several albums - what continues to be missing and against meas music and in a way is more missing than ever on this new record are legitimately overpowering emotions instrumentation guitars and drums that are actually hard-hitting and exciting and visceral I think this record lyrically makes a lot of good points but musically it's tame it's too tame for me to enjoy really I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this LP transition if you've given this hare listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should hare next and that's it Anthony Fantana against me hair forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new silver mount zion record fuck off get free we pour light on everything these guys are a montreal rock outfit known for their connections to the seminal post rock band Godspeed you black Emperor their connections but there are also differences for one the abandoned bites singing and lyrics on to its records much to the disappointment of some hardcore godspeed fans who aren't really that into the singing of frontman ephraim menak whose voice is a bit of an acquired taste however i wouldn't say these changes are so great that it would keep a post rock fan from enjoying silver mountains ions first two records at least early on in the band's music they were sort of emphasizing the more orchestral side of their sound the more instrumental side of their sound but since then with each new release they have been evolving into more of a rock music style and even though guitars and drums have been more of a loud heavy driving force on silver mountains ions past few records this new one of theirs fuck off get free is definitely the most fully realized and developed so far in terms of this heavier more aggressive sound the band sound on this record is super heavy distorted guitars piled on top of one another to the point where the first track on here sort of develops this overwhelming fuzziness warmth it becomes kind of psychedelic too as these string sections are swimming through this sea of guitars and the instruments on this track the blare so loudly it's impossible for this song not to be loud even when you turn it down you could shut the door but it's still going to sound like bombs shells are dropping outside the last third of this track even introduces these slow booming guitar riffs that feel slightly akin to do metal and in this more chaotic stage in silver mountain Zion sound on this record ephram's vocals don't sound half-bad i'm not saying his singing has gotten way better but I think his vocals are a bit more digestible sitting on this bonfire of burning guitars and bowed strings now given that this band is godspeed related and some of the LPS that have come out previously from silver mound Zion you might listen to this track expecting something that is a bit more subtle or dynamic or refined but the band actually puts their all into just creating this Hulk of a track I can't wrap my ears around it I can't wrap my arms around it it just rolls so slowly bulldozes everything in its way passionately I love the group vocals on this track the eerie melodies the dramatic string sections that introduce themselves in the last three minutes and the finisher of this track too is pretty chilling I think the singing some of the group vocals are a little overbearing and somewhat goofy occasionally but this is a great start to this LP and to me the album just gets better from here austerity blues a song that tempo wise is really mid paced but one of the more aggressively performed on this album it really sounds like the band is jamming on these riffs that they've written instrumentally the band takes pretty much that same all heavy all powerful approach really direct really explosive but the band still manages to incorporate elements that make the song feel detailed cinematic really vivid and even when the track really picks up and gets loud as hell the band manages to make things even louder and more intense as they introduce some group vocals into the mixture like the eight-minute mark this really raises the energy level the refrain that they're singing is incredibly impassioned and like many explosive moments on godspeed and silver Mount Zion records sometimes the aftermath is just as moving with just everything simultaneously coasting down the guitars fading away the strings and the vocals kind of driving the track home here the strings and the drums are so sparse the vocals feel so weary the band continues down this really immediate path on the next track to take away these early grave blues and even though silver Mount Zion had tracks on their previous record that landed around in this six or seven minute mark this is easily one of the most volatile tracks that they've put out within that time frame again the guitars are blaring the bass grooves are so steady on this thing and sound like they came out of a bad acid trip and the lyrics here don't words either and are delivered with very unpleasant shouting take away these take away these take away these early grain blues as far as a lyrical structure the song does take a lot of influence from blues but I don't see a lot of connections being drawn to that genre outside of that and the title because a lot of the melodies the string melodies that pop up in between these verses feel almost middle-eastern in a sense and the song grows more dissonant and chaotic as it continues with all these malformed strings and sour notes floating within this wall of sound it's just a really rebellious and immense song the melodies on this LP take a more sad yet uplifting and tender direction on the track what we loved was not enough still a very heavy song but emotionally potent as well a track with what I assume is a 3/4 time signature it's it's kind of like the waltz to end all waltzes the song features all these really teary-eyed string sections vocals that just Yelp out these frightening Lee morbid lyrics that are sort of carried by the phrase the day has come where we no longer feel there will be war in our cities there will be riots at the mall blood on our doorsteps and panics at the ball all our city's going to burn all our bridges going to snap all our pennies going to rot lightning roll across the tracks all our children going to die it's a cataclysmic track that the more I listen to it the more it just grabs me and just shakes me emotionally obviously and the only slight letdown of this entire LP is the closing song which I do think is slightly underwhelming short of breath it feels more like an epilogue honestly if this song had just been erased the last track would have been a somewhat fitting closer but I do think that this song is added on to add on to the themes of this album that have to do with end times people dying in their younger years early graves premature death dying before you even reach the point of adulthood this may have to do with the fact that this song in the title says it's a tribute to Capital steez with all the refrains mentioning children dying on the previous track and the early great blues on this record this does seem to be a recurring theme on fuck off gift free and even though I think that a lot of the lyrics on this record are incredibly flowery there is something that is really moving about how blunt and direct Silver Mount Zion is with its messages I was hoping for a little bit more from the ending here but I guess in a way and I'm just sort of interpreting this on a personal level it does bring home the idea that when the ending comes it's not necessarily something that holds your hand it doesn't necessarily give you an explicit warning it arrives when it feels like it much to our surprise despite that we may be making our own beds hmm I'm feeling a strong 8 to a light 9 on this record transition if you've given this thing a listen what did you think of it love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana silver Mount Zion fuck off get free forever
