hey everyone Anthony Pham tanto here Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new self-titled murmur album this is the sophomore LP from the chicago-based metal outfit murmur this new LP of theirs is being dropped right at the start of this year by a label which is a subdivision of Season Of Mist records a pretty heavy hitter in the metal underground as far as labels go if you weren't aware this band's 2010 debut LP slipped by me however when looking through their back catalogue after listening to this new album of theirs I was not surprised to find that they actually have a split out with another experimental metal outfit from the Midwest knock Miss diem and I'm not surprised because I feel like these two bands share a lot of common ground I do think they have a similar stylistic approach in that black metal is a really huge foundational influence for the music that both of these groups create in the case of murmur seems to inform their retched vocals their claustrophobic recording and they're sort of dismal chord progressions but both bands only really use black metal as a bit of a home base as they reach out and experiment with other genres incorporating them into this traditionally dark sound even though the first track on this LP is a pretty harsh wake-up call with some obvious black metal influences as this song and this entire album progresses elements of experimental rock jazz rock jazz fusion all reveal themselves the band might jam on like an off-kilter riff or an odd time signature or create some chaos with some really glitchy electronics or a flurry of percussion from drummer Charlie Werber whose playing is actually a huge highlight on nearly every track here the track recuerdo s-- is kind of a an acoustic guitar driven funky interlude that's pretty nice come down and there are moments on this LP as well where the band seems to embrace that noisy my numbing riff repetition of a van like swans which happens on the track king in yellow a song that isn't my favorite on here mostly because I do think that repetition makes the song overstay its welcome a little bit the vocals on this thing can be really aggressive and abrasive and in other spots here kind of melodic on the song when blood leaves have these sort of eerie deadpan vocal harmonies that have such a cultish vibe to them I love it on the opening track here there are some really heavenly chorus vocals hanging in the background and whether they're sampled or synthesized or not they add a really nice and sort of pretty sound to this very evil metal recording and to speak to the more freakish side of this record there is the song Zeta 2 part 2 where over these really oddly shaped riffs that are locked in really tightly with the drums we're getting what is sort of heavy metal scatting even the final song in this LP is a cover of King Crimson's larks tongues and aspect part to really more of a bonus track for those who are interested but that sort of shows you where this band is coming from they really love their progressive rock they really love their jazz rock and not that they should be ashamed either of what bands they're sort of taking ideas for them to make this record because this is they're blending all these influences so seamlessly that this self-titled record is a little refreshing in a sense for the most part the band understands tension and release and how it can use these two things to drag songs on for long periods of time and keep it interesting this talent is best displayed on the first three tracks here for one the song water for water which has this really dismal opening with acoustic guitars and it builds really slowly with some guitar leads that are wailing and electric piano keys that are scattered about the percussion is all over the place and suddenly the song just explodes into a wall of blast beats these very messy and chaotic tremolo Pickett ARS and like I said earlier these heavenly background vocals that sort of as they return raise the climaxes of the song higher and higher then there's the song bull of Crete which has all these really sharp shrill guitar chords and riffs playing over this drumming that the more I listened to it it just reminds me of animal from the Muppets I can't really explain it in any other way while I do know the stylistic influences that make Charlie Weber play the way that he does I just imagine him playing this track and just see his hands all over the place the song eventually just glides into this ascending chord progression that I absolutely love the track then moves through a series of riffs and dismal interludes before it comes back and returns to a lot of the same themes but with a lot more drama and power those are two words I would use to describe the next track on here as well almalik the longest song here with more than 11 minutes in length and a track that sticks out to me because of the greatest difference between one part and another part in another part in the song I mean there are so many hard-hitting riffs right at the beginning of this track but then it just boils down very quickly into this deep dark depressing bleak set of guitar passages and they're really murky bass riffs and the sort of sparse electric piano it reminds me of darker groups in progressive rock music like magma or Guapo the band essentially structures this album in a way where they hit you with these three monsters and then sort of go down a little bit into this funky interlude which is a very great track and then hit you with three more tracks that seem to be sort of linked into one another to me there are only two major weak points on this LP and they don't even really distract me that much from enjoying the album for one the vocals sometimes they're chilling and really aggressive sometimes they're melodic other times they're kind of straightforward and shouting and pretty intelligible the vocals definitely get the job done they don't bore me but they don't wow me on here as much as some of the guitar playing and especially the drumming however this might also be due to how buried the vocals feel in the overall recording which is sort of my second issue with this album what exactly murmur is doing on this record the detail of it feels slightly obscured by the kind of grimy sound that this record has to offer and while I'm sure on some level it's an aesthetic choice it did take me a few listens to kind of make heads or tails of the nuances to the playing on this thing so I thought this thing was really great I'd highly recommend it I mean there was a really visceral jagged progressive rock riffs on this thing fantastic diverse drumming with a lot of fluidity excitement these guys keep this sound gritty and they keep the playing strong and I think the album itself is pretty cohesive from front to back with a lot of songs on here complimenting one another segue into to another or explore different sounds or experiments to keep this record from getting too redundant I wish the sound on this thing was a little more hard-hitting and I wish the ending was a bit more climactic it's definitely one of the most dismal tracks on this entire record but still I am feeling the lightest and fluffiest of eights on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh murmur forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Nils from album spaces this is the latest full-length LP from German pianist and composer Nils Frahm hope I'm pronouncing his name correctly this may be the first time you're hearing of him but he is a seasoned musician with numerous releases under his belt so on this LP Nils essentially does what many musicians do they have a pretty sizable back catalogue he puts out a live album and because this is a live LP it's not like Nils is pushing outside of those minimalist and modern classical styles that fans are used to actually quite a bit material on this thing lands on previous LPS like the bells and felt but he goes into spaces with the mission and for me that seems to be that he wants to put the electrifying and pretty moving magic of his live performances to tape and in the process transform a lot of these songs the song said and done alone almost triples its length on this album and if songs on this thing aren't being stretched out they're being mashed into massive medleys that span past 10 11 15 minutes on the song hammers you can even hear what I assume is Nils manically moaning along to the lead melodies that he's playing which are really simple but also beautiful and powerful and sort of sit atop these speedily played piano arpeggios that sort of serve as the foundation of the song and even though the general tone and the vibe of the pianos here do give off a somewhat new-age esque vibe on this live album occasionally I do think that Nils is far too spontaneous and gritty to be lumped in such a category the entire album itself even begins with an intentional hiccup on the 1-minute track and aborted beginning now even though this LP sticks very wholly to solo piano compositions it does have enough variety on it to keep me engaged for most of this thing like the song says which is this really wonderful progressive synthesizer Odyssey I'd expect from someone like Vangelis but this track doesn't just sound like another artist it also sounds like the sensation of being weightless it sounds like the stars sounds like interplanetary travel following this track is the song said and done which at its foundation has the sustained piano notes just ringing very rhythmically over and over and over it's hypnotic and it's very simple foundations like this that are the basis for many songs on here and on top of these rhythmic patterns Mills will drop a very simple but pretty lead melody or some very grand or glorious piano chords and even though many of these tracks may seem very repetitive and cyclical within a given moment focus is never lost on where the song is moving next like at the 3-minute mark on this track we're all of a sudden this entirely different chord introduces itself ringing along with the singular piano notes for beautiful harmony and at the five-minute mark on this track the amount of piano notes ringing out with this sustain seems to have increased to the point where it sounds like I'm listening to dozens of bells ringing all at once the song is cluttered but it's wonderfully uplifting and there's a very somber piano piece finishing this track out as well that's beautiful but not every tone down moment on this LP moves me like the song went missing which I actually found to be kind of nondescript I prefer moments on this thing like familiar which has a much Moody or melody and one that I think is a lot more memorable and the track improvisation for coughs and the cellphone has a really dreary edge to Ross's harmonium is another one of the softer tracks on here the final track on this entire thing and even though the harmonium the tone of this song and the really beautiful chords make it stick out the abrupt fade that ends up finishing this song off makes it a pretty lackluster closer and makes me feel like this album is is more of a compilation of recordings live recordings as opposed to a wholly conceived project or album so there definitely are some underwhelming spots for me on this LP even if it doesn't seem like it's a big deal because these songs are consistently some of the shortest on the album but I'm sort of torn on this thing sometimes because there are tracks on here that are in credibly mountainous in their ambition and their beauty like the the medley on here for Peter toilet brushes and more the song has all bees shimmering synth chords at the start all of a sudden these murky bass notes make their way in eventually and then Nils sharpens these waves of Basie drones with some higher tones and all of a sudden these slow-moving waves of sense just thicken up they get bigger they get wider they're larger than life they're monolithic and the song comes to a climax on the song toilet brushes with all of these very nimbly played piano chords and notes cascading over one another with a little bit of delay sounds overlapping one another really beautifully its tracks like this that the playing is so intense it's so muscular it's so in the moment it's hard for me not to get wrapped up in the track get lost in it the execution is fast it's somewhat technical as well but the music that is being played is sort of simple immediate straightforward but not so much that it feels dumbed down every move that's made on this record feels very purposeful even on the songs that do sort of feel a little bit more like wallpaper to me overall spaces does have some really amazing moments on it to the point where I want to stay in tune with whatever this guy is putting out next I liked a majority of this album a lot but I didn't love every track here and I thought spaces in its entirety was a little too long-winded but personally my biggest issue is that I wish these performances and sort of Nils aesthetic in general was just a little more idiosyncratic I mean the compositions are fantastic the playing is great and tracks on here like toilet brushes and hammers do show a significant amount of eccentricity but there is a considerable amount of tracks on here that do go by without much in the way of a unique or interesting angle I'm feeling a decent strong seven on this thing transition if you've given this album listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it Fantana spaces playing forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Lee Bannon album alternate endings Lee Bannon is a super versatile music producer known mostly for his hip hop production letting his beats the likes of pro era as well as super helpful but the guy's been dropping lesser-known solo albums and EPS for years now LPS like big toy box and fantastic plastic and Caligula theme music and a lot of these releases dabbling in instrumental hip hop and some cloud rap and trap rap as well and even though his releases have been getting darker and more atmospheric and chilled out and moody I didn't really foresee the move that he was gonna make with this record or really just the the surprise transition he made away from hip hop I wouldn't really say you did a 180 with his music he really did three backflips a spin kick and a front aerial off a two-story building landing somewhere in Jungle break beat drum and bass territory genres of electronic music I remember being wildly popular when I was a lot younger and I liked a lot of the bigger names coming out of them as well like the prodigy and The Chemical Brothers and Crystal Method had some songs I liked and then later I drove into artists who were much more aggressive and experimental with some of these breakbeat drum and bass drill and bass sounds Square pusher effects twin and because there was a time when these genres had crested in the in the popular consciousness it's hard not to see the direction that Lee Bannon takes on this record as nostalgic and alternate endings makes me wonder whether or not this genre could sort of see a second coming get popular once again especially given that Lee Bannon has recreated these styles with such a deep attention to detail the LP kicks off with the fantastic track resurrect a very speedy break beats on this thing glitchy vocal samples that are relentless locked into the beaten constantly jumping up and down in pitch sometimes chipmunks sometimes grimy beasts lines on this track great groove this song to me has everything a great song in this style should have but bannon's sort of distinguishes himself in this genre with an emphasis on atmosphere executing some of these songs with a massive amount of reverb that might remind you of a burial record and I know there are atmospheric drum and bass producers like Goldie who definitely have influenced bannon's music but he does take the reverb he does take the ethereal tones to an extreme degree sometimes especially on tracks like this opener where seems like Lee is trying to either find or create as much common ground as possible between incredibly aggressive jungle and breakbeat music and ambient interludes these sounds also come together really well on my favorite track here NW / WB which has all these vocal samples from the RZA peppered throughout the vocals are just screaming their attention-grabbing really reminds me of the prodigy then there's this incredibly infectious synth line and this lead is so strange it's warped it's twisted the song delivers a blazing opener but slowly grows more panoramic and ethereal as it continues on incorporating these sounds in the background that sound like haunted winds along with a lot of other indescribable noises and glitches and tones and little percussive flares that are spread throughout the track again there's a really great balance of hard in-your-face sounds and more ethereal sounds as well on these first two tracks but this atmosphere sometimes can be bannon's undoing tracks like prime / decent and shoot out the Stars and wind and then songs like this really set the stage but they fail to cast a leading role the LP really is break be wallpaper for a little while unfortunately and this doesn't really change until the track Phoebe Katz where while this song is atmospherically addicted as well the vocal samples and the overall melodies hanging in the atmosphere in the background are so pretty there so beautiful they're so serene and then there is tu-16 another favorite of mine on here which starts off with a very very eerie and murky piano part right at the beginning there are these wailing vocal samples popping up repeatedly throughout the track I love the cascading keyboard phrases over the bridge tracks like this on this record are fantastic ones that have a ton of detail multiple phases you really feel like you're traveling through different parts of the song from A to B even though there are tracks here that I think do sort of lack variety within the song itself I do think liebe Anand does bring a number of different vibes and feels on some of these songs even though he does stick very passionately to that drum and bass jungle break B vibe with some very subtle references to things like hip hop and dub and dubstep the song cold slash Mel is kind of a detour for me not really a highlight but still stands out as being very psychedelic and the closing track on here is similarly trippy as well and then there's value 10 as well which has one of the more standout vocal samples I love the funky bass line break toward the end of this track the very steady ride cymbal the changes of pace and sound are just enough for me but even if you are into this sound I do think to an extent Bannen does test patience especially with the length of this record and behemoths on here like the nine minute song ready slash available one of my least favorite songs on here not because of its length but because of its really tedious lead melody that you don't get any relief from until about the six-minute mark of the track when these song changes pace and starts ascending up a somewhat epic chord progression overall alternate endings is a decent album considering it's Lee bandhans first big commercial release after being recently signed in into tune records it's got some undeniably fantastic tracks but does it stay entertaining for the entire hour not for me Plus at this point with pursuing this style of music I think Lee Bannon is doing more emulating than he is carving a niche out for himself while it's good and encouraging to hear that Lee Bandhan can recreate this musical style to a tee it's gonna be exciting to hear if he can push it beyond this I'm feeling a decent too strong sex on this record transition but if you've given this LP a listen what did you think of it love it hate it Why What you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Lee Bannon alternate endings forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Shu Shu album Nina any month you get to talk about Nina Simone twice on your music review vlog is a good one jazz singer pianist and songwriter Nina Simone has been getting a lot of attention over the past half a year so mostly because of a sample of one of her songs that landed in one of the bigger tracks of Kanye West's latest LP yeezus however my favorite tribute to her music from this past year comes in the form of this record from artpop experimental rock outfit Shu Shu with singer-songwriter and frontman Jamie Stewart masterminding the whole thing this project has been putting out LPS for about 10 years now and in my opinion Nina ranks as one of those projects most ambitious albums yet it features eleven revisions of songs that Nina had either written or just had a really great performances of in her discography and even though there are tribute albums out there already for Nina Simone's music and there are a lot of tribute albums out there in general I would like to think of this record as a big deal I would like to think of it as a big undertaking for Shu Shu I think the band has shown no lack of ambition with a ton of raw live instrumentation on this record backed with horns which brings a bit of a human element into the equation which has been sort of missing from some of the more glitchy and electronically driven albums they've been putting out recently however even with the effort being put into getting this live instrumentation putting the Arrangements together Shu Shu has come out with a covers album that is so stylistically and just sonically off the mark I'm not really sure I could responsibly recommend it to nina simone fans and it's it's not really because this record isn't jazzy enough if there's anything proven by the end of this LP it's that Jamie Stewart and the musicians he works with on this LP have a very firm grasp of jazz instrumentation what's probably going to be an issue is that even though this thing is a Nina Simone covers album it sounds a lot more like the last Scott Walker album a lot of the instrumental arrangements throughout these tracks are noisy they're dissonant they're cluttered and Jamie Stewart singing on these songs is more unorthodox than usual for a shoo-shoo album whisper quiet very breathy hanging mostly in the lower register and it also sounds like throughout these tracks that steward is in some kind of great amount of pain most likely emotional but I wouldn't rule out physical what disappointed me a little at first is that Jamie's vocals are a little quiet and a little whispery a little understated considering that he is trying to tribute one of the best voices in jazz he's trying to tribute a jazz great however what he does do singing in the fashion that he does on this record is captures the inherent eeriness and a lot of these Simone songs making them way more twisted and nightmarish especially on tracks like pirate Jenny where Jamie Stewart sort of takes some lyrical liberties in a story about a woman who is working on a ship and is planning to sneakily kill all the passengers when they least suspect it and Jamie delivers this song like an evil villain sort of unfolding his plan to a single listener in secret it's a great track it's one of my favorites it's a song where I actually think the odd vocal styling plays really well into the lyrics of this Nina Simone song however there are some tracks here that I think maybe are a little too spooky for their own good that spookiness that comes with the sparse instrumentation and Jamie's vocals over takes some of the melody or maybe what the storyline is a lot like on the opening track here don't smoke in bed the horns on this track do a fantastic job of very quaintly adapting the opening melody but I feel like the singing on this song with it being at its most whispery on this entire record possibly doesn't really do the tale here justice I mean what this song is lyrically is really a lot like a letter that you find in the kitchen one morning when you wake up to see that your significant other has completely disappeared and they're leaving you however with the vocals being so eccentric on this record and this track and and so theatrical it forces me to kind of imagine why they would be sung in this way and the only scenario where that I could come up with is that this person is trying to slink away and say their final goodbyes without waking their significant other up but really I can only guess why certain things happen and why certain things sound the way they do on this record outside of the moments where melodies and instrumentation very clearly mimics spots from these original Nina Simone tracks there isn't much on this record that makes clear obvious sense the song where can I go without you for example one of my favorites on here but still a song with these very sparse Celeste melodies and sort of funhouse sound effects creaking and just causing a riot in the background against Jamie Stewart it's just soft quivering voice this song sounds like something you would hear walking down the hallway of and saying asylum in the middle of the night and you sort of peek into a padded room and see some straitjacket sweaty guys singing this song to himself rocking in a corner a lot of the decisions made in adapting these tracks seem more personal than practical and sometimes Shu Shu pushes the envelope so far that some people may think that these tracks are just too overacted they're too freaky to be genuine or enjoyable and I think that would be the case if you were just simply holding this record to a rock or a pop music standard and even though those genres do inform many of Shu shus records I think this is one of the few LPS that they've put out where that just does not cross over here Nina scratches a whole series of different itches this is a record for people who like their music to be very eccentric dissonant challenging odd and chaotic if that's the case there's no reason that a track on here like while does the wind shouldn't appeal to you I love the tension in this track the rickety percussion just causing a riot in the background the duet horns and the guitar all sort of moving at the strange fluid pace just a cloud of instrumentation orbiting Jamie's dying breath vocals the south and what's incredibly haunting on this LP is the very steady pace of the track don't explain the music sounds like the soundtrack to someone slow painful murder with Jamie Stewart sounding like he has tears rolling down his face as he's singing the song there are some moments on this LP though that are very visceral like the song sea lion woman which has some very hard-hitting percussion in the background wild horns with some wailing screaming free jazz embellishments and Jamie Stewart's vocals are just hot intense they're loud reaching into his upper register I wish we saw this side of his voice more and even though this track is in a way a highlight because of how loud it is it does not really make it into my favorites on here because it's a little short of breath on the length still the song for women is another very loud and intense track and is a bit longer pays off with a really awesome chord progression at the finish with the horns resolving in a really beautiful way and the song you'd be so nice as well I feel like pushes that free jazz experimentation even further with the horns going absolutely nuts and behind all of it there's this really strong jazz walking bass line it feels like some sort of freaky perversion of a track from the Twin Peaks soundtrack so there are aggressive moments on this LP there are just freaky eccentric moments on this LP they're sad spots here they're creepy spots here but there are moments here that I do think are hauntingly beautiful are sort of soulful as well like the opening horn melodies on the track just say I love him which also features some very beautiful accompaniment throughout from guitar and a bit of melodica as well as they bounce back and forth with the vocals just as this LP is great at churning out sounds that are hugely disturbing it's just as good as putting out sounds that are moving even after 40 minutes the acoustic guitar backed song the other woman sounds kind of rude Sein and friendly in comparison with the other tracks here even though this song as well is fronted by Jamie Stuart's very strange vocal stylings I will say the only downside to this track is while I do like the thought of what they tried to do with tender side of this song in this record I do think Jamie Stewart's singing style here does sound much better with heavier accompaniment overall I have to say this LP is really unique in my opinion it's entertaining it's strangely fun and bizarre and with how eccentric this record is especially in the vocal Department I do realize that this album is gonna garner some really strong opinions people who are just far into hating it and people who are far into loving it and those opinions might even swing further into the hating it direction simply because this thing is a Nina Simone covers album and these covers aren't exactly complimentary in a really obvious way but to me after numerous listens to this album it's very apparent that Shu Shu deeply appreciates and understands the emotions and the stories that are laced into every Nina Simone song at least the ones that they covered here as well as the instrumental quality - and the way that the band goes about covering these songs is so incredibly interesting as well just taking single ideas instrumentally just sounds or chord progressions or tones and just exaggerating them or magnifying them to the point where it feels like an entirely different song and once you've magnified this one single piece and just brought it out and just made it bolder and weirded it up a little bit then the entire song around this is sort of free for you to recreate Shu Shu takes a ton of liberties with these nina simone songs there's no denying that but despite that I do think that there is a ton of power and and beauty to this record I'm feeling a light eight on this album transition if you've given this album a listen and what do you think I should review next let me know yep any Fantana Shu Shu Nina Simone forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new album forceps these guys are a French rock quartet and even though this is their debut LP the band members do have ties to more established groups in France's hardcore and post hardcore scene like pigeon and as we draw and birds in row the last of which actually had a pretty decent album come out last year however I wasn't that crazy about the LP there wasn't much on it melodically or riff wise this stuck out to me considering how many bands there are out there right now combining the ferocity and the speed of punk music with sludgy metal production there's a lot of bands on Southern Lord doing this sound some recent additions to Death Wish incorporated like Code Orange kids or Oathbreaker nails trap them this routine is hell Kurt Beaulieu of converge actually produces quite a few of the group's going for this sound and I think even a moderate fan of extreme music will pick up the converge influence and calve Ayers music right away along with some sounds coming from the world's a crust Punk and D bead and black metal and grindcore there are some very complicated grooves that feel almost math rock inspired on this LP too but I wouldn't really say that clear inspiration hurts the enjoyability of this album in any major way it definitely doesn't lessen the impact of the unrelenting tooth clenched anger disdain on every song now from what I've read about this LP the band tracked it live and it definitely sounds like that a whirlwind of rock instrumentation all turned up to 11 with gunshot drums and hellish vocals heavy heavy guitars and the aggressive parts that are here are detailed and interesting enough to dive into not just sort of let them pummel you to death the opener on here starts off with some incredibly fast and tense and off-kilter guitar riffs that are syncopated very tightly with the drums and all of this rhythm all of these riffs they just move so fast it's it's difficult to describe them as anything else but kind of a blur guitars pretty much dominate the entire track with the exception of a few moments around the 1-minute mark where some really gruesome group vocals sort of overtake them but only for a little bit and this track segues right into the next song like they're both the same song it's just such a fast transition and on this track pummeling riffs are accented with really shrill guitar chords the band starts chugging through a groove slows down the tempo progressively gets slower and slower and slower until they hit this sludgy depressive stride that kind of sounds like the harsh come down after the anger Laden crack they doled out on the first song the band starts to show off their instrumental dynamics on the next track where Asajj it's a 4-minute song one of the longer tracks on this LP which for the most part is filled with songs that barely reach the two-minute mark there's a very bleak build of guitar leads and primal drums on this part of the track and then the song eventually breaks through into a series of brick to your face riffs and blast beats so many of these tracks shift and change so quickly what they're doing but what it's changing from is one incredibly intense moment to another incredibly intense moment but on the end of this particular track there is a very beautiful and dreary set of slower guitar chords that are played through where the vocals are actually in the background trying to add some element of harmony so sometimes the changes that these songs undergo are significant but still I do wish that the vocals stuck out a little bit more and did bring maybe a bit of a gentle or vibe at this point in the song I guess in a sense it just kind of feels a little OneNote I can also hear the vocals pushing outside of that screaming role on the song caret L and this track has some really slow melodic guitar passages that make for one of the more emotionally powerful moments on this album but still on this track I'm sort of left wishing that the vocals brought more of a sea-change the instrumental dynamics on this LP continue on tracks like Oh porks the longest track on this entire LP is six minutes it kicks off with some marching snare drums and some very dismal guitar chords this moment in the song is very thin it's very trebly but then eventually the bass kicks in the song gets really thunderous and unrelenting and the longer it goes the more the track feels like being tossed down a bottomless pit and you're surrounding the slowly grow darker darker and darker and even though the slower spots on here the more melodic spots to me are the ones that truly stick out there are riffs on this album that though for the very short amount of time that they play do feel very catchy they feel visceral they really whip me into a friends you've just wanted to bob my head and wave and fly up my arms of violently there are some guitar tone changes here and there as well but for the most part you're gonna be hearing the thunderous riffs that you catch right at the beginning of the album and again to go back to the one major issue that this LP has a lot of this LP just kind of coasts by in a bit of a frenzy not that this album is forgettable because you will most definitely not forget the impact and the aggression that this band brings to the table but the details of it do end up being fuzzy even after multiple listens and it's not really for lack of tight playing or fantastic production or great ideas this LP has that I actually think there are some better writing ideas on this thing than there are on some albums that are similarly frenzied metallic hardcore fusions the songs on this record aren't really organized in a very cohesive way and if one of the goals here is to be as disorienting as possible mission accomplished the music is slightly nihilistic in this way but it is strangely satisfying despite it all of this nihilism kind of comes to a head on the last track where every single instrument in the mix is trying to make as much noise as possible as fast as possible just before the audio of the song just cuts out into pure silence which in a nutshell is kind of this album however for the short period of time that this LP does last the noise that it's making is incredibly intense loud well recorded just there's an impressive level of energy and stamina and rhythmic complexity to a lot of these songs that just keeps me coming back despite the fact that some things just aren't sticking I'm feeling a light 7 on this thing transition if you've given this LP listened what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan oh god forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new self-titled Beyonce album beyonce is a famed aren't he and pop singer who through her solo LPS and her year she put in with Destiny's Child is one of the most widely known singers ever and her biggest records played a large role in shaping the sound of mainstream commercial radio friendly R&B throughout the late 90s and 2000's and unless you've been living under a rock I'm sure you know how a lot of these records sound instrumentally very clean punchy immediate the most important elephant being of course Beyonce's incredibly bold and powerful voice especially on some of her biggest singles like crazy and love and single ladies run the world you're replaceable there's a lot of them honestly I'm not really here to hold your hand through a bunch of stuff that you already know and music that you may or may not have grown up with all I can really say is that outside of the singles I've been pretty neutral on Beyonce for a majority of her career however I was pleasantly surprised by a lot of songs on her last full-length LP for an LP where I actually thought she eased up a bit on the surface level immediate commercial appeal of her music and started favoring instrumentals that were a lot more dynamic and I basically went into this new LP of hers hoping that she would venture further outside of that radio-friendly comfort zone and sort of throw off the pressure to essentially make an album full of radio songs and that's kind of been a recurring theme with a lot of popular albums from this past year and this whole I'm not making songs for the radio mantra has been kind of a recurring theme with a lot of artists over the past year Kanye jay-z Drake these artists and artists like these dropping more experimental records ethereal records and specifically in the case of jay-z relying more on YouTube advertisements and the buzz surrounding a deal he did with Samsung to buy so many copies of his album and then distribute it to their users and Beyonce in a similar fashion as well didn't really do any teasing with the music toward the release of this new album of her she just pooted out toward the tail end of last year and allowed everybody to hear for the first time all together at once and obviously putting her album out this way subtracts radio promotion from the equation when it comes to building to your new full-length album but I think people are a little quick to jump the gun and just outright praise her simply for that on this LP it's not like Beyonce didn't have successful singles in 2013 it's not like she didn't have a stunning Super Bowl performance last year plus her album was plastered all over the front of iTunes the day that it dropped which caused the internet to spread the word like wildfire considering Beyonce's young listening audience which is most likely very deeply linked into the internet I don't really know if you need much more promotion these days however right now it has been a handful of weeks since this LP originally dropped a lot of the hype surrounding it has already dissipated a little bit and it seems that beyonce and her label aren't really looking to get into any huge advertising campaign to ram the album down people's throats in the coming weeks and this slightly unorthodox approach for beyonce is also reflected in the direction she takes the music into she has over an hour of songs on this album and they're brought to us by her and a gauntlet of co songwriters and producers who you might actually be familiar with if you've been reading a lot of the liner notes of mainstream contemporary R&B and hip hop albums over the past several years Timbaland Timberlake Mike Dean boots Noah forty Drake's producer Miguel the dream hit boy Pharrell surprisingly enough Caroline pull a check of chairlift and a lot more I haven't even mentioned however what is most interesting on this thing is of course the music which has received a pretty warm reception from critics across the board with a lot of people praising Beyonce for putting out her most surprising and ambitious album yet and I guess you can tag it as that if you want but I think there are some R&B records that have come out over the past few years that are a little more ambitious Janelle monáe's past few LPS Frank ocean's too and has some kind of dull instrumentals their tracks on this LP that bring some really heavy bass and some trap style high hats too and throw some really inane self-serious swag on top that sort of reminds me of tracks from Miley Cyrus's last album or like some Rihanna singles that have come out recently especially on tracks like partition which has all this sexual imagery in the lyrics that is so vivid it's tantalizing like born and I don't really think this tracker tracks on this LP like it are horrible but I do think they lose their flavor kind of quick there are high points on this hi everyone Anthony Fantino here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for our final video of classics week Nina Simone pastel Blues Nina Simone songwriter accomplished pianist and one of the most unique voices in jazz music her deep bellowing vocals earned her hits right from the start of her career and recorded music and even though her pop appeal did keep her album sales going a lot of her songs and albums did have kind of a darker side to them a mournful side or even a politically charged message like the track Mississippi goddamn or her infamous cover of Billie Holiday's strange fruit which lands on this LP Nina was also early to cover songs like screamin Jay Hawkins I put a spell on you as well as House of the Rising Sun she's put out a lot of songs throughout her career that relate to her heritage or love on the rocks she never really shied away from tracks whose subject matter was really cynical or biting toward popular culture like marriages for old folks but she was also not really a stranger to jazz standards and traditional songs and and love songs which is true of this LP right here as well pastel blues an LP who from its title you might guess is a blues album blues does seem to be a basis for a lot of the chord progressions on this LP and what I also like about this album is that Nina sticks very closely to her quartet of guest musicians that accompany her sort of sidestepping a lot of the heavily orchestrated vocal pop that she had done before on her previous records that was sort of popular during this time period and the first track on here is especially stripped back be my husband a song that was allegedly written by Nina's husband and features nothing but her voice clapping and a hi-hat and the melody she's singing on this track and the way that she delivers it vocally it just feels like an old spiritual in this track because of a stripped back it is instrumentally it's just a really great display of how fantastic her vocals are she howls she moans she croons her way through this song in a really emotive way jumping up and down her vocal range and the moments when she reaches her highest these ad-libs sound amazing and have her sounding more like trumpet than a human being she had such a unique vocal and it's interesting that they would take a song that is that is this skeletal and put it first right at the beginning of the album this song gives away to a Bessie Smith track nobody knows you when you're down and out which was originally recorded in the 1930s the song has a very bluesy instrumental that plays it very straight which happens with a few other tracks on here trouble in mind chill wind don't blow and ain't no use these tracks even though they are solid songs the instrumentation is a little lacking and surprises especially considering how great of a pianist Nina was though her playing in her improvisation on the last of those three tracks is great still this is pretty forgivable especially on this Bessie Smith track because it tells a story that is as old as time in such a heartfelt way everyone's there for the party as long as your foot in the bill but as soon as you're broke everyone's vanished and not only is it a good tune not only are the lyrics really vivid and telling but Nina's vocals are especially powerful on the turnaround on the back end of this song the song trouble in mind is another catchy tune attract that lyrically visits a very familiar blues theme that you know bad times today but maybe things will be better tomorrow very good track and you know not to give more credit to the dreary er songs on this LP but they really are where Nina feels her boldest on this record her vocal performance on the track end of the line is absolutely chilling hearing her singing with such a heavy vibrato while pushing herself into the deepest lows of her range of her vocal range plus the very nimble piano chords and arpeggios dipping in and out in the background adds a lot of drama to the tune and again that vibrato it's no wonder she's been such a heavy influence on people like Jamie Stewart of shoo-shoo an indie band that recently put out a covers album of songs that she had written or recorded and performed throughout her career another slower track on here that I love tell me more and more and then some the song is a bit of harmonica back blues has a pace that is as as molasses and it is a sultry back alley track moonlit night light breeze leaves falling temperatures in the low 50s it's like that the bass and the drums on this track are shadowy just hanging in the background like a stalker the harmonica chiming in and disappearing just as fast as it came like a car driving by in the distance and I love the way that Nina fills in the spaces and the silence with her voice and and the piano chord she just swipes at the silence so aggressively and she really sort of picks her shots sparingly and my favorite tracks on this thing are easily the two that this LP ends off with first her infamous cover of the song strange fruit the second Billie Holiday track to make it onto this LP a song that is really one of the most vivid and stomach-churning depictions of lynching in the southern United States and Nina Simone does it unspeakable justice and instrumentally she really values space again on this song a lot like the other Billie Holiday track here and it just makes the incredibly mournful lyrics on this song even more empowered and the way Nina is singing on this song the way she's a moding on this track it just makes the topic feel so much more sinister and and unspeakable the closing track on here sinner man which strange fruit sort of glides into pretty seamlessly is easily the longest track here ten minutes long and does not really feel boring or long-winded not for a single beat Nina and her band pulled together a really powerful rendition of this traditional song and they moved through multiple phases of this track too with Nina and her band just gaining more momentum and intensity with their playing as the track progresses it's really easy to get wrapped up and how they're playing off of one another in this song especially as the background vocals are boiling up and as the song moves along the starts and stops the drum fills the drum improvisation 'z Nina been propping a little on her piano with clapping happening in the background though the tune is good it's just really hearing these people play together so passionately that makes this song great and hearing Symone push her vocal range to the outer limits on the very very end of the track it just makes for such a powerful and moving finish overall pastel blues is a really solid set of songs for Nina Simone a great starting point if you haven't really listened to a full-length album of hers yet and a great display of her vocal abilities if you're really looking to get up close and personal with this really this pre Fugazi era is the band led by co singer-songwriter in Fugazi guy Picciotto writes off spring a band that a lot of people credit is sort of being forefathers of emo emotional hardcore and the whose bass lines actually are really pivotal to the groove bass sound that Fugazi brought to the table there are a lot of things that I like about these bands and projects that were formed leading up to the formation of Fugazi but here in this band I feel is where all of it really clicked they were able to successfully take the ferocity the aggression of hardcore punk but apply it to more dynamic song structures flashier guitar playing more adventurous song structures as well and there were already a number of groups in the 80s that were experimenting with the sound of punk rock and hardcore who while they were very influenced by hardcore punk they appreciated pop music and lots of melody as well that's why a lot of these groups taking hardcore punk music infusing it with other genres are usually labeled post hardcore but Fugazi has never really been one for labels anyways so Fugazi came after all these bands but what makes them stick out to me is that they had a little bit of the best of all of these worlds intensely catchy songs with big shout along choruses and burning unforgettable guitar leads great riffs that just had a lot of punch to him but they weren't really heavy in fact they were very lean and had a lot of mid-range to them but but just a very sharp tone and occasionally the way that these guitars were layered was very noisy chaotic abrasive and even though I more complex than anything that these guys have worked with before in the punk bands they had been in previously and these bass lines and drum beats especially when the guitars are stripped back and you're simply listening to the bass and drums what they're playing the vibe the tone sounds like sort of a precursor to a lot of the alternative rock and grunge that would hit the mainstream just a of about choosing ignorant in the face of a problem that someone might need to fix passing the problems on shelving the problems using turning over and sleeping instead as a metaphor and I just love out for them as well as Paseo does lyrics as well when he just delivers his words on this track he just sounds so incredibly gripping and passionate and he just shows so much conviction on this song hahahaha hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the Johnny Cash album at Folsom Prison Johnny Cash is one of the biggest names in classic country and rockabilly music an American musical legend if you're looking for an artist whose sound represents the good ol USA few artists hit the nail harder on the head than mr. cash and when I say that I don't mean in the sense of I don't mean like that even though Johnny Cash did deliver some patriotic songs over the course of his career I mean more in the sense that Johnny Cash's tunes and his sound were heavily indebted to American roots music and gospel plus American folklore played a really huge role in a lot of the stories he told through his songs to not only that but he exemplified the typically conflicted American mindset so well in his personal life and his music to Johnny and his songs were god-fearing compassionate and loving but there was a seedy and violent side to him in his music too he had his struggles with drug abuse as well throughout his life and it's not like he was the only country or folk artist to capture the American spirit or maintain an outlaw image but what makes Johnny special to me is that he did it so well for so long maintaining a very large audience much of the time he did this right up to his final days of dropping records on Rick Rubin's American label and it was great that Johnny Cash left us on such a high note however the record I'm talking about in this review is Johnny Cash at what is possibly his highest note it also happens to be the most badass live album ever laid to tape and this LP continues to rank as Johnny Cash's best album because of its great performances great songs but also because it's a really revealing album too because Johnny Cash's his passion and his personality are on full display in the banter between the tracks the way that he interacts with the crowd of inmates watching his performance one of the most hilarious moments between songs being when he's telling everyone that what's happening is being recorded for an album and that you can't say l or or anything like that and Johnny Carrey it's a great selection of songs for this live show too that shows that he really thought hard and deep about how these songs would be received by a group of people who are locked up in a horrible place for an extended period of time he delivers tried and true hits which made him popular with inmates in the first place like I got stripes and the iconic opening track on this thing Folsom Prison Blues one of the most memorable moments in music being when Johnny Cash initially introduces himself and the crowd just goes insane and if you're already a fan of Johnny Cash you've probably heard just the studio version of this track off of Sun Records it was one of his biggest singles however hearing the live energy of Adhir and hearing the inmates just cheer and howl when he says that he shot a man in Reno just to watch him die it just adds an entirely new energy to the track and this crowd that he's playing to consistently yell and laugh and cheer at the most despicable parts of every song on this album sometimes causing Johnny to laugh and sort of break face mid-song even during somber moments like long black veil their tracks on this LP that also speak to themes of travel and freedom and escapism that would most likely lend somebody who's locked in a penitentiary some kind of relief or fantasy of a faraway place like orange blossoms special as well as Jackson where June Carter is singing along with Johnny Cash and the way that the drums are playing on orange blossoms special so tightly so mechanically it really feels like to me that a train is playing the rhythm section it just adds to the travel fantasy of the track and their tracks on this LP too that openly glorify drug abuse violence and getting jailed like it's a badge of honor like the song cocaine blues where essentially Johnny Cash guns his woman down for being unfaithful while he's on a coke binge he goes to bed almost immediately he tries to run away the next day the cops nab him down in Juarez and even though at the end of the story he says that he's gotten in trouble and let that cocaine and let that whiskey be the song's intended comedy and viciousness is kind of hard to ignore especially given that the crowd is going absolutely wild by the end of the track and tracks like this which are some of the best on here deliver a very frank and straightforward tale of being in jail was just a twist of dark humor like 25 minutes to go where lyrically Johnny Cash is literally counting down the minutes before he's hung by his neck in the gallows and he's singing about his last meal and the preachers trying to save his soul and they're testing the trap and the trap works just fine which causes him to to laugh there's some very humorous and novelty tracks that sort of uplift the spirit in a way like dirty old egg-sucking dog as well as I think the funniest track that Johnny Cash has ever done flushed from the bathroom of your heart which to me has some of the most clever wordplay in a country song and there are songs here too that that sort of deliver hope via spirituality like gray stone chapel and even though the crowd that Johnny is playing to seems really wild and unruly there are some songs on this album that do manage to sort of chill the whole crowd like send a picture of mother where essentially it's one inmate talking to another who was just about to leave get out of jail but it's sort of apologizing about how he tried to escape and now he's never gonna get out of here because the sentence was extended don't tell the family he's gonna be stuck in here for the rest of his life just write back tell him how things are going and send a picture of mother and there's also the song give my love to Rose where Johnny Cash is talking about just being privy to the last dying wishes of a man who's essentially leaving his family behind and there's the wall to which does have a bit of an interruption from the crowd but it's still one of the sadder songs on this LP a track about a man contemplating escaping but essentially just ends up killing himself due to the misery of being stuck in this prison and even though there is some similarities and melody and and drum beat and guitar phrasing across these tracks this album still feels very very far from one and maybe that's because of the variety of stories on these tracks as well as this thing just being an emotional rollercoaster it's not often that you hear a performer connect with a crowd so personally much less a crowd of inmates with these songs Johnny Cash sympathizes with these people he lasts with them he cries with them he mourns with them it's not surprising to find that at one point in his career he really focused on prison reform activism and even testified in front of the US Senate on the topic during a parole bill hearing in the 1970s plus Johnny played numerous unpaid concerts at prisons across America over the course of his career so it's not like the idea for at Folsom Prison was just some kind of crazy out of the blue experiment what's even funnier is that Johnny was not some kind of hardened criminal however he's sang about the surliest stuff so off-the-cuff that everybody assumed that he had done some kind of hard time at some point in his life in popular music today the image of a criminal is typically reserved for something like gangsta rap hip-hop is definitely the the home right now for the modern musical outlaw however with at Folsom Prison and the subsequent at San Quentin Johnny Cash proves himself to be an original modern music outlaw if that's the kind of storytelling you're into then at Folsom Prison is probably one of the best go-to albums now as far as the production on this thing if you're already familiar with the country twang sound of Sun Records and Columbia Records in the 1950s and 1960s then what at Folsom Prison sounds like will probably not be that big of a surprise to you I actually think another reason this album is so great because of the very raw and live performance that was coming together musically on this album that was a bit of a breath of fresh air from the increasingly commercial and pristine sounding recordings of country music throughout the 1960s and 70s the musical performance here especially with the guitars and with the drums is tight its fiery there's just a lot of momentum there's a lot of energy these songs really pulsate they flow they fly they speed by the ballads are tender they're slow they're moving they're really human vocally Johnny isn't as OnPoint as he is in the studio but his person his humor his conviction more than makes up for it and yeah the instrumentals the vocals as well as the inmates cheering all these sounds throughout this record are really just bleeding into one another sometimes drowning one another out however it's it's this kind of wild spine and eighty that I love to hear in a live album it just adds to that sense of place quality that transports the listener directly to Folsom Prison when listening to this album in a nutshell that is at Folsom Prison a country record that is so great that it'll probably make you pity people that say that they don't like country music transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why and why did you feel either of those two things be specific this is gonna be on the final exam cool cool Anthony Fantana Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison forever

by kaljaa chesta thanks for the glasses I'll always wear them during this review The Velvet Underground is a beloved New York band featuring the singing and songwriting talents of the recently deceased Lou Reed and I don't just want to focus on Lou though because throughout the best parts of the Bands career they also featured songwriting credits as well as the instrumental talents of multi-instrumentalists Sterling Morrison John Cale and Maureen Tucker there wasn't really a strong pecking order to the band's lineup which did change over the course of the group's career to the point where the Velvet Underground's final album featured no original members on it whatsoever squeeze an LP that I don't recommend you listen to however I think it is incredibly interesting that in such a short period of time from 1967 to 1970 with such turbulence going on in the band's lineup in their style and their sound The Velvet Underground still managed to put out four full-length LPS that make up one of the most influential discographies in rock music ever it's not often you see a band that puts out a record that is as experimental and is noisy and it's freewheeling as white light/white Heat and then just two years later they're dropping the very commercially sculpted as well as very enjoyable loaded aside from their music what made the Velvet Underground so great was their spine a'ti their ability to successfully accept and reject every convention music had to offer during their time with songs that were very poppy and lovely and gentle beautiful on the ears as well as tracks that were just vivid gritty disgusting displays of sex violence and drugs that would make most squeamish and most importantly what I think The Velvet Underground and this record represents is that great music doesn't need to be commercially successful as well as critically acclaimed upon initial release because clearly this is an instance where we all got it later however let's not just analyze the band in a vacuum for one would we be praising albums like this today if it weren't for the commercial success of albums like loaded or the commercial success Lou Reed saw in his solo career would we be loving The Velvet Underground and seeing them as seminal and influential if Andy Warhol hadn't taken them under his wing are there other factors here I could be taking into account probably all I'm saying is that while great music is great music fame and acclaim are a bit of a perfect storm sometimes plus it's not like development underground was the only band experimenting to such an extreme degree within this time period of music yet Frank Zappa and the mothers of invention Captain Beefheart the Sonics bringing the darker side of garage rock the noisier side of garage rock to the table avant-garde music was in full swing psychedelic rock was in full swing there's also a very general appreciation for the world of rock and roll on this LP - plus there were some other experimental rock and folk acts in New York in this time period as well like the gods as well as the fogs and the holy modal rounders regardless of what influences though The Velvet Underground & Nico is an incredibly bold record for its time and for today and is also very deserving of its definitive and iconic status in rock music it's filled with experimental artful songs that sticky celeste melody that opens up the song a melody that is not only gorgeous but is also gorgeous and the dreamy instrumentation behind it complements it perfectly it's just an amazing song every single time this track out I'm just like astonished at how pretty it is pretty and soft and gentle because of Lou Reed's very breathy vocals on this song the reverb on his vocals to that it doesn't seem like there's that much at the beginning of the track but as the song progresses into certain parts it increases there's a very faint viola drone on this track too that just softens everything and just makes it feel very mm then and then you've got some piano chords and some guitar leads that come in later on the track and give it a little bite the song really kind of sounds like just the Morning Sun coming through the window and kissing your face the leaves are green the birds are chirping there's a little bit of a breeze outside the temperature is perfect it's really what morning must be like for morning people however these very soft and gentle drones take a very sinister dark horrifying turn on my favorite track here venus and furs a song that lyrically is about a dominatrix type character and a song that sonically is a lot like All Tomorrow's Parties in that it feels like this foreign archaic gathering but so much more sultry and sexy and subversive with these wailing viola lead melodies and these very brittle dissonant guitars and on top of all of it Lou Reed delivering his lyrics as if he's some kind of desperate submissive just begging to be whipped as he sort of acts and role of a character from a novella of the same title which this song is based off of again this song is droney but it's also dicey like another favorite for many on this LP heroine not my favorite track on this LP but in a weird way I think maybe the most beautiful song on this record because of how frank and honest' it is as well as how interesting the free-flowing background instrumentation is behind Lou Reed's story and vocals the song and a lot of moments is floating in this very slow very just formless cloud of viola drones some very light drumming some slow guitar strumming and lyrically Lou Reed rambles and meanders and wanders through this heroin fueled haze of his but sort of unpredictably the song just all of a sudden gains momentum picks up speed mo Tucker is playing this drum beat that just gets more and more tension and Lou Reed's verses on here range from blissful toward the beginning of the track where he is feeling like he's jesus's son and there happens on the song I'm waiting for the man a very nasty messy noisy rock and roll song with a relentless rickety drum beat and the song is essentially about a Lou Reed is waiting for his drug dealer and in this song he paints this guy is this weird shadowy elusive character but it's also the situation surrounding this character that makes this song just so vivid you can smell you can taste you can feel this song with the $26 in his hand Lou Reed is going to a part of town where white people usually aren't and he's being questioned as a white guy like what are you doing around here and the very interestingly noisy rock tunes don't just stop there there are others on here like the song there she goes which is a track essentially about a prostitute or prostitution and a lot of people sort of stop their description there but what I think is most interesting about the track is the point of view of the narrator of the song Lou Reed essentially singing about this prostitute from the standpoint of someone who seems like they're really angry or pissed off or they really care about everything that she's doing like they're somehow involved in her personal life maybe in a romantic sense and there's also the song run run run which to me is kind of like an electric Bob Dylan nightmare and Dylan's influence in my opinion doesn't really just stop there on this record it also bleeds into the Black Angels death song - it's one of the many tracks that Velvet Underground when playing this song live would sort of stretch it out - very challenging lengths and then there is the final song on here European Sun which is a track that is dedicated to a professor that we read had at Syracuse University not that it really has any bearings on what the song is or it's about it has a few short lines of lyrics toward the front end of the song and then from there it progresses into an incredibly noisy dissonant and challenging instrumental not really my favorite of the Velvet Underground's more abrasive moments but still it does fit in with the general not fitting in vibe of this album and in a nutshell that is the Velvet Underground's debut full-length LP definitely one of a kind rock record but still an album whose relevance and importance is heavily dependent upon everything that happened with development underground and Lou Reed after it which is not necessarily a bad thing because when tracking the seedy underbelly of rock-and-roll this is an important part of that evolution a lot like the very first moment when the multicellular organisms living in the ocean first sprouted legs and crawled out of the water to walk on land there is part of me that prefers just a little bit more the very freewheeling sound of this band sophomore LP and the very gentle and slightly more composed feel of their self-titled LP their third LP but still when you're talking about The Velvet Underground's entire discography you're just comparing one great LP - another great LP I just would hate for a lot of you to listen to this album like it and not listen to their other work as well again I would hate it 50 years later and we're still peeling slowly and seeing transition if you given this Velvet Underground LP listen what did you think about it love it hate it and why did you feel either of those two things cool cool forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the brand-new burial EP rival dealer burial is the pseudonym of a famed uk-based electronic music producer very well known in the circles of dubstep 2-step future garage and his very atmospheric detailed and moody approach to these genres has earned him quite a bit of praise with electronic music fans and critics but ever since his last full-length LP untrue which he dropped in the late 2000s he's been releasing EP after EP with a handful of tracks on each one and a part of me has actually enjoyed a little bit more what he's been doing on these EPS as opposed to his LPS because I think as he's he's been releasing more music his sound has been getting more progressive longer more expansive tracks more detail more sound play so considering I pretty much like everything that burial is put out as of late I was looking forward to what he was doing on this newest EP rival dealer however I can't say I like this thing it's just one of those moments where an artist who has impressed you on numerous occasions with release after release totally changes directions and changes sound in a pretty big way and the end result is a little disappointing I think diehards will be into a burial is doing on this EP even if it is for kind of a one-off but a lot of this EP did not sit well with me however there were high points on here most notably the title track a song that is not in burials typical style but still very well produced and chock-full of these break beats with just whiffs of drum and bass influence and throughout a great deal of this pretty long track ten plus minutes you're getting these speedy cacophonous drum rhythms repeated over and over and it's being coloured with all these ethereal sound effects and noises a really epic synth line and this really filthy grimy bass line that I like a lot just got a lot of and there are all of these low five vocal cuts that are sort of playing in the background I would say the mix is a little muddy with all these sounds bleeding into one another and the vocals are maybe the most obscured part of the whole mix it sounds like there's a touch of auto-tune on them but with just how bountiful the entire song is with just how many sounds it throws at you it doesn't really overtake the track too much it doesn't really become a standout characteristic it's just a subtle addition to an interesting track and sort of plays its role as a bit of a distortion effect on the vocal which is already pretty obscured by just the muddiness there are these abstract interludes that sort of interrupt throughout the track and then in the halfway point of the song the beat changes up and we get this driving 4/4 rhythm there's an ambient outro some interesting spoken word as well overall this song is really heavy it's enveloping however the other two tracks on this thing I can't say I really care for them at all and for pretty much the same reasons between these two tracks for one the shortest song on this EP hiders seems like a great idea at first with burial introducing these very slow-moving glistening piano chords that are very tender very pretty very evocative I was sort of being moved by this song as it was just plotting on with this very pretty set of chords very grand very uplifting but then this auto-tune lead vocal comes in to sing over it and it just sounds awful I could understand the vocal working on the title track from this thing because of how buried it was and all the muck and just how heavy and visceral the song was but to me this vocal on hiders is really an emotional focus of the track that doesn't really convey or work in terms of an emotional tool it doesn't really make me want to do anything but just the song goes even further downhill as soon as these twittering high hats and just a very simple bass drum snare pattern come into play and typically burial is so well known for how great his beats are and how interestingly they move and progress over the course of a track but this rhythm just grows so stale so fast it's really just like a synth pop song at this point point point point with way too much reverb and some cheesy going on in the background it's kind of like a combination of a very lackluster and boringly written New Wave single and like an endless song coming together and like Power Rangers and what's even worse is the song come down to us not only because it features a lot of the same characteristics but it's longer it just does not know when to quit and the singing is even worse than it is on the song hiders the singing is so off that the auto-tune can barely even cover it mom you are a star with this very repetitive synth line and drum pattern sort of playing out in the first half of this song I feel like burials really again moving away from what he's pretty well known for and instead trying to churn out some auto-tuned pop ballads for sure his very cavernous production style is is still in play however I wouldn't say that that's a saving grace of any of these tracks either and I guess another thing that has remained unchanged is that he still has the ambition to write longer tracks he is still kind of taking a handful of different ideas and stringing them out for 10 for 13 minutes however I would not say that this song gets any better in the second half a lot like on the first track here there's an ambient outro with some spoken word a transgender person is talking about coming to a point in life where this person accepted that that they were worthy of love of being loved that they could be loved still this does not make anything that happens in the second half of this song any more digestible for me especially when the drum beat gets a lot more hyper and the song essentially to me goes like Free Willy soundtrack all the way I find the tracks here that burial has delivered even though they are long and expansive from a melodic standpoint from a rhythmic standpoint to be really under written under developed I don't really care for this sound when other people do it and I especially don't care for it when burials doing it if some of the vocal cuts on this thing weren't so cringe-worthy then maybe the EP would have been more enjoyable for me but the vocal performance is used on these tracks are nowhere near as good as what is landed on burials previous EEPs and pretty much everything that was on untrue so not only am i surprised that burial has totally switched directions in a big way on this EP but i'm also sort of surprised at the lack of quality control on the singing on these tracks unfortunately i'm feeling a strong for to a light five on this thing transition if you've given the CP a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think i should review next and that's it anthony Fantana burial rival dealer forever

hi everyone you know who it is what's up hope you're doing well basically before we get into list week where I'm talking about my favorite of the whole year we have one more great albums segment to
